reviewText:
I met a sombre infected wielding a rusty machete who only wanted to walk into walls.

Why must you walk into the wall?" I asked him.
"Why must I not?" He replied.

He said his name was Phil and he was done with the zed life.
Guts didn't taste the same way they used to.
He said he came to this facility to start anew and wanted to make a name for himself.
I wanted to help out so I threw a decoy bottle at his feet.
All of his bros turned to watch him explode in glory.

10/10

Would make new friends again.
__________

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about it.

Episodical game, each episode consist of 2 chapters - one for Claire and Moira and one for Barry and Natalia.

First of all it's visible that this game, unlike many great episodic games - was not developed with it being released in episodes in mind. Due to that episodes/chapters are extremelly uneven - some are great, offer a lot of various content, some are just walking doing nothing or solving 1 puzzle and you're done. Some chapters take 1-1.5h to finish, some take 15 minutes. Pacing for this game is all over the place.

But besides these things - it was nice side-story set in RE Universe. And it has coop done right this time - characters have different abilities and all are useful.

Oh and DLC content is worthless - both playable content DLCs are just reused maps from the main game used for stupid and uninspired boring gamemodes. TheStruggle is just set of horde modes (defeat all enemies coming in waves, 25 enemies remaining) on maps we already visited with some excuse of a story that you can explain in 3 lines of text. And Little Miss is the same just you get stealth missions instead of horde missions.

reviewText:
After beating the first 3 episodes single player, I can fully recommend this title, even though, apparently, the game is MUCH better in co-op.

+Storyline is actually well written and is fairly unpredictable (compared to most recent releases)
+Graphics are easily the best of the released resident evil games, yet they are not spectacular.
+Performance is a solid 120fps for me across the board EXCEPT in a very few areas where it stutters.
+Team mechanics work incredibly well and are quite original to me.
+Monster design is pretty good, yet not over the top.
+Game is cheap and has a lot of content. Id say the game is roughly 10 hours long if playing on hard and assuming the final episode is the same length as the others. Also, add raid mode on top, which will be amazing once there is matchmaking.
+Great characters (except maybe Moira, who irritates me. Barry is a badass.)
+Game creates a sense of suspense and tension during some points, a feature lacking in recent titles.
+Checkpoints are well spread out, not too far apart or too close
+Game does well at giving you hints and you never feel truly lost at any point.
+Game rewards players looking to explore and players who frequently use the charcters' abilities.
+Puzzles and trap rooms make a re-appearence, but they can be easy at times.
+Game is generous with ammo but you can still run out if you don't play smart.
+Level design is good.
+CLAIRE SANDWICH

-Some parts of the game can become frustrating, but luckily there aren't that many quicktime events (y)
-Bosses are meh, except one which I enjoyed.
-Hard mode is a pain in the *** when playing single player, as the AI is incredibly unpredictable.
-Stuttering and performance may be a pain on lower specs

That's pretty much it. I don't have many negatives. The big negative for me is that I had to restart in casual, because I got to a boss in chapter two with little ammo, and I didn't have a smart partner to get me through it.

Graphics: 8/10
Story: 8.5/10
Characters: 7.5/10
Sound: 9/10
Level design: 8.5/10
Enemy design: 8/10
Bosses: 6.5/10

Final Rating: 8/10 - A great game which adds some great new ideas to the franchise, but unfortunately it suffers in some fields and as a result may not be appealing to some.

reviewText:
Resident Evil is possibly one of my favorite series. While lots of people say that Resident Evil went down hill once 4 came out, I am one of the few old school Resident Evil players to actually have enjoyed all major Resident Evil releases, including 4 and up. Resident Evil Revelations 2 in my opinion is a decent mix of scary moments, with tense action horror. The co-op is extremely fun, and perhaps the most interesting in the series thus far. If you have someone willing to play a side character who doesn't get as many fun toys, but does get some interesting perks, then you or your partner should enjoy it.

One of the other positives to this game, at least on release, was it's cheap price. The game launched at 24.99, and for that price it's a great bang for your buck. The episodes are not extremely long, but they feel just right, and by the end of the game you will most likely feel like you got more than what you paid out of this game.

I do have some major gripes however. This game launched with no campaign co-op support on PC, and while they did fix that, there is still NO ONLINE campaign co-op. I pre-ordered this game assuming this would have been standard, as it was with all previous co-op RE titles, but sadly this game was not. reviewText:
~Rating 7.5/10~

Resident Evil: Revelations 2 is a good game and if you are a fan of Resident Evil you will certainly enjoy the ride. Revelations 2 takes place between RE5 and 6 and ties in strongly to the main story arche of the series. Without any spoiler I will say the events will effect future titles. It was done very well and ties up a few loose ends.

Revelations 2 puts the player in the shoes of two fan favorite characters, Claire Redfield and Barry Burton (star characters from the first two games) who each has their respective partner. Claire has Barry's daughter Moira Burton as her partner and Barry has the mysterious new charater Natalia to accompany him. Claire and Barry will handle the majority of the action while Moira and Natalia will provide much needed support. You can swap between both the main and support character at anytime during the game while the AI will control the other character (think RE0 if you have played that before). The combat is extremely fluid and very addicting once you get the hang of character swapping.

Speaking of combat, this is not RE6. The ammo in this game is far more scarce and you must stun an enemy before you can melee (much like re4 and 5). You will want to use your ammo wisely to make sure you do not run out, which will happen if you go in blazing. A new feature in this game is an MMO style skill system that you can level up with Battle Points you earn for completing chapters. This allows you to specialize your character in certain areas to make them more effecient to your playstyle. If you are a fan of this costumization system you can look forward to spending many hours in Raid mode after completing the main story. In this mode you can choose between many different characters and level them up in a dungeon style setting while acquiring new weapons and skills along the way.

A few of the settings in the game are unsettling, especially the prison where the game begins. However several of the areas can become bland fast and this is one of the games true weak spots. There are some very unique enemies, however there is not a large variety. The Revenants will surely creep you out when you first meet them.

~To sum up; If you are a fan of Resident Evil you should buy this game. It has a very relevant story and some long missed characters. It has a much stronger focus on the survival aspect than more recent titles in the series. The lack of enemy variety and the bland scenery are the most obvious downsides. You do get a lot of content for the price of the game, especially if you plan on sinking time into the bonus modes.~

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations 2 was a wonderful surprise to me. I mean I expected it to be good since I liked Revelations 1. But this was still better than I dared hope. This was apparently a lower budget game, as it isn’t sold at full price. But there isn’t much evidence of cheapness in the final product.

Compared to the main Resident Evil games, Revelations 2 feels a bit crude and rough around the edges. The quality of the visuals is somewhere between Resident Evil 4 and 5, achieving a style that feels oldschool, but also ageless. It gets the basics right of how you’re supposed to stage and light a scene for the intended effect, with the least amount of technical brute force. There are a ton of locations, and loads of different enemies. It doesn’t feel compromised.

The game feels like a greatest hits of features from Resident Evil 4, 5 and 6. Movement feels similar to those games, but now with the addition of being able to dodge in any direction. All the enemies are designed with this in mind, as even the most basic enemies can run and jump at you. The system felt great when I started to get into the habit of spamming the dodge button as soon as I saw enemies winding up their attack animations.

The whole game is designed around co-op, but I played it in singleplayer, and that works just fine. Switching characters is done with a quick and satisfying zooming animation, and the game seems to give your AI partner more health when you’re not controlling them. They were never a nuisance, and I felt like I could just relax and let them do whatever they wanted while I fought off attackers myself.

Enemy design is superb, working both as a greatest hits of the series, but also bringing many inventive new creatures to the table. Most importantly, the difficulty balance feels just as good as it was in Resident Evil 4 and 5. You often get out of big battles with only a single bullet left in your inventory. This is done intentionally, so you’re never screwed over by the game, as it knows to give you a break after giving you a hard time. It’s superbly paced, never doing too much of anything before changing things up, clearly having learned from the best of the series past. It shows restraint, not overdoing anything. For example, there’s maybe only two jump scares in the entire game, and loads and loads of sections where you expect jump scares, but nothing happens.

The most wonderful thing in Revelations 2 is the quality of the writing. It’s unapologetically Resident Evil. Head writer on this game was Dai Sato, who has one hell of a track record, having written some of the best episodes of shows like Space Dandy, Ergo Proxy, Ghost in the Shell Stand Alone Complex and Eureka Seven. He was also head writer on Revelations 1, and it feels like him and the rest of the Revelations 1 & 2 development team work together beautifully. This isn’t some literary masterpiece, as it’s still just as hokey as you’d expect from a Resident Evil game. There’s hilariously evil villains conducting bio weapons research, murdering loads of people without conscience. So this isn’t trying to reinvent Resident Evil in any way, and isn’t going for a new audience or anything like that. This is still the same wonderful ridiculous Resident Evil, but written with something resembling a heart, with a love for what the series is.

What makes this so good is how it treats all other Resident Evil games as canon, but with a level of self awareness that the series hasn’t had before. It embraces the camp, showing clear love for it, and still poking fun at it. For example Barry Burton is a playable character for the first time in the series. He famously had the greatest lines in history in the first game, about Jill being the master of unlocking, and the Jill sandwich line. In Revelations 2 he’s older, a father out to save his daughter who went missing on a mysterious island. Other characters talk behind his back about how he keeps going on about the glory days of when he and Jill went on adventures in the RE 1 mansion, and he keeps making the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ jokes just as he did in that game. And sure enough, when you play as him in Revelations 2, he drops several weapons grade puns. But there’s more to him than that, and it’s the same for all the main characters. At first when I saw that it was a co-op game I thought “eww, but I want to play alone!”. But thanks to the writing, I was happy to always have another character there, because the quality of the banter elevates the game.

You might want to sit down for this next bit: The characters have wants and needs outside of the events occurring in the game, and go through arcs where they learn and change as people by the end of the game. I know, that sounds like the bare minimum of what you’d expect in a story, and yet that is still quite remarkable to see in a game. It’s fairly easy to predict what’s going to happen next in the story as you’re playing. But the journey to get there was more exciting than I expected. Just as it sets out to actually fulfill the bare minimum of what a good story is like, it also executes it on the level of quality that you should expect, where character moments feel earned, and you actually empathize with them. This is again something that is depressingly rare, not just in games, but in your average action film as well. We should expect stories to at least be this good. But they aren’t, which made this stand out to me. They actually gave a ♥♥♥♥, and had people who know how to tell a story be allowed to put it into the game in a way where it works effectively. What a concept.

The game isn’t even close to perfect, as there are a couple areas that feel like filler, and on a couple occasions the story conveniently bails out of scenes prematurely just so they can extend the length of the game a bit. But even with all those flaws, I loved this game. For long stretches of the game I was smiling, and whenever the game tried to be tense and spooky, I was feeling tense and spooked! Everything about it from the title to the tone feels silly and stupid. But it’s the best kind of silly and stupid, done in a completely earnest way, by people who took the project seriously, and didn’t hold anything back because they looked down on the game, the series, or the audience. If you liked Resident Evil 1, 2, 3, Code Vernonica, 4, 5 or Revelations 1, you will most likely have a wonderful time here. It’s everything I like about Resident Evil, without the dreary and slightly desperate tone of Resident Evil 6. Just like Revelations 1, the first 30-60 minutes of the game aren’t the greatest. For a moment there I thought “oh no, have they made another bad RE game?” But then Barry Burton was introduced, and I started loving it.

Many people seem to like Revelations 1. They say even if its not true survival horror, it still goes into the right direction. I dont agree with that. Revelations had its moments, but everything in that game was let down by the fact that its a DS port and you felt it every second. So with Revelations 2 we get a proper Revelations game, developed for the main platforms.
Unfortunately this is not an AAA game, Capcom will probably reserve that for Resident Evil 7. That means that the graphics, animations and sound effects are not great (about the same level as Resident Evil 5). The most dissapointing is the level design. Its not bad, but you can really feel the technical limitations. Actually there are some really cool levels in this game, but Im sure with proper technology they could make much bigger and more complex levels.
The combat is the same as always, but less clonky as in previous games. What I like the most is that they added the dodge move (was already in Rev1) which makes combat much more dynamic and makes you think about evading enemies and maybe trying to use the knife and conserve ammo. And you actually need to conserve ammo in this game unlike many other Resident Evil games (on Survival difficulty at least). I also like the finishers" which returned from previous games

reviewText:
CAPCOM use to be such an upstanding company with a wide diverse catalog of games that while not all award winners were, in fact, rather fun and varied. The Resident Evil series has been wildly skewed since its humble, campy beginnings but it built a lucrative franchise for CAPCOM so it's not surprising that they've been milking this particular cash cow for close to two decades. Unfortunately, their last few additions to the RE series have been ludicrous rather than lucrative, some so terrible that they've become the insult to the injury that the movie adaptations scored in the franchise.

RER2 EP 1 plays absolutely horrendously. The frequent frame rate drops, terrible mouse and keyboard controls, the frankly dated environment graphics, the terrible integration of standing graphics verses interactive graphics, the too short episode (which played like a prolog to the episode rather than an episode), and the blatant lies and hamfisted attempts to cover up those lies about features that were advertised since day 1 of the preorder cycle lead me to conclude that this game was never intended for a PC audience. CAPCOM yet again just wanted to cash in on the PC market money without actually committing effort to adapt to the needs and requirements of the market. It's clear that there was little to no testing for this badly ported title and in how quickly the company was to blame the consumers as well as some unknown copy-editor or intern for the misrepresentation of their product which didn't seem to bother them until the consumers started to complain about missing and/or misrepresented features promised to them.

The cons outweigh the pros thus far in this disastrous addition to the RE series and not even the absolute nostalgic novelty of playing Barry Burton can or ever could take the sting of betrayal, shady business practices, and simply bad ports that CAPCOM continues to employ when it comes to their offerings to the PC market.

TL;DR: This game might look good at first but it pretty much takes a dive within the first few seconds of gaining control of your character(s) and plays like an absolute brick. The story is paper thin, the zombies/monsters" are laughable
hoursPlayed: is typical RE ♥♥♥♥♥. My suggestion is to give this game a pass until at least two more episodes and a veritable crap ton of updates and optimization fixes are released because otherwise you're paying for a terrible gaming experience. Save your money for now

reviewText:
A successful start to the first episodic Resident Evil all while taking the elements that are in place for a traditional and memorable Resident Evil experience with the most effective scares the series has seen in years.

But thats not to say Resident Evil Revelations 2 dont have its problems with weird frame drops/stuttering and occasional crashes outside story mode (while connected to the online service), but the sheer amount of content you get for such a small price make these easy to overlook.

And while you wait for a new episode each week, go play the Raid mode (Hordemode with a few twists) for some more awesome zombie slaying fun. (Raidmode will have Online mode via a patch.)

reviewText: Capcom clearly didn't put much effort into the PC version. Horrid frame skipping and lagging in the campaign mode to the point where it is practically unplayable, even with no enemies on screen. Raid mode ran fine until I got to level 3, where the game tried to spawn a street full of enemies (a common occurence in Resident Evil games), and the game outright crashed. It really looks like the PC version of this game was an afterthought, and it shows all over the place.\n\nUntil the numerous problems are dealt with, I strongly do not reccommend you buy this game for PC.

reviewText:
Well I did enjoy a few parts of this game sadly those moments passed quite quickly. the initial story was good enough for a resident evil game but it dragged on in a way that just made it boring by the time I reached the 50% mark. Not saying any resident evil had an absolutely perfect story but at least some kept you wanting to play, this is not one of those resident evil games.

TLDR: Game bad, no like old game, Raid good fun with friend if have one. It only worth it on discount.



That being said let's look at the other aspects of the game.

Champagne:

Combat: About the same as any other resident evil, it grows as you progress but ultimately becomes a game of annoyance with slow reaction times and twitchy bullet sponge enemies.

Weapons; You start out with your standards and it’s best to keep with them any gun you find will likely do less damage and hold frwer rounds, I honestly dont know why they bothered adding any extra weapons in the campaign I didn't swap one of my originals out the entire playthrough.

Environment; I enjoyed the look of most of the maps the designers really did a good job this time around. the only thing I disliked was how the colors didn't change much from inside to outside. it was all a vague brown red with black.

Sound; I think the soundtrack and sound effects were spot on, even at times i jumped a bit when enemies entered or chased me because something about the sound actually put me on edge this time around which is something that hasn't happened in a long time for a Resident Evil ( looking at you Nemesis).

Champagne; 4/10 it wasn't that good at all, by the time I finished I was more relieved that I didn't have to play it anymore than anything. Really Capcom lets go back to Resident Evil without a partner.

Raid Mode:

Its fun with friends and a good challenging action game as long as you keep your lvl matched to the map that is. its not that fun solo unless you just want to grind to beat your friends score, well if you find that kind of play fun that is.

Raid mode gets a 6/10 only because it didn't start with online Co-Op because an action shoot-em-up cluster **** is the only time you want a partner in Resident evil.

All together I think its an ok game definitely get it on a super sale if you're on the fence about it full price is just a joke for this one.

reviewText:
Well I sure did preorder this game, so I'll add my voice to the growing number of upset and dissatisfied customers about this game's launch.  While I don't really intend to coop this offline I do find it disconcerting that it seemed to be advertised as such until the last minute.

My real complaint is that my HD 7770 is well above the recommended requirements to run this game...and it runs poorly.  It LOOKS good, but it doesn't play good, especially in the campaign.  I didn't even get far before I stopped playing.  It's simply too big of an issue to ignore with how obvious it is.  RAID mode is a little bit better, but there's still issues there.  I'm not sure if the game is actually running in slow motion, because it seems the movements for enemies is slowed down for some reason...it's hard to tell if that's just how the game is or if it's related to performance issues.

Either way, it's unacceptable that this game be released in such a condition.  I rarely preorder games anymore unless I feel they would be a sure thing"

reviewText:
THIS REVIEW WAS MADE WHEN ONLY EPISODE 1 WAS AVAILABLE

Liked: - Raid Mode is still fun!
- Barry's voice sounds A LOT like the old school Barry I find.
- Story (finally not that military crap).
- The main enemy is VERY zombie-like.
- Claire's scenario had some cool backtracking elements (although the backtracking was not present the entire scenario).
- Swapping between 2 characters allowed for some pretty cool gameplay tactics.

Disliked: - WAY TOO MANY BUGS!!!!!!!!
- No offline coop for the PC version.
- It's an episodic game (seriously whoever thought that was a good idea for Resident Evil should think twice before making another game).
- Claire is....different somehow.  She's still a bad-♥♥♥ but her attitude and personality is different (also the new voice aint bad but I realy wish the Degeneration voice actor was her voice actor in this game).
- Game is WAY TOO ACTION ORIENTED.  Not once did I fear I was gonna run out of ammunition and the stealth gameplay should not of been there.  The stealth on its own is fine but it makes the game far too easy and helps in saving ammo that you already have too much of to begin with.
- Barry's scenario had practically no backtracking and frankly the game is far too linear overall.
- Since you always have someone following you, you will not feel any horror.  Don't buy this game if you're expecting some survival horror".
- My PC is beast and Raid mode staggers a lot and feels like my fps is really low (less bad in the campaign but it's still a problem there
date:
especially the staggering).
- Raid mode has some micro-transactions involed (not anything that ruins the experience but still annoying).
- You may now revive yourself if you die in Raid mode if you have some crystals left.  This makes certain missions far too easy.

VERDICT: Man what a disappointment......... if it wasn't for all the bugs and lack of offline coop then I would have probably been happier with the game.  Resident Evil NEEDS to go back to its roots.  Having someone following you all the time removes the horror

reviewText:
Now most of the game breaking technical bugs have been Patched out I can Finally recommend this game
The Campaign episodes 1-4 took me around 5 hours.
first of all the episodes coming out a week apart was a bad move, there is no real reason for them to be episodic but now you can get them all at once its much better to play through them in a row.
Episode 1 is breif and average.
Episode 2 is by far the one i found most enjoyable with the most intersting story and gameplay. with other characters in the fray it feels much more involved.
Episode 3 is good but suffers from too man puzzles in a row. it gets a little stale with Claries section consisting of puzzles and a running section. Followed by one of the blandest boss fights in the game. Its the ustank boss from Resi 6 basically. (anything reminding you of that game is not good)
Episode 4 is decent but the tie ups to the storys plot feels kinda weak.
honestly the campaign is average at best and the extra episodes are not worth playing

So WHY would i reccomend the game to you if the story mode is a strong 6 id say,
RAID MODE thats why.
this is where the majority of my hours come in, around 32 and ive just beat" the main raid mode missions
(but unlocked more to do)
Raid is much improved from the last revelations. it involves going into a mission area and having to kill all the zombies in the level to proceed. doing a mission gives gold and xp. gold can be used to buy new weapons and add cool upgrade parts to them.
parts and weapons can also be found in missions

reviewText: I was waiting for Resident Evil game with Claire as main protagonist so long. Then Revelations 2 was announced (just for information, i've bought handheld Nintendo 3DS just because of RE Revelations with Jill). I was excited, happy. After first trailer, still great. First information was talking about more characters coming back, but also that the game will be divided between episodes. I was not fan of episodic games (most of episodic games has 1 episode per month or more, so i was afraid cause of that, but then the developers said that every week will bring new episode, which is pretty OK for me). I have to also say, i am a fan of classic RE games (static corner cameras, RE 1-3), but for story i've played all of RE games (RE5 and RE6 only for co-op, as i did not like RE6). So yeah, i am big fan of Resident Evil, ever since i saw my father's colleague to play RE2 on his PSX :) And also big Claire's fan, so maybe this review is slightly affected with that.\n\nBut back to Revelations 2. I didn't know what to expect from this game, but i've preordered it. I was afraid that it will be more action game than horror game. Well, locations are pretty scary, but there is also a lot of combat, so it is OK. Cutscenes are fine, but one thing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off right from the beginning. Claire. Her voice. I mean, i was expecting Alyson Court's voice, as she dubbed Claire in RE2, also in Code Veronica, Operation Raccoon City, the movie Degeneration, but she does not dubbed Claire in Revelations 2. This new voice, there is nothing bad about voice acting, it is good, but i just wanted classic" voice

reviewText: This game is actually the best RE of the last 5 years, interesting story, gameplay which is a mix of RE6 and RER1 and a ton of content with both campaign replayability and Raid mode. Enigmas are back, some jumpscares are back, Claire Redfield is back. Absolutely recommended.\n\nGame has some bad optimization issues but you will find a few tweaks in forums which will help a lot. Search for the RER2 D3D9.dll and put edge detect AA and supersampling in catalyst control center after creating a profile for RER2 (don't know the solution for nvidia, but there should be one). Override application settings. That should let you play above 30 in every area, 60 if your VGA is strong enough.

reviewText:
Below you'll find a written and video impression on the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H7cJOhUSL_k

When I originally played RE:Rev2's first episode on PC< it was a buggy mess. Frame drops, crashes, there were problems. Now that the whole game is released in it's entirety I'm glad to see Capcom have fixed many of the problems that plagued the game at the start.

Resident Evil Revelations 2 put you in the shoes of Claire and Berry, fan favorites from the classic era of Resident Evil. You're joined by Moira,  and Natalia as secondary characters, who help you find hidden objects and to solve puzzles. The buddy system is something I'm not a huge fan of. The AI isn't great, and often stand around and take damage. From a mechanics perspective I wasn't a fan of having an AI partner the whole game.

Luckily for us, the poor AI partner doesn't do much to sully the overall experience. The game is well paced, and throws you into scenarios and presents elements that might be reminiscent to older Resident Evils, something that I really enjoyed. The story is also something I really liked about Revelations 2. Though I feel Moira and Natalia to be something of a chore to play with, they are welcomed additions in terms of narrative. These characters are less like super agents that are so prevalent in the RE series, and more human. You learn more about these 2 and how they're involved in the situation. They're also not shoe horned in, the story's main motivation is from these 2 new chanters. The Story of Rev2 also explores a bit of the series origins which was something else I appreciated.

The game also offers a lot of value as well. For $25 you can expect around 12 or so hours in the main campaign, then an additional 2-3 hours in the bonus campaign. Then there's also raid mode and unlockables which has potentially unlimited play. This is not a bad deal purely from a value proposition.

I feel like the game being released episodically overall hurt REV2 in the end. The first episode was by far the most uneventful and it was pleagued with technical issues. If Capcom released the game in full, and in an optimized state that it is today, I feel like there would of been much more excitement for Rev2, and more positive reviews. Capcom literally put their worst foot forward on this one. It's a shame because the game as a whole is actually quite enjoyable.

Pros:
- Well paced campaign
- Great story (for RE standards)
- Great bang for your buck (good value)

Cons:
- Poor AI
- Releasing this game in chunks (IMO) hurt it in the end.

reviewText:
NOTE : episode 1 review and first impression. will update if finished the rest of the episodes

As a child I remember playing Resident Evil 3 and encounter nemesis for first time, the dread I felt back then almost as intense as the first village stage in Resident Evil 4 after the chainsaw dude hunting for my head. While the 5th installment are a delight to play but with a few flaws here and there. 6th was 'okay'.

Then along came the revelations. As the name suggest, it was almost like a capcom had a revelation making this.

Revelation 2 despite a not-so-big budgeted like the 6th, delivers a solid survival horror experience.
The graphics are great, at least for me compared to 6th (5th being the best-looking visuals for me). The enemies look very detailed and terrifying, not to mention disturbing. The details on the character is also well done, the animations still lacks a bit but didn't bother me that much.
The sounds are well done, you can hear the breathing of the enemies (didn't know zombie had to breathe) makes you cautious and gives the game the atmosphere it needed.

and then we got the character mechanics. while the 5th and 6th had a partner that can also carries gun and deals significant damage to the enemies, Revelation 2 brush that off and leave the partner as a support. They didn't carry a gun, but they had their own mechanic such as focusing flashlights to blind the enemies and make them vulnerable, and even sense their 'presence' or locate their weaknesses and points you where to shoot. I won't spoil who are able to do that , you'd just have to find out yourself in the game (trust me, it's more enjoyable that way). Also you can switch characters if you're playing alone.

Now, I played the hardest difficulty from the start, and I must admit after few deaths I started to think I bit more than I can chew. But, after understanding the controls, and the mechanic of the characters can do to dispose the enemies, it was a blast to play. Ammo and healing items are scarce, and when you do find more, it almost felt like a blessing.

Ofcourse, you cannot leave the flaws that this game had. First episode was a bit short. The keyboard controls a little bit confusing, it takes time to get used too.
There's framerate drop here and there, I heard it was worse the day this game launched. Now it has been patched and mostly stable.

As Resident Evil fan, this title is very recommended to add to your collections, at the very least try episode 1.
As a gamer overall, this is a satisfying survival horror experience.

8/10

reviewText:
This RE is a good one, Im not gonna be that guy who says the game is terrible because there is no Co-Op (Yet) I can assure, this game is better then half the games that are out on steam, it's not the best but I believe RE is making their way back to their old survival roots.

Positive things about the game:

- A lot of fun with the gameplay mechanics, learning the mechanics was like any other RE game.

- Nice animations, detail, and creative settings that made this game feel like an actual survivor horror

- Each episode is longer, and more fun because the new challenges as you go every episode

- Each episode gets more interesting as it goes, plot twists factor that big time, a few others too that I wont get into because I dont want to spol anything

Had a good story and an ending that kept you thinking about a new RE coming.

- Simple but great looting/crafting system

- Learning the mechanics to the game makes it really fun and a true survival horror.

-So far the story is pretty interesting and the overall game is immersive.

- The details in this game are great

- Pretty good voice acting

- They brought Barry back, been a while since we seen him.

- The story keeps you thinking, and makes you want to predict everything.

- The game actually made me jump a few times (We all know how long its been since a RE game has asipred a certain sense of fear in anyone)

-You can SNEAK!!!! I dont know why, but it made the game a lot better. (Ive always been suited to a stealthy playstyle)

- There are very many unlockables for Raid Mode and Story.

- Moira is a beast with the crowbar

- These devs put in everything we asked for, a couple minor jumpscares, you have to act quickly and think about how to get out of certain situations

-You can use a lot of objects in this game to your advantage in surviving.

- Headshots actually do what you expect.

- Raid Mode is very fun, I havent had this much fun with an RE game since Outbreak 2 or RE Zero

- Crafting system is pretty good, not complicated or anything special, but its simple.

- Weapon Upgrading system is the same as it was in the first revelations (Gathering boxes of parts)

- Theres more then one ending to this game, so more reason to go back and replay campaign.

- The game is more survival based, along with the story instead of it being like the previous games where you rush. (Group working together, always finding out the new enemies you're going against)

- Pretty fun boss battles

- Claire's new voice actor, makes Claire seem more grown up, matured and battle-hardened.

- I really like the perk system, nothings all that over powered and makes the game much more fun.

- You can use Moiras flashlight against EVERYTHING to your advantage  (Against what you guys have seen so far in their campaign anyway)

Negative things about the game:

- FPS drops in the first part of the story mode (About 30 minutes into the game after getting so far, my FPS stayed at a solid 60) (Also bad FPS drops during episode 3 - Claires/Moiras part)

- (Please fix) It bothers me when I play this game and Claire/Barry arent walking on smooth ground so they look like human vibrators.

- Not much to do in the game (As of right now) All the episodes are not released and have to wait a week per episode.

- Each Episode released ended on major cliffhangers.

- No Co-Op is a downfall, but not a major rupture to the game itself. (Its being implimented soon)

- FPS drops on start menu? That shouldnt be.

- I dont know if its just me, but when I double zoom a sniper rifle my FPS goes to ♥♥♥♥.

- Sometimes story gets predictable.

- Not many characters. Was hoping to see Leon and Chris again to < but thats not really a big deal.

My over-all vote on the gameplay. 8/10
Vote on the story. 8/10
Vote on detail and immersive-ness 7/10

reviewText: Would not recommend for anyone, and actually i have to go and look for the license plate on the train that just ran through my gaping @sshole. I was very hyped and aniticipated a very well made Co-op game that i could enjoy with others online or offline LAN, but sadly i got neither. The single player consists of a useful character and a walking talking flashlight that will do absolutely nothing to aid in finding items or fending off enemies unless you take the time to switch characters with them, which then leaves your useful character sitting in the corner grabbing their ankles and waiting for any enemy to take their turn. The story itself seems like it would work well, but the graphical optimization of the game makes it absolutely painstaking to follow without wanting to chuck a brick at a characters face. If you like Resident Evil go ahead and save your time, frustration, and money by just going out and downloading a psx emulator to play any of the orginal games. I rate this overall at 2/10 for lack of quality performance, misleading consumers and fans into a game that seems to still be in development since you couldn't even release the online Raid Mode, and lastly for making a little girl with a brick the most useful character in the game.

reviewText: Takes some steps from some steps back.... Graphics may not be up to par with previous titles but that doesn't really matter... The controls are good.... The environments have the scary vibe you would expect.... The performance is really a hit or miss and parts of the game can feel unpolished but that is expected for a game with a slightly lower budget and being another crappy port from CAPCOM.... Raid mode is a huge improvement over the first game with more organized enemies... The story will make you ask for more in its current episodic state but it also makes you appreciate each section and not rush through the game with the different characters.... The AI co-op is alright... could have been better.... overall I would probably wait if you are on the fence otherwise this is a must play for any RESIDENT EVIL fan!!!!!!!! XD

reviewText:
Finally after the wait, the game is here. I was so excited for Resident Evil Revelations 2, the sequel to the first Resident Evil Revelations which was the first Resident Evil game I got into. Capcom killed the pc port upon the release of the game which rather disappointed me. Luckily they eventually fixed all stabilization issues with lag spikes that were occurring across majority of peoples PC's. Now that we got that formality out of the way, it is time to discuss the game in its entirety after I just beat it last week as of writing this review.

Story: The story takes place in a prison. You are thrown and trapped into a prison by the evil head behind all the grief you will find as you play, going from area to area in Resident Evil Revelations 2. The storyline is completely separate from any other Resident Evil story line out there in its own right and regard. Capcom created this side series as a response to people that wanted a more survival horror based Resident Evil game as opposed to pure action.

You start the game as Claire in which you are going to a lovely dinner get together with people you know, and then in comes some type of swat team in the introduction of the game. The eye is a symbol of evil relating back to Horus’s day. It symbolizes that there is a person behind the chaos that further happens. That is as much of the story as I can reveal without spoiling too much.

Graphics: The graphics are the best yet I have seen in a Resident Evil game. Mostly I favor the graphics because I enjoy horror games that throw me into a prison or asylum. The Island which you arrive at when you first start playing as Barry Burton is very pretty with light reflecting upon it. This is where you first meet the new character, a little girl named Natalia whose parents were killed at the Terragrigia incident.

Gameplay: The controls are fine, intuitive and no complaints.

Partner AI System mechanic: My only complaint to this game is the partner system. Many times if you don't play as Moira, she will not shine her flashlight always to where you need to go. This gets incredibly frustrating especially in hallways where all you can see is darkness. Some enemies you have to shine the light on with Moira's ability to blind them so you can hit them. If you don't do this on the new enemy the Iron head. More than likely even if you melee him, you will have a quick death.

Scary? Yes and no. I play horror games quite often and intend in the future to replay some with another play through. Some moments gave me scares though.
Primary areas I got scared at or at least my heart felt tension. There are more but these are just the ones that gave me the largest amount of intensity.


1. The Swamps: The swamps was one of the most chilling environments for me. When I looked at the swampy water and the choice between one through three options for tunnels to go down. I inevitably thought of Outlast. I thought of the dreaded game Outlast where Chris Walker would stalk me from the waters beyond what I could see. Don't fear though, enemies don't jump scare you in these swamps.

2. The Final Boss: I will not spoil this. There is just something though about Japanese horror films and games that stick especially with makers behind the Resident Evil franchise. The boss is more scary then Laura; which is the multiple legged long-haired woman spider that is covered in blood in Shinji Mikami's successful, The Evil Within. This final boss battle ignited my heart with tension and reminded me why I play horror games through and through.

3. There is one invisible enemy called the Glasp. It is a huge genetically modified insect. I can't pinpoint what insect in real life it would mimic.  This enemy is so annoying because you are not able to always see it as it makes a horrible sound like a huge bee coming at you. If you don't shoot it in time, it is an instant death.

New features:

1.  Wristbands on all the characters. The wristbands show you the character's response to fear and other emotions as you travel through this game. It is the most brilliant idea to be implemented in my personal opinion towards a horror game. Resident Evil and Outlast got me into horror games. Nonetheless it deserves my rating of a perfect 10/10.

***Note*** When I pre-ordered this game a month in a half before release I was very disappointed that everyone had problems with massive choppiness, lag; including some teleport lag here and there and massive framerate drops. Luckily now through all the patches they released early on this year, the game is polished and runs smoother then butter.

2. Lastly for notable new features, this game is released in episodes. You can buy each episode separately or buy the whole season for full price. There are also two extra episodes you can get if you purchase the full package.

If you want a good horror game and are in the market for a new one to try out, go with Resident Evil Revelations 2. Raid mode is a very good time with a co-op partner. You can go all the way up to level 100 per character.

3. If that is not enough, they have also included a countdown and invisible mode to test your speed and then your accuracy with enemies you won’t always be able to see when they are coming for you. That should add to the scares if the main storyline does not get your blood, adrenaline pumping and also some slight tension with slight jump scares possibly depending on who you are.

Game rating: A+

Scale : 10/10

reviewText:
So I was very weary on buying this game when I read the reviews below, all saying it suffers from horrid frame rates and that the games unplayable and awful, blah blah blah. Its only $6, like a meal at wendy's or something, so I figured why not. I loaded up the game expecting awful frame rates and expecting to dive into the graphics menus to fix it. Instead I was greeted with gorgeous cutscenes and a FLAWLESSY running RE:R2. Played for almost 2 hours so far, and havent had a single frame dip or freeze.

Gameplay wise, its certainly fun and intriguing so far, but so far im not as hooked as when I played Resident Evil Revelations for the first time (3DS hipster player here), which is easily one of my all time favorite Resident Evil's (didnt play 1,2, or 3 so I cant compare it to those, sorry). It has some very intristing dynamics. You constantly have 2 characters, whether it be Clair and Moira, or Barry and Natalia. You can press tab to swap between the two. Barry and Clair are the offensive ones of the pairs. They do pretty much all the fighting. Whereas Moira and Natalia can find hidden objects, like herbs, ammo, etc and reach or open places Clair and Barry cant. Overall its a pretty cool mechanic that im enjoying so far.

I havent tried raid mode yet but if its anything like the original, it will be fun if your just in the mood to blow apart zombies and mutated humanoids.

Overall, I think capcoms done a great job. It sure isnt The Walking Dead kind of engaging where it hooks you and makes you want to finish the entire game in one go, but its definitely intriguing, entertaining, and enjoyable to play.

My PC specs for those who want to compare: Nvidia GTX 960, 16gigs of ram, i7 haswell 3.4Ghz.

reviewText:
Genre - Episodic Japanese Survival Horror

I have only recently played through various Resident Evil Games over the last couple of years including the first Revelations. This game is released with a four episode campaign with episodes released at different dates. This allows you to follow the story over time like a Telltale game. However, there is a bit more action involved here. There are four characters you control in all, two sets of two. Barry and Natalia, Rachel and Moira. All characters need to be used to complete episodes. Moira and Natalia have unique abilities that you use to get past certain obstacles. The graphics are quite nice and although you move along a mostly linear path, there are secrets and items scattered around to find, increasing the re-playability. You also have difficulty modes and an invisible and countdown mode for each episode. The story fits nicely into the Resident Evil universe and you will care about the characters on their journey.

There is an additonal RAID mode that allows you to fight infected of different types and levels. This is where the game should shine. However, at the time of writing there were a few issues with this:

1) I have to play in offline mode, as a soon as it tries to connect to server it freezes or crashes. This is workable, but hopefully it will be fixed at some point soon.
2) There is currently no online multiplayer, when added the experience will be twice as good.
3) A split screen mode was promised and then removed at last minute. However, they have promised to look into this and offer something to compensate (no idea what at the moment).

Basically this is a great game for fans of the Resident Evil universe and there is a lot to keep you interested. You might want to wait until they fix the RAID mode before getting it though.

reviewText:
Edit:  Updated to reflect full season and updates/patches.
Resident Evil Revelations 2 is the best thing to happen to Resident Evil since Resident Evil Revelations. The controls are tight, the graphics are good, and the plot is more compelling than any RE game in the last 5 years.

PROS:
A unique soundtrack.
A surprisingly functional partner system. Both Moira and Natalia have logical, well-implemented functionality.
More classic" looking zombies.
A lot of eastereggs/in-jokes for long time fans
Fantastic dialogue.
Limited ammo drops.
The island has a fitting atmosphere that actually makes you fear the next group of enemies.
The graphics are good
date:

There's an interesting plot that compels me to play more.
Co-Op! Finally!
A lot of throwbacks to the older games in terms of level design towards the end.
They finally patched the framerate issues.

CONS:
Over-expensive

reviewText:
Being a huge fan of the original Revelations, it surprised me just how under the radar Revelations 2 was. I didn't even know of it's existence until I stumbled across it by accident. And now I know why.

It's painfully generic. The shooting mechanics are okay, but aiming feels floaty and inaccurate. Like the previous Revelations, you still don't get a health bar, meaning it's still difficult to accurately gauge how much health you have left. Making the screen pulsing and red doesn't tell you if you can survive one more hit or two more hits. As well, like the previous Revelations, there's still a scanning system. To find the majority of the ammo in an area, you have to stop and painstakingly scan each individual room. It kills the pacing like nothing else.

Also, half of the things in this game are copied from other horror and action titles. If you squint your eyes enough, Barry Burton's campaign looks a hell of a lot like The Last of Us, only even more profoundly ♥♥♥♥. You'll find enemies where you have to shoot limbs off, Dead Space style. Only in Revelations 2, instead of shooting limbs to weaken enemies, you're forced to shoot limbs off to make a random glowing weak spot appear. And you'll groan when you come across Pyramid Head copies.

RE games are hardly known for their original and creative stories. But, Revelations 2 does the 'missing person' plot better than Revelations 1 by leaving the state of the missing party's future ambiguous, instead of showing them being completely fine. However, the story is hamstrung by terrible characters and awful writing. The one-liners are just awful.

To boot, the PC port is very sketchy. Even on the highest settings, the textures are blurry and muddy, and environments are flat and simplistic. The game really does look like a spit polished 3DS port. Even then, that doesn't excuse the framerate problems every time you exit a loading screen, and framerate problems for any map with weather effects.

Also, have fun trying to work past a lockpicking minigame that requires controller rumble when you're using a mouse and keyboard.

reviewText:
I want to give this a good review. I really do. But, I ... just cant. Not yet anyway. Out of the half hour that I ran the game, I spent almost half trouble shooting, looking for reasons why my computer wouldn't be running this game smoothly. Unfortunately, the issues aren't on my end. Capcom did a weak job on the PC version here. I can't even review the gameplay or story, because in it's current state it is unplayable. I really hope I can change my review after some patch work fixes these issues, but we really shouldn't have been sold such a poorly ported mess in the first place.

Things that definitely need fixing: (UPDATE 13MARCH2015)

-Frame rate issues. While some patches have corrected this issue for the most part, there is still some noticable stuttering. This is most notable in the physics on Claire's ponytail and Barry's backpack.

-Raid Mode functionality. It has improved with patches, but crashing is still happening for some.

-Lack of advertised cooperative play. UPDATE: Capcom did patch this. It's a shame they had to patch it in after leaving us to believe we were already getting it at launch.

All in all, at least I didn't pay 59.99 for this. Keep patching this game CAPCOM. I really have faith that you want to support the PC gaming community, but it hurts when you can't create a functioning PC port of your game where many lesser developers have succeeded.

I'm running this game on an ASUS G751J (NVIDIA 860M, 16GB RAM, I7 QUAD CORE PROCESSOR)

reviewText:
REV2 IS THE BEST RESIDENT EVIL GAME SINCE RE0 (2002).
Yes, it suffers from random frame drops and stutters here and there, but they are slowly being fixed.

Besides that, I have to congratulate CAPCOM this time. (it's the first time I do this).
Capcom nailed this one.
It seems to combine the best of each past title, especially RE5 and RE1-3. I hated how action-oriented RE5 was. But now they managed to get the best of what RE5 had and blend that into the RE1-3 atmosphere.
The graphics can look a little 2009ish, because this game problably had a low budget at its disposal, although that's not a problem for me at all.

The MAP system is great! One of the things I most hated in RE5 was that the scenarios were too straight forward, no multiple doors to choose from. Therefore, the game didn't need a map.
In REV2, you can actually get lost if you don't have a map. And fortunately, they kept the REV1 map style, in which you can only see part of the enviroment and are not able to open the whole map. This increases the sense of claustrophobia. Worked very well in Queen Zenobia and is working on this too, especially in the prison.
HOWEVER, this game can be pretty straight forward sometimes, just like RE5.
Example: Episode 2 of Claire's campaign. You need fuel and a battery to start the helicopter's engine. Instead of forcing you to search every room in order to find those (maybe solve some puzzles to get them, like in RE1-3), the game simply point out where they are in the map for you. This is pretty boring.
But let's get back to where I was. Which elements REV2 got from the past titles? See below.

Things they got from RE5:
- Partner moves (Like Claire giving Moira a boost so she can climb a broken ladder; Just like Chris and Sheva used to do - it adds a lot to Co-op)
- Collectible gems or precious items.
- Breakable boxes.
- You can give itens to your partner.
- Fast enemies that make you feel desperate. This feeling is increased by the almost-tank control.
- Can switch between characters to go through certain parts.
- Can use the herb with one button instead of going to inventory.
- Story is split up into chapters/episodes (Actually, this is not a good point from my point of view, but I'll let you decide. Personally, I prefer open world style. If you agree with me, then buy RE HD REMASTER here on Steam before buying this one).

Things they got from RE1-3:
- Puzzle-like gameplay. Need to restore power of machine - engine is missing - find engine - restore power.
- Super limited line of sight increases the horror factor, especially when the enemies are so fast. U feel helpless. It works just like the outdated tank control.
- Good scary moments. I almost peed in my pants in the first 30 minutes.
- The workbench works in a similar way to the chest in RE 1-3.

REV2 has some unique elements as well, like finding gun parts during campaign (in REV1, you could only do that in Raid Mode) in order to improve your arsenal. These parts are all inside chests with interesting unlocking system.
Another thing that I liked is that they not only kept the RAID Mode, but made it better. And let's be real, RAID is much better than Outbreak and Operation Racoon City.

reviewText: ive played this game for a while now with campaigne finished and spend most of my time hunting achievements and doing raidmode. If you are  a veteran of the Resident evil series you might be a little disappointed since its not many jumpscares or overall feeling of dread. The game is mostly action which is ok but i prefer the resident evils with more horror elements. But im glad to finally play as Claire Redfield again last time i played  her was in Code Veronica X, And ofc the good old Barry! The new char Moira is also fun to play with, same goes with Natalia. The game is worth the 40 euros on steam but if your not sure you will like it you can just buy episode 1 and try it out, overall i would give the game a 7/10 not my favourite or most enjoyable resident evil but it was ok.

reviewText: In my opinion, it's the best RE game since RE4. REV2 brings back the atmosphere, the puzzles, and horror as well as a nice blend of action. The story is intriguing and the characters are well-written and have actual arcs and development.I've seen some complaints about the graphics, but I think they look great for a low budget $25 game.  The dialogues are still cheesy at times, but they're self-aware, including some nice references and throwbacks to the old games. While it can never compare to the classic RE games, REV2 contains almost everything I love about the series, and it's definitely a step in the right direction.\n\n8.5/10 (the resolutions could have been better written)
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Best Resident Evil since RE4 (I personally like Rev 2 more than RE4), and an excellent game all-around. And finally a proper RE that focuses on horror more than action. (but ironically delivers a better gameplay engine for action-origented moments than RE5 or 6, or 4 for that matter)

Is Rev2 perfect and everything we want from an RE game? No, but it's still pretty damn good for what it is. It's certainly a good foundation for this series to turn around on. If they can leep things rolling in this direction going forward, RE may yet return to the top of the horror genre.

Dark, creepy enviroments. Actual zombies that don't wield guns and ride motorcylces. No obligtatory daylight mow-everything-down action sequence.  Pacing that is fast enough that you don't get bored, but deliberate enough that it is unnerving. A story where there was clearly some passion for trying to create interesting and unique plot. Enemies that actually look scary and can be scary to deal with. And arguably the creepiest final boss RE has ever seen. Silent Hill level unnerving if you ask me.

Then there's Raid mode. Which is a million times larger and better than Rev1's. Everything you loved from Rev1 but more more more. More levels, more weapons, more parts, more chars, and now skills added the system. (lots of active and passive skills to choose from, which can dramatically change how you play depending on your combination)

Yes, the performance issues and lack of offline co-op was incredibly stupid. But that has since been patched. Though I still urge Capcom to give PC players an exclusive gift to properly make up for those mistakes. Doing what you were supposed to do in the first place doesn't count as an apology. But giving us something exclsuive like No Mercy modes for Campaign and Raid... that would make up for how you initially gave us the shaft.

I really want some kind of No Mercy mode anyway because if there's any gripe I have, it's that I wish the game would throw more enemies at me some times. This game has the best gameplay engine RE has ever had, but it's kind of wasted on the fact that the game usually throws only 5 or 6 enemies at you at one time. I want those intense moments where there are like over a dozen zombies running at me, and more just keep coming as you kill them. (let me experience craziness like the opening for RE3) So c'mon, add some kind of No Mercy difficult for Raid or something. You owe us something exclusive for botching the PC release. Going back and doing what you should've done in the first place doesn't count.

reviewText:
So a long time Resident Evil fan who loved the good old soap opera sci-fi drama of the horror games. I am talking the original playstation resident evil and even the remake. Was not a major fan of 3s run around and shoot nor the new major action focus of the recent games.

This one I feel hit it right on the nail just like Revelations 1 did. The audio is amazing, the story is what I would expect from a typical corny resident evil feel and the dialog is priceless along with references back to the first games and even the new ones. There are moments you have to flee, you need to conserve ammo but not a ton if playing normal or lower, there are a few action sequences and most cut-scenes can be skipped. I would recommend this for any fan of the slow paced puzzle focused resident evil games since it does start to get puzzle focus more in episode 2 and a lot in episode 3.

As for raid mode...I really can't comment...a lot of people love that but I am not one of them.

This is surprisingly not super hard but it does have its moments. Sadly Co-op online is not available but they did just get co-op offline as in split screen enabled. The frame rates are not an issue for me but my machine is a top line editing machine just recently built in the last year for video editing. I do notice where people complain but if your machine can handle what most ports from Xbox 360 or ps3 have then I feel you won't have much of a problem.

The best way to make sure is look up the requirements and make sure you are above the minimum if you intend to buy this for the pc.

reviewText: RE 6 set the bar low, but this is quite competent RE game. Episodic structure seems to work fine in story mode, as characters working in pairs. The story isn't the strong point here, as usual, and the appearance of that particular voice actress from SH series doesn't do much to help. Also, these quotes from F.Kafka are WTF material in general, and not really meaningful inspiration. The dialogue is on par with usual RE B-movie horror style, although if you're an English native, Moira's teenage millennial bits will probably make your ears bleed. The environments have a bit of a Silent Hill vibe, which is nice.\n\nThe controls (gamepad) are solid, and so is the gameplay. The Story can be challenging, even on Normal difficulty, and you have to conserve resources to survive. I tried the Countdown Mode, and the Invisible Mode as well, but I found it way too punishing. The Raid Mode is really addictive though – more interesting than Mercenaries, with all the leveling and RPG grind mechanics, despite most arenas having been ripped from RE 6. I'm surprised I had this much fun with the RE game, as this hasn't happened for a while.

reviewText:
To start with, this game is a broken mess.  My computer is on the higher end of things, well exceeding the recommended settings, but it's been dropping frames like crazy, stuttering, and there's a weird glitch that makes the screen pan in and have a border for no reason.

HOWEVER, with all that being said, I am INCREDIBLY SATISFIED WITH THIS GAME.

Pros:
-RAID MODE
-Engaging story
-Interesting split character mechanics
-Smooth controls
-Old school Resident Evil kinda feel
-Barry
-Gun customization
-Allied partner regenerates

Cons:
-HORRIBLE PORT at the moment, will drop frames no matter the specs in resource heavy areas
-Claire's first chapter borrows HEAVILY from The Evil WIthin for no real reason
-One monster looks blatantly stolen from silent hill
-Sometimes rely to heavily on jump scares even when they don't make much sense
-Abilities present in previous installments are not available until you level up" your character
-Allied A.I. is incredibly dense at times
-Micromanaging between characters can be a bit ridiculous at times.

After playing through both the campaign

reviewText: At this point in the franchise if anyone actually thinks Capcom is going to make a REmake style title when the action heavy titles far outsell the rest, it is on them. Resident Evil has changed. What started out as a slowpaced survival horror has become a much bigger and more action oriented franchise with horror elements. Honestly, they make the most competent 3rd person co op shooter this side of Gears of War. I have deep love for the old titles, but I love the new ones just as much. Give Revelations 2 a shot if you want the slower pace of Resident Evil 4. The game doesn't go to the extremes that 5 and 6 did, but it still maintains the solid action-horror that the series has evolved into.

reviewText: http://youtu.be/rWmzzAWC634\n\nResident Evil Revelations 2 offers some new likable mechanics into the age old formula but still rests on the side of action rather than pure survival horror. There's a fine mixture of puzzles versus exploration and some clever moments fused with equal amounts of frustration that create much satisfaction once bested. Some elements are a bit wonky and could be better polished in terms of control, but in general the game serves its purpose and is easy to pick up and play for newcomers and vets alike.  There's ample variation when taking into consideration the two extra episodes which focus on stealth and team based combat making a well rounded package that's cheap and reasonably polished. Whilst there are some moments where nothing seemingly happens and enemies appear sparse, when they do jump out there's some neat gameplay mechanics (more-so in  Claire's campaign) to give the game is own identity within the long running series. Whilst it doesn't re-invent the wheel, it's a pleasing and gratifying game offering some interesting concepts, an engaging story with some familiar faces. If you're a fan of the series then this is a no-brainer and well worth checking out. Action fans will also find some entertainment here although might find some of the puzzles interrupting the flow a little. If you can ignore the abundance of cheese in the last moments of the story and bask in the game's extra content you'll find a worthy game to add to your collection.

reviewText:
What a fantastic Resident Evil game. I'll make it short. Fantastic, dense atmosphere, some really evil jumpscares which I did not see coming at all,  there's enough ammo in the game but you have to make sure you're not wasting anything and use your melee weapon(s) from time to time. Combat feels solid, the story is fantastic (well at least for a Resident Evil game it really is top notch) and the characters are really likeable. For me, especially the (playable) support characters who do not use firearms. As a nice little side effect this makes the game so much more interesting.

Playtime for me was about 15-18 hours, including the two (DLC) Extra episodes. And my god, those two Extra episodes were great. While The Struggle was kind of a Single Player Raid Mode experience, Little Miss just blew my mind, it was a different gameplay experience, had a ton of fun. But careful, no weapons in this one at all.

By the way, Revelations 2 feels much less clunky than Revelations 1. It's a really, really good game. That's what it is.

reviewText:
The main detractor of this game (at least on PC) is the lack of both online and offline co-op. I feel like the game needs at least one of these to truly shine.

That being said, RE: Revelations 2 is an enjoyable experience both in Campaign and Raid mode. It was fun playing as the different characters+also switching between them in order to find items, get attack combos, or for exploration in general. I particularly thought it was ingenious the way the partners complemented each other. Moira can blind enemies for Claire and Natalie can point out enemy weaknesses for Barry to exploit. Switching back and forth to create these effects felt really cool in terms of strategizing and dealing with enemies in the most efficient fashion.

The campaign is indeed very actiony, but I was glad that it included horror elements. Barry's and Natalie's storyline, in particular, had some really intense scary moments that put me on edge. This was compunded by the fact that I was playing in hard mode, which made it very friggin' difficult for me to manage my ammo and health item usage efficiently. It truly did feel like Survival Horror despite the fact that its style is more similar to a third person shooter rather than a classic horror game.

Raid mode is a lot of fun and I haven't grown tired of it yet, nor do I think I will for a while; the level and skill progression system ensures this. There's always something to look forward to after each level up, whether its by using skill points to level up skills or by finding out that you've unlocked a new active or passive skill slot to use. It's also fun to mess around with all the different characters available, given that each has his/her own skillsets and level progression. It's definitely a great mode to have fun with. It really is a shame there is no online co-op, though.

The game does have its downsides, too. Like DLC. It is indeed annoying that there is so much day-one DLC when it feels like there really shouldn't be. Thankfully the DLC doesn't include anything that's truly crucial, most of it is just bonus stuff that just makes the game easier. It does suck that we have to pay for costumes though. I wish they could have just been unlockables like they've been on previous games. Why Capcom? Why?

All in all, though, I was pretty satisfied with the game. Despite its issues I still think it is a worthy addition to the Resident Evil series.

reviewText:
I heard a lot of negative things about Revelations 2 about it not looking all that spectacular, you can tell its a low budget game, etc. I actually enjoyed this game a lot from what I played of it. I had a lot of performance issues due to playing on a laptop but that's expected for me by now. After days of testings out different settings and constantly having to switch my graphics around, I got it so it works somewhat decent.

The story was on par I feel if you compare it to the story of the first Revelations. I enjoyed the connections to the FBC, Morgan Lansdale, and Terragrigia. For YEARS I've been wanting a game with Claire and Barry since they're my all time favorite characters with Claire being an absolute badass and Barry being that doof with bad jokes but a hell of a father. I enjoyed the character development within Claire and how worn down she has been throughout the years. She lost her touch with dealing with children and her appearance is also very hardened. Barry's still the doofy dad with the cheesy lines but the dedication he has for Moira is touching.

Only thing I wish this game had was more information about Alex Wesker. Her relation with Albert was known but how about those family ties and what sort of relationship did those two have? I feel like more development on her story could've been very interesting. As a very long time fan of the series, this game..for me, did not disappoint and I highly recommend it. It is a little more on the short side with it taking me about 7 hours my first playthrough. Another point I want to add, this game is difficult. In my opinion, Barry's half of episodes are significantly more difficult if you compare them to Claire's imo. I think this and Code Veronica are the most challening titles in the franchise but the challenge makes it more rewarding when you do progess into the story.

reviewText:
I've sunk about 3 hours into the game at this point, and I'm enjoying it so far. THE GAME DOES NOT FEATURE CO-OP AT THE TIME OF THIS REVIEW.

The PC port, however, is rough. The frame rate stutters and can't even manage to keep a stable 30, and the lack of Co-op is a big problem - the game was CLEARLY designed around the use of 2 characters, and many of the mechanics are tedious.

For instance, in order to find some items, you need to point them out as the support character, but the game's AI partner can't do this automatically - instead you must switch to the second character and point them out. This problem wouldn't be so present if it wasn't for the lack of Co-op.

The faces and characters in the CG cutscenes are kind of weird looking, too, but it's not a giant problem.

reviewText:
Review after finishing episode 1/4::
The game ran smooth for me at 60fps (locked) and only dropped when autosaves occured and I really enjoyed it. Sure it's short but no longer than a Telltale episode and their is much more playing" involved here.
While the game is truly picking up it's mechanics from the RE4+ series of games it seems to have dialled back on the whole massive set pieces that RE fans hated about the 6th game. Instead we have a game with wonderful atmosphere and some nice environments (especially towards the end of Barrys campaign) and what promises to be an engaging story. Also with Capcom selling the episodes individually it's quite cheap to dip in and see what it's like.

Looking foward to Episode 2.

Review after finishing episode 2/4:
Ep2 significally ups the ante in both characters sections
date:
with some meaty story hooks and a new more open map in one section akin to the village from RE4 or Evil Within and a pretty good character/boss fight that gets some satisfying development and back story. After episode 2 I am enjoying where the story is leading and the dynamic between the games main characters as well as it's secondary characters.

Review ater finishing episode 3/4:
Claires campaign is the one that shines in this episode as we learn more backstory to the characters and especially Moira herself. The episode mixes some good story telling with a lot simplistic puzzles which brings a certaint something back that old school Resident Evil fans will have missed. Some of the action sequences in this episode certainly throw Claire and Moira through the grill but it's worth it to experience the end of Claires segment which is the best the game has been so far. Barry's section on the other hand kind of gets a little less love this time around. While there are some touching moments in this episode for Barry
recommended: it's let down by the fact that half of it is just carrying a big box around. Still
hoursPlayed:
the episode overall is great and the game continues to impress.

Review ater finishing episode 4/4:
Claires Campaign takes the sideline this time around with it clocking in around 20 mins and only having any story development at the very start and very end
voteText: good but nothing that they couldn't have added at the end of the last episode for Claire. Barry on the other hand brings his A game this time around with his section lasting around 2 1/2 hours on my playthrough. Barrys section features a couple of puzzles and a good variety in locations with the pinnacle being a throwback to Resident Evil 1 near the end. The climax has some good ideas in terms of trying to change up the stale boss fight formula and gives Barry one of the greatest moments in the whole game. A satisfying end to an overall good package.\n\nThe 2 bonus episodes also reveal a couple of things from the main campaign that aren't explained so to get the overall story playing these is recommended."

reviewText:
Dammit where to start for this excellent game. Let's get the big number out of the way.

9 / 10

Graphics: 8
Gameplay: 9
Story: 10
Port Quality: 8.75
PC Controls: 8.5
Content: 10

This is an improvement for the series, it looks good, its gameplay is enhanced over Revelations 1, it has WAY MORE content, a minimum 40hrs was spent half assing collectibles and secrets so it's not a full completionist run, but still more than what most people do... but 40 hrs,  with a hell of a lot of other things to complete.

The story concludes in spectacular fashion and pretty much all the questions are answered by the end of the episode. Resident Evil has had some fun if crazy stories over the years but Revelations 2's story is one of the best in years. For the first time in a long time this game also has 2 endings a good and bad. There's not a lot I can say without spoiling the game but make sure you read all the files it answers a lot of the questions and as some nice call backs to past games.

Bonus Episodes: The Struggle and Little Miss are the two bonus episodes available for download there a fun change of pace from the regular game and have some gameplay mechanics new to Resident Evil. You don't need to play them in order to fully understand the game but they do flesh out the story more. Little Miss in particular as some really fun and creepy cut scenes.

The final batch of Raid Mode missions is fun and the new code red difficulty increases replay value however it was a shame not to see a Ghost Ship style mission from Revelations 1. You also get two new characters who I can't really reveal without spoiling the story but they're both fun characters one in particular as a great ability to make enemies fight each other.

As an added perk we also get some nostalgia in the form of Claire's RE 2 outfit and Barry's STARS outfit.

Revelations 2 was a fantastic ride from start to finish it gave old characters a chance to have the spotlight and the story was without a doubt one of the best since Code Veronica. The graphics aren't the best and the game was clearly made on a limited budget but with fun old style Resident Evil gameplay and a brilliant story, not mention the addictive Raid Mode this game is easily worth 10 out 10

reviewText:
It's sad people are abusing the review system to report 1 or 2 minor things and ignore the actual game itself. The stutters stop after changing 1 whole menu option, and the game is perfectly functional and arguably much better in singleplayer. I seriously doubt all these people base their entire quality assessment on whether most games have offline co-op or not. It's just aimless, indignant rage, and rather than judging the game for what's actually there, they lob off some revenge reviews to tank its rating.

The game itself is very solid so far. For a budget game, it looks fantastic, with its rusty prison cells and pitch black forests. Revelations 1's interesting weapon upgrade system is back and expanded on here, as well as a new bomb-mixing functionality for throwing weapons. Both sets of characters have interesting dynamics, with one being the gun-man and the other being support. This works out in a surprisingly cool way, and somehow I ended up preferring to run around as a helpless child rather than armed-to-the-teeth Barry Burton. The combat is greatly improved from Rev1, now almost reaching the heights of RE4 in terms of feel. This is noticeable in Raid mode, which isn't online yet but has tons of potential and depth so far. There's a ton of ♥♥♥♥ to do in there.

So, in conclusion, if you're one of the people who tanked Dota 2's metacritic score because it didn't give diretide, this game may not be for you and your petty nerd-grudges.
