reviewText: With four different characters used smartly across two interconnected campaigns, Resident Evil: Revelations 2 is a great survival-horror experience. Presented in episodic form, the story rolls forward and brings variety that ranges from stealth to escape sequences. The supporting characters are more than just companions; they are part of a team because the player can control them at any time. The campaign becomes a collaborative effort and the complementary skills bring diversity. Splitting the campaign in half allows for some experimentation, as levels change based on previous actions and key areas are revisited. Online play is supported through a RAID mode that provides arcade inspired content as you level up characters and fight creatures in small battle arenas. Both the online and campaign modes employ a fair combat system that minimizes rigidity while maintaining basic survival-horror mechanics. This is a game that makes it clear that teamwork is about characters with complementary skills, and fear is an excellent motivator.\n\nRead full review[www.newgamenetwork.com]

reviewText:
RESIDENT EVIL REVELATIONS / BIOHAZARD REVELATIONS 2
Scariest Resident Evil game I have played since I played 4 on release.

PROS:
Jumpscares are plentiful. Atmosphere is dark and moody. RARELY any QTE as opposed to RE6.
Enemies can be tough and aren't a cakewalk like the last couple of games. Hard mode is hard. The skill system is nice, I like it. FInding parts for your guns is always nice.

CONS:
Ammo can be tough to find, especially near minibosses.
The lockpicking system seems kind of lame.
Due to being a budget game, the FPS is really bad sometimes even on high end rigs.
Microtransactions in Raid Mode.  Yes, this is optional but I don't like microtransactions all that much.

Overall Rating: 9.5/10

reviewText:
+ Story mode:  Good survival horror atmosphere and is overall interesting so far.  There is a good balance of action and survival/puzzle mechanics.
+ Raid mode:  Greatly expanded upon compared to Revelations 1.  I can already tell that this will be where the majority of my playtime will come from.

- Graphics:  Texture quality is far inferior to RE6 and even RE5 (a game that was released in 2009).  It looks like an upscaled game that was originally designed for a handheld, similar to the Revelations 1 port.  Revelations 2 was designed for consoles and PCs though so there is no excuse for this.  The contrast is also bad.  Dark areas are overly dark, and bright areas are overly bright no matter how you adjust the settings.  There are no proper Anti Aliasing options, the only choice is blurry post processing FXAA.  There is also a constant grain filter applied that can not be disabled.
- Game stability:  I have had a couple of freezes when exiting the game that forced a shut down (couldn't even get the task manager to come up).  Others are reporting huge dips in FPS, I have had no problems myself after the second patch.
- Lack of co-op:  As of release there is no story mode or raid mode co-op (online or offline).  They are planning to add online raid mode co-op eventually but there is no reason this shouldn't have been included out of the box.  This is a feature that Capcom outright lied about.  They advertised offline and online co-op up until the day before release and then changed the store page description once everyone started complaining.  This sort of false advertising is unacceptable business practice.
- Microtransactions:  Want extra storage space for your raid mode gear?  That'll be $1.99.  This isn't an MMO, save files are stored locally so there is no reason for this.  This is just a cheap cash grab attempt.

Overall the core gameplay experience of both Story and Raid mode are dank.  However, the lack of polish, false advertising, and microtransactions feel like a slap in the face and hinder the experience quite a bit.  I'm sure I will put a good amount of time into RE Revelations 2 mostly thanks to the raid mode but I can not recommend it at this time due to the glaring faults.  I will update this review if Capcom addresses these outstanding issues in a future patch.  Until then, this stank turd isn't worth the asking price.

5/10 bomb nuggets.

Edit:  Updated the stability section to reflect some recent problems I've encountered.

Edit #2:  Updated the stability section again after Capcom broke the game further with their first patch.

Edit #3:  Updated stability once again after patch #2.  If/when the major problems are fixed and I feel this game is worth recommending I will do 1 final update.

reviewText:
If you liked Resident Evil Revelations then you will most likely be satisfied with this game. In my opinion the single player is better than the first Revelations and is way better then Resident Evil 6.
Pros
-	The price for the game is rather cheap $25
-	Raid Mode is addicting
-	Solid gameplay
-	Get to finally play Barry Burton in a Campaign
-	Lots of content
-	Great campaign
-	Survival horror theme
Cons
-	There are frame rate issues upon the games release but should be patched soon
-	Majority of Raid mode missions are levels from Resident Evil 6
-	No local Coop
-	Online will be updated at a later date
-	Mouse arrow won’t go away during cut scenes. Again this should be patched in the future.
Overall the game is a lot of fun, and the issues above don’t ruin the experience for me but might for others, but I would still recommend the game to Resident Evil fans.

reviewText: I am NOT dissapointed because of no co-op.  On the contrary, I am quite happy about it.  What  I am mad about is once again Capcom, the CREATOR of survival horror has once again released an action game.  Resident Evil HD Remastered has broken records for digital sales, and sold more copies in January than ANY OTHER GAME.  That is because the original games have an almost cult-like following that want the classic resident evil back.  Give us the option for fixed camera or over the shoulder.  Put back REAL puzzles in the game, that have you backtracking back and forth like a mouse in a cage.  CAPCOM LISTEN TO THE REAL FANS WHO HAVE BEEN WITH YOU SINCE 1996 !!  Look at your sales, go back to your roots and stop butchering the genre that you birthed.

reviewText:
Ok first and formost this is the most fun Ive had in a RE title in years. RE6 to me was nothing short of a absolute disaster. And RE5 was just gears of evil. While I did enjoy Rev 1 it had its moments that had me just annoyed and frustrated (on both 3DS and PC) but I LOVED raid mode.

That said...

I have been Loving REV 2.

So far Ive only completed Clairs story and will knock out Barry's soon, but I had to dive into Raid mode and to my surprise I loved it even more.

So Campaign is a kind of shout out to RE roots with a shot and being atmosphirc and scary. Now while the scares are really just jump scares it has a very Evil Within feel to it and Im fine with that. Now as I played threw the story I did get a few of these framerate drops but they were few and far between eachother and by no means made the game unplayable. As for the AI its back with all of its stand in everything stupid glory. I found doing the game on survival Difficulty was borderline impossible due to the AI having their own Health this time around and being very adverse to shooting a freaking gun. That said I dumped down the difficulty and just sat back and steam rolled it to a pleasent start to a decent story looking foward to the rest of the episodes.

Now Raid mode

It is sooooooo much better than Rev 1 first and formost the Maps. They dont just throw you into locals from the single player game no they toss you into locations spanning from from what ive seen so far RE2-6 which I love. The character progression is seperate this time around and the skill tress add for a nice addition to leveling up (btw Hunk SOOOO OP) the fighting is far more fluid and while the aiming took a bit to get used to Im pleasently happy with it as I havnt had any issues with getting Head shots. The Gun customazation has been awesome. Instead of just basic pierce and knock down you can add elementle affinities to your weapons (all the old stuff is still around) which again adds to a deeper custimization than the first.

All in all im 100% happy with my purchase and cant wait for Online to come out in 4 weeks so I can tackle raid mode with my friends. The AI is trash but that has been the case for years now nothing new to the RE series there (ashley was the only decent" ai) Also Ill say the facial graphics leave something to be desired as when they talk their mouths just kinda flop all over.

So if you were a fan of REV 1 id recommend this absolutly. If you only enjoyed Raid mode with friends id say wait till all 4 episodes are out up to you but for sure pick this one up."

I played the game for 15 minutes, realized that Crapcom always seems to prove me wrong with every subsequent release of the Resident Evil... or should I say the BIOHAZARD franchise... because I guess THAT'S getting forced down our throats now due to all the weebs in Crapcom's fan club.

When Resident Evil 5 came out and I had finished it, I thought to myself... wow what a pile of dog ♥♥♥♥... Then came Resident Evil 6 and I was like... huh, Resident Evil 5, not such a bad game after all... the co-op was nice... yeah... and Matrix Wesker wasn't THAT bad... was he? Nawwww.

Then came the turd Resident Evil Revelations... I was like, alright WTF is this trying to do? Who are these characters? Who the ♥♥♥♥ is that!? What is going on? Why does this game play like a tin man's ♥♥♥♥ trying to work a poon hole... ugh. CRAB PEOPLE!?! THE FAAAAACK!?

reviewText:
Well I am an oldschool RE fan and I've played every RE, some even several times.

I really liked REV1 so I instantly bought this one and well its far far worse than the first one.

The story is quiet boring, linear and well not very impressive at all, the ending is very disappointing.

The locations are boring too, you just realize, you've seen everything before and they even included a mini mansion with a damn underground laboratory, just gotta make sure everything's checked on the list.

The enemies are by far  the most boring and annoying ones ever seen in a RE (except the zombies), not to mention certain special enemies are overused to death and everything looks like some weird mutated Jelly that can't be identified as anything anymore (savings made with the enemy design, check) there are no real bosses whatsoever and the final boss, just something to forget. And yeah they brought back the yellow blisters you gotta shoot to kill most of the enemies.


Overall its just a disappointment, what's left of RE is just a mediocre coop action-shooter, didn't even took me 6 hours to finish this on survivor, if you're a true RE fan, buy it on sale and play thru it one time and just forget about it.

reviewText:
Even though this was the first episode I feel a review is in order  The Storyline is awesome as usual for the RE franchise.  Being able to find what you need is fair if you actually look for it.   The controls and settings for the controls, as well as display settings, are a toss up for me however!

Aiming and targeting are fine as well as the normal foward movement, which is what should be expected of any FPS.  I also find switching between characters to complete tasks interesting.  However, turning around on the spot is extremely sluggish.  I like to be able to turn on the spot when I have to go back to a previous position, not wait for what seems like 5 seconds for the character to turn around.  The movement should really be more fluent and easier to use.

Also I've noticed that the games crashed quite a few times. Not sure if thats a game or steam issue, or just my PC, but I found that my interest to play lacked because of it.

As for the control and display settings, when trying to brighten the diplay and increase the mouse sensitivity, I found that doing so didn't make any difference at all to display  or mouse movement.

This being said, the gameplay was fun overal, but could use a little more developmental tweeks.  I am recommending this game because I am a fan and I enjoyed the story.  If you like good story progression, then I suggest this as a buy.  If you are more for gameplay style, I suggest you save your money

reviewText:
Upon release, RE: Revelations 2 had a lot of performance issues that made it impossible to play at times. Despite having the recommended specs, my experience in the beginning was plagued with stuttering and low frame rates.

Since Episode 3, it seems Capcom has patched those performance bugs and it runs great. It is certainly playable and I thank them for listening to fans, even though it took a while to fix.

Gameplay is similar to RE: R1 and keeps a similar feel. Honestly, the first felt more creepy than this one but the story is a bit more engaging since it doesn't split off with 3 or 4 different teams.

I also like that there are multiple endings, which harkens back to classic Resident Evil.

Aside from the beginning performance problems, I enjoyed this game and recommmend it to all RE fans. Lots of playability and you get your money's worth with story mode, extra chapters, and raid mode.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The mood of the enviornment is well done. The music is great, and it does feel scary on the first playthrough. Fighting new enemies is challenging when they come in packs, and also resources can be scarce when playing on high difficulty. New characters are interesting and likable (expect for Moira's swearing). Moira's inability to use firearm is not as frustrated as I first thought, and though Natalia can't use weapons at all her ability to sense enemies from afar is useful. There aren't many puzzles in this game, but some does require the corporation of two characters, or the unique ability of a character in some way. However, this create a problem in single player campaign on PC as there's no co-op, and continuously switching between characters does lengthen the finishing time. I don't have any issue with the graphics, I think it looks fine and I don't complain as long as the gameplay is fun.

I personally think it is better than Revelations 1, The gunplay definitely feels better than the first game, and the episodic story works fine for me too. Raid mode is fun, but I always prefer the campaign mode. All in all, it is a nice game added to the RE series. I believe the future games will take the good ending as the canon ending?

I'm glad that the frame rate issue and Barry's immobility in the final boss fight are fixed! Also, it would nice to view weapon/creature stats on RE net too.

reviewText:
Great story, they are definitely trying to take it back to more horror based gameplay, rather than straight action. Both Claire/Moira and Barry/Natalia stories are captivating as you learn more and more about their relationships. Plenty of twists and turns with the story.
I'd the give story a 9/10.

Raid mode is solid, they fixed a lot of things from Revelations 1. I will admit I feel as though raid mode is lacking an assortment of weaponry. Other than that, it's enjoyable. The one downside is the maps. A good 95% of the maps are either Revelations or RE6. Even the throwback maps are from those two. They are used repetitively, only barely varying. Raid mode is fun, and time consuming if you want to get all the medallions for all of the guantlets.
I'd give raid mode a 7.5/10.

reviewText:
I loved RE: Revelations, and I must say this one is actually a bit better.

I liked almost everything from the characters, a lot more realistic than usual, to the story, very intriguing and captivating.
Sounds and setting are really awesome too, they made the survival horror experience real (More than RER1), i still have bad dreams hearing the song from the factory in EP. 3 LOL
One thing I liked particoularly is the enemies design: though there are not so many different types of enemies, they are really well done, creepy and disturbing at the right point ( i refere especially to the invisble ones and the revenant).
Bosses are nice too, though not too hard to beat, unless you play in survival mode.

I never cared much about the missing local co-op, since i've always wanted to play this game in single player, so I really enjoyed every last bit of it, from the beginning, and with all of its contents this game really offers a lot.

P.S.: I did have trouble running this game in its early days, but now I can play on a normal laptop with max res and graphic parameters.

reviewText: I went in with very low expectations. I wasn't a huge fan of Revelations so I wasn't sure if this one was going to be any good. I wasn't even going to play it until I heard it was decent from a few friends and reviews. I decided that I'll buy the first episode and see if I like it. I was blown away. I truly felt scared at certain parts and they actually have a good balance between survival horror (Claire's episode) and action horror (Barry's episode). On top of that, I feel very invested in the story. Sure, it's still cheesy as hell, but the first episode (which, by the way, is all I've played so far, will update after playing the rest) ends with one hell of a cliffhanger that will definitely have me buying the season pass at some point. Highly recommend it to all RE fans, be they the newer generation who enjoy action horror, or the generation like myself who prefers the good old survival horror in the originals. If you're still unsure, shell out the six bucks and play the first episode at least. I can guarentee you WON'T be disappointed.

reviewText:
A return to form for the Resident Evil / Biohazard series. Everything I hated about RE6 is absent in Revelations 2. It gives me renewed hope for the future of Resident Evil.

Getting to play as Claire again in the main story was awesome, something I've looked forward to for a long time since Code Veronica. Moira, Claire's partner throughout the story, was a great new character that spiced things up and helped with some occasional comic relief. You learn to enjoy her banter after a while. It's hilarious, honestly.

The partner system in Revelations 2 was really well-utilized and fun. It reminded me of Zero's a bit, but this one is much faster. The partner characters also are more unique, in that they can't use guns and instead contribute to the team in other ways. You would think it would be boring to play as a character that can't use guns, but I found it refreshing.

The game has a nice variety of settings. The marketing for this game focused almost entirely on the prison, but that's actually just the first of many locales you explore in the game. There is even a mansion segment of the game that serves as an awesome throwback to RE1, complete with claustrophobic hallways and creepy paintings.

One thing I have to note - this game is really obviously lower budget, and you will have to lower your expectations with regard to visuals if you want to have a good time. The texturework is nothing to scream about, and the high-quality texture work seen in RE6 is mostly absent here. And, oddly enough, when they are present they are used where they shouldn't have been. For example, tree bark isn't shiny and glossy in the real world, but in this game, it often is... It gives the impression that the spec, bump, maps etc were hastily auto-generated to save time/money, not baked manually and professionally. It's almost as if Revelations 2 began as a 3DS game and was ported over very late into its development, because that's what it often looks like - a low-res 3DS game. There is also a disparity in quality with regard to polygon counts and other things. Sometimes you'll be in an area with really gorgeous models and then suddenly you'll be in another area with models that look like something from the N64.

None of that detracts from the experience too much though! Overall this is a fantastic addition to Resident Evil, and I recommend it to any fan of the series. Despite being a lower budget entry, it's EASILY a much better game than RE6, and I dare say even RE5. To me, Revelations 2 is the game that RE5 should have been, as a true followup to RE4. It takes what RE4 did, and innovates on it by adding some new gameplay mechanics not seen before in the series. Just a shame Capcom couldn't justify giving it the same budget it gives to the main numbered titles, because this game definitely deserved it.

reviewText:
Pros:
This is probably one of the best Resident evil games since Resident Evil 4. Not just a zombie action shooter like much of resident evil 6. There are lots of puzzles, immersion and character development in the game alongside the classic resident evil survival horror genre interspersed with some action sequences where you need lots of ammo (that you should have been saving).

There are 2 endings of the game based off a cutscene with Claire / Moira  at the end of Episode 3. When you get there, look up how to get either ending if you want. After I played the game I wish I had known that and replayed Claire's episode 3, and Barry's episode 4 to get the other ending.


Cons:
I have a fairly old CPU but fast SSD and Unfortunately the game still needs some bug fix/ optimization patch on PC for pre-loading / caching. To me, it seems that there are still things to preload, after the loading icon disappears, and your game may lag for 10-40 seconds while it continues to load. The lag does go away however, after this 'unfinished loading' is done. My suggestion is to run the game in windowed mode, so whenever you get loading lag, just pause game and do something else. The pre-loading will continue while paused. If you have a faster CPU, you'll probably have less lag, but my 6-year-old Q6600 @ 2.61 ghz quad core, was getting pretty much 100% CPU usage until this loading finished. I don't know of any fix for this yet but there are some discussions of it on the forum.

reviewText:
EDIT: I have to rewrite this review, because I found out why the game was running like ♥♥♥♥. Vsync is apparently not a friend of mine. If your game runs like ♥♥♥♥, try turning off VSYNC.

Now that all the episodes are out I have to say I am thoroughly enjoying this game, I was a little on the fence about where it was going at first but the last two episodes in particular were worth every penny. There are some pacing issues here and there, but for the most part the game flows well. It has a lot of replay value, and though the raid mode is not as good as I'd hoped it would be, I cannot say it is a let down. I did not buy this game for the raid mode, I bought it for the campaign, and in that aspect it delivered.

I can recommend this game to most Resident Evil fans in a heartbeat, I can also recommend this game to most gamers in general. It's a great experience, even with its flaws.

reviewText:
I have just finished playing through the first episode. Honestly, it was incredible - much better than the first Revelations, packed in just a couple of hours gameplay.
I regret not pre-ordering this game, as the last few games in the series made me anxious about buying this one. After reading reviews saying that it brought back the classic, unique element of survival horror that the older games offered, I decided to give it a shot, and now I can say with a chill down my spine that this is the scariest game of the series, at least from what there's been in a while. Play with the lights out at your own risk, I started off on the Survival difficulty, which was a great experience.

I would strongly recommend to any fan of the Resident Evil franchise, and to anyone who enjoys the horror/survival horror genre in general.

reviewText:
REvelations 2 is a game that came off as an awkward sequel to Resident Evil Revelations but ended up being a pleasant surprise. The game improve some mechanics of the previous game, although others where worsened.

Compared to the first game, you now have an inventory that needs to me managed properly so you won't end up with excess of items you may not need and lack of those you may need, much like the classic Resident Evil. Despite being more linear compared to the first game, it still encourages exploration and searching using Moira's flashlight or Natalia's ability to see certain things in the dark, which adds to the linearity making it a nice change of pace.

Unlike modern RE games enemies don't drop items, but you have to find them on a fashion similar to the GENESIS of REvelations 1. However, customization of weapons is lacking on this title, due to pieces being extremely rare, by end game you'll probably use all of them on your guns, unlike in the first REvelations. The health system is the same, but it indicate poorly since it only adds the bloody effect rather than both a bloody and a desaturation screen effect of the first game.

Claire's chapters 1 and 2 are a bit dull, 3 is good, it even includes a puzzle for extra stuff, although 4th is basically a escape from the auto destruction sequence we see on all the games so far. Barry's chapters on the other hand are far more interesting and add a sense of isolation from early RE games, since Natalia can only help pin pointing things and throwing bricks.

The plot gave me mixed feelings due to how the game ended, but the story tellign makes up to it, despite being nothing exceptional. And although Capcom wanted players to use play more on RAID mode, Story mode, despite being short compared to REvelations 1 has it's own share of replayability with hidden things to search for. I also recommend the extra chapters since they have their own interestign mechanics (one based on item gathering for progression without resulting in going to the start point when losing, and other based on pure stealth).

Final score based on my experience: 7.5/10 - Is not the creepy, scary RE classic fans want, but it's still nice for its setting and campaign.

reviewText:
Resident Evil Light (but still a good adventure game)

I really enjoyed this game. It's not as good as the first game and it's not as creepy as it should be but it's a great adventure game with a gloomy atmosphere at its best parts. Playing with 2 characters at once and switching between them added some depth (There are scouting and fighting characters and you need both). It was fun to fight and sneak and to explore the well crafted levels. The crafting aspect felt a bit dull though. The graphics were still good and fitting, the sound effects and music were great. The story was well told. the characters were very likeable.

The quality of the 1st addon suprised me. The Struggle" is a short story with Moira as main character and it features perma death. Especially on the harder difficulty level you`ll need a few tries to beat the game (Don't forget you can switch characters here too). The storytelling and gameplay are on the same level as the main game.

I'd rate this game  2+."

reviewText:
Came for the story, stayed for the raid.
I just played the first ep, which people say is the worst but I think it is pretty well done.
The raid mode is something like phantasy star online in a creepier setting, with lots of different scenarios though not so different enemies and barely final bosses, though you will find some.
Still, raid mode is great and you ll be able to find people online, even if you cant join no one just make a game and wait a bit.
The best part is that you may be playing with someone from a very distant continent and you wont have any lag, even playing at lesser than 500 kbps, and dont worry if you dont have a gamepad cause keyboard mouse works like a charm, its what I use to play.
Edit. Now I see that if both players have a really bad connection they wont be able to play together, but most of people have a decent connection, so it wont be a problem

I am changing this review a lot.
Raid mode pros:
- addictive, lots of settings, not an epic ost but it helps to keep the fast pace, lots of characters and cool skins, rpg elements which are good.
- the interface is quite friendly.
- is fun even playing solo.

Raid mode cons:
- rpg means a lot of grinding, though it can be shortened with the soul eater weapon part, not so many enemies and barely final bosses (close to 20 different enemies, 5 or 6 more would help to keep it fresh)
-  the fact that all the characters can have, through that grinding, any skill from the others. I would see more challenging that each character would have some skills available but not all of them (for example gina's set of skills fits to her, and same with the others), but cypher, I could understand it could have any skill.

Summing up raid mode is great, it seems to me that it needs some changes, but basically the idea and execution is fantastic.

reviewText:
It started out promising, but as I progressed through the episodes it felt like they put less and less effort into them. The game could have been so much more if it allowed online co op, as nearly all of the gameplay mechanics were pandering to co op play. Like one character being the support and the other being the gunner, one being able to spot enemies from behind walls and objects and the other being the obvious combat role.

Playing through it single player was extremely tedious. The game forces you to swap between them in certain segments as the AI itself is pretty much rigged to follow you (and often even fails at simple tasks like that)

But the atmosphere and spooky jumpscares and monsters were pretty great and for that reason I would recommend a playthrough of this game if it's on sale.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm not a big fan of horror/jumpy games as, in all honesty, i'm a bit of a wimp.

BUT

I played 3 episodes of couch co-op story mode with my brother at his house and I became immediately addicted, i've not braved finishing the story on my own yet, will probably do that next time i'm at my brother's house. It's not like other Resident evil co-op modes, in this game you have someone who can play the shooter/stabber and another who can find clues/secret items/smash enemies melee style....or....point..... XD So there's a different aspect to many co-op shooter games out there.

I have been on the online raid mode quite a bit and it's pretty great, best online co-op part of a game i've seen for a long long time, finally we have something to play that we can stick at for hours on end; it's been a long long long time since we enjoyed an online non-mmorpg game like this.

Online mode consists of a lobby (physical room) where you can buy,upgrade,sell weapons and parts and upgrade your characters skills. You can then select to join a partner/find a partner or go for a random online game - or you can just raid alone. There are also daily challenges and timed special events to take part in though I havent took part in a special event as of yet.

I highly recommend this game for both the story (so far) and the online/co-op modes, fantastic game!

reviewText:
The Story of Resident Evil Revelations 2 : Claire Redfield & Moria Burton are attending a commemoration party when all of a sudden the  lights go dark and  a group of masked assailants raid the headquarters and have Claire, Moira, and many other attendants captured. You then wake up to find yourself in a  prison alongside with Moria wondering why and how you got here and what is the attentions of the person who brought you here.


PROS :Tons of DLC Content, Great Voice Acting, 7.1 Surround Sound, Raid Modes Unique Customization of Characters, Weapons  & Upgrades, Online Events & Support for Newer Weapons

CONS:Lacks built in Anisotropic Filtering support, but you can easly turn it on in your gpus control panel
Random FPS Drops from time to time, No Online Support for Story Mode unless you use the  mod found on the  Resident Evil Modding Community page, Built in Film Grain which makes the game look dull and ugly but can also be  turned off with Film grain removal mod, game may crash randomly if you alt tab .

Overall with this cons this game has I still find it enjoyable for hours on end farming in raid mode for new weapons...

reviewText:
As an old school fan of the Resident Evil series [culling the infected since '96], I have to say that this series has definitely had its ups and downs. I still remember the completely game changing shocker that was Resident Evil 4, shying away from the traditional Survival Horror we were used to. After that, the franchise seemed to have lost its way a little. Resident Evil 5 was atrocious, both in the way of the plot, and in the character development. [Chris became a giant steroid monkey, and Wesker loses it completely and goes over the top, a terrible ending to one of my favourite video game bad guys] Operation Raccoon City was a very enjoyable non-canon romp through Raccoon City during the height of the T-Virus that stood apart from the rest of the franchise. Revelations was an interesting game, and 6 was... okay. It had its moments, but felt like it was trying to be too many things.

Revelations 2 however, hits the nail on the head. On one hand, you've got the ever brave Claire Redfield, sister to franchise protagonist Chris, fighting alongside Moira, daughter to Barry Burton, whom also was in the original game from way back in 1996. The two women have been kidnapped and are being held on an island somewhere near Russia, and are being monitored by someone called the Overseer as they try to find a way of escape. Unfortunately for the ladies, they are part of an experiment on a new virus called T-Phobos; a variant of the Uroborous virus, which is triggered in states of extreme fear. On the other hand, you've got Barry Burton himself, alongside a strange young girl named Natalia, trying to track down Moira and Claire on the island.

Each campaign has a distinct feel to it. Claire and Moira's made me feel constantly under pressure; Why have you been brought here, what the hell are these things trying to kill you, and who the hell is the Overseer and what is her end game? It is a very fast paced campaign, with quick enemies, boss monsters o'plenty and a defined goal: Escape. Barry and Natalia's campaign is more a slower paced, creeptastic crawl through the horror. Shambling zombies [although some who can pick up speed quickly, and some with extremely long reach!], more firepower, monsters that change depending on how you previously defeated them as Claire and Moira [I'm talking about normal enemies, not boss monsters!]

Each campaign has its own sidekick gimmick. Moira has a flashlight which can be used to blind enemies [setting them up for a strong melee knockdown] and can attack foes with her crowbar, whereas Natalia can sense and detect enemies through solid objects, and can throw bricks. [Don't knock the brick throwing, sometimes it's hilarious to hoss a brick at a zombie and watch it crumple] Each of these bring a different style of gameplay. If playing solo, you can jump back and forth between your character and their sidekick. So you can jump to Moira, use her flashlight to stun the quickly advancing Hammer Dude, so Claire can run forward, kick him to the ground, and you can quickly run up as Moira and implant your crowbar directly into his chest, weakening [not killing] him considerably. Whereas Moira can be a hindrance to her foes, with blinding lights and crowbar stuns, Natalia can be a very very helpful little lady! Using her ability to figure out where your foes are positioned can make for some very satisfying stealth clears, where it's possible to clear entire areas without being seen or heard.

I suppose I should try and wrap this up, as I could quite easily write an essay on this game.

As a Resident Evil fan, I think it's a step back in the correct direction for the franchise [although this game does officially tie up the LAST loose thread of the entire Resident Evil story line, so perhaps it could be the last step before the 'reboot' that has been mentioned a few times]

It has a couple of jump scares, likable new characters as well as returning fan favourites who have been out of the lime light for some time. I didn't have any performance issues, and it ran surprisingly well on a set up that is 5-6 years old.

Definitely worth picking up, especially when it's as cheap as it is right now!

reviewText:
I'm looking at some of the negative comments for this game, and I can't really see what the big deal is.

Ran this on an i7-4790k and EVGA 970 SSC with no hiccups, black screens, or slowdowns. Didn't really know this game had split-screen co-op nor did I really care for it, but I had two controllers anyways. Even after downloading the following episodes and other dlcs I never experienced any long loading times or crashes (then again, I'm running it on an SSD). I dunno about anyone's builds, but I'd look there and discern any possible problems there first instead of blaming the game instantly. Then the price is really aggreeable considering the entire full game. Most people are just afraid of buying something in episodes, which is not a problem. But when the full base game, all 4 episodes and even adding the 2 DLC episodes, are less than $30, and the deluxe edition (all DLC) IS $30... I dunno it seems like a good deal when even NOT on sale.

The story was engrossing and I'm glad to have bulk-bought the rest of the episodes after going through the first one. It was also cool to see and play as Barry again since... well more than a decade ago. Then Claire is always a welcome sight since growing up with RE2. The side characters, albeit only being mainly utilitarian in gameplay, still were a good hook into the story. Then having one duo trace the steps of the other gives that sense of constant care and vigilance even amidst the horde.

The enemies were okay. Not too bad but not the best. They could've had a bit more to them, especially after playing through raid mode a bit then finishing the game... But, of course this game has their unique One-Shotters. And yes a few retries have racked up due to their... persistence. But that's alright. That's what the side-kick is supposed to be there for, I guess. No big deal... Stupid invis!

Raid Mode taking what it was in RERev and building upon it in good ways. Seeing all of those numbers: EXP, Gold, LV, HP, ATK. Seeing them increase is what really gives that mode its power and popularity. At least with me. I enjoyed the Mercenaries mode all the way back in RE3. I had bought the Mercenaries stand-alone game and Revelationsfor the 3ds and liked them. With their post-game stuff they want you to play more. Yeah they have little microtransactions in Raid Mode, but for what they get you, I'm positive I don't need them. Lives and extra guns and some parts aren't really worth it to me so I won't partake.

All in all, in my opinion, its a very decent game. I played through the main 4 episodes and plan on playing through the extras. I'd reccommend it to any and all who enjoy Resident Evil games, like a bit of a challenge, and/or are not opposed to the episodic style of this game's initial release. Oh and listening with headphones to the the story mode is reccommended highly. It will save you plenty of times. I guarantee it.

reviewText:
Resident Evil Light (but still a good adventure game)

I really enjoyed this game. It's not as good as the first game and it's not as creepy as it should be but it's a great adventure game with a gloomy atmosphere at its best parts. Playing with 2 characters at once and switching between them added some depth (There are scouting and fighting characters and you need both). It was fun to fight and sneak and to explore the well crafted levels. The crafting aspect felt a bit dull though. The graphics were still good and fitting, the sound effects and music were great. The story was well told. the characters were very likeable.

The quality of the 1st addon suprised me. The Struggle" is a short story with Moira as main character and it features perma death. Especially on the harder difficulty level you`ll need a few tries to beat the game (Don't forget you can switch characters here too). The storytelling and gameplay are on the same level as the main game.

I'd rate this game  2+."

reviewText:
A return to form for the Resident Evil / Biohazard series. Everything I hated about RE6 is absent in Revelations 2. It gives me renewed hope for the future of Resident Evil.

Getting to play as Claire again in the main story was awesome, something I've looked forward to for a long time since Code Veronica. Moira, Claire's partner throughout the story, was a great new character that spiced things up and helped with some occasional comic relief. You learn to enjoy her banter after a while. It's hilarious, honestly.

The partner system in Revelations 2 was really well-utilized and fun. It reminded me of Zero's a bit, but this one is much faster. The partner characters also are more unique, in that they can't use guns and instead contribute to the team in other ways. You would think it would be boring to play as a character that can't use guns, but I found it refreshing.

The game has a nice variety of settings. The marketing for this game focused almost entirely on the prison, but that's actually just the first of many locales you explore in the game. There is even a mansion segment of the game that serves as an awesome throwback to RE1, complete with claustrophobic hallways and creepy paintings.

One thing I have to note - this game is really obviously lower budget, and you will have to lower your expectations with regard to visuals if you want to have a good time. The texturework is nothing to scream about, and the high-quality texture work seen in RE6 is mostly absent here. And, oddly enough, when they are present they are used where they shouldn't have been. For example, tree bark isn't shiny and glossy in the real world, but in this game, it often is... It gives the impression that the spec, bump, maps etc were hastily auto-generated to save time/money, not baked manually and professionally. It's almost as if Revelations 2 began as a 3DS game and was ported over very late into its development, because that's what it often looks like - a low-res 3DS game. There is also a disparity in quality with regard to polygon counts and other things. Sometimes you'll be in an area with really gorgeous models and then suddenly you'll be in another area with models that look like something from the N64.

None of that detracts from the experience too much though! Overall this is a fantastic addition to Resident Evil, and I recommend it to any fan of the series. Despite being a lower budget entry, it's EASILY a much better game than RE6, and I dare say even RE5. To me, Revelations 2 is the game that RE5 should have been, as a true followup to RE4. It takes what RE4 did, and innovates on it by adding some new gameplay mechanics not seen before in the series. Just a shame Capcom couldn't justify giving it the same budget it gives to the main numbered titles, because this game definitely deserved it.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game quite a bit. Series veterans Claire Redfield and Barry Burton return to stop yet another bio-terrorism threat, along with new characters Moira and Natalia.

Gameplay wise, Revelations 2 delivers on the promise that the Revelations games would return to the series more survival horror roots. The relentless action of later main series entries takes a back seat in favor slowing things down and letting you explore each local for weapons, items, and resources, while still having some robust combat encounters. Exploring each area becomes necessary as enemies no longer drop ammo, all you get is from scavenging from the environment. There's also hidden items and shootable tokens scattered around, which further encourages exploration. Additionally, the game features a decent amount of puzzles that, while relatively easy, feel satisfying to complete. Inventory management is also a more prominent mechanic, as key items and pieces of combinable equipment are often encountered and fill up space quick. This direction in gameplay reminds me of the fine balance between action and survival mechanics in Resident Evil 4, which is part of what made that game great for me.

On the technical side of things, the game seems well optimized enough. I've read some negative things about it in that regard, I can't speak for when the game came out, as I waited quite awhile to play it, but it seems like most of the major issues have been resolved. I experienced some minor slowdowns when loading into a new area for the first time, but that's about it. The game has a decent amount of options in terms of graphics and controls, and while it's not as visually impressive as the newer main series entries, it still manages to look pretty good.

Overall, I had a pretty great time with this. You get an impressive amount of content for the price: 4 main episodes that average 2-3ish hours each plus bonus episodes, along with a more fleshed out Raid Mode brought over from the original Revelations. Unlockable weapons, modes, and costumes encourage replayability, so with everything you'll get a lot of play time out of it. Personally, I enjoy the direction the gameplay is taking in this series and I hope they continue to make more entries in it. Highly recommended.

reviewText: RE:R2 is a slightly better game than the first one and the pacing change of tension/action is much better executed than the prior title which felt like a huge clusterfock with its mess of a story and amount of weak characters. This games progression & atmosphere feel more in the vein of RE4/5 and not the horrible later outings like RE6/Racoon City. However it is obvious the production value & feeling of being part of something bigger isnt there like it is in RE4/5/6, the story is a much more down to earth version with really minimal twists.\n\nThe 4 episodic format feels sadly like a poor excuse from Capcom at gathering in money in a different way, its not well balanced at all in its length like the episodes from RE5 or 6 which felt just right for people to end their game session, this game really needed a extra episode or some message popup when arriving at a new long section of the game like for example The Sewers" or something. The episodes are way too long on episode 2
date: 3 & 4 especially the ones with Barry/Natalia.\n\nGameplay alternates between and stealth quite often and actually gives you the feling of conserving ammo unlike RE6 which messed that part up. However the stealth mechanics in this game are rather weak and only really adds to slowing the game down way too much too often along with the re-arrival of one of the worst implementations in the RE Revelations games which is the "Genesis Scanner" from RE:R1 which had your character scanning walls and floors of cleared areas for items. This time its there in a slighlty lighter form by switching your character but is still a weak and annoying gameplay element due to not only taking away from the pace of the game but also making you feel like you are hoarding because you will use it in a game where you might be afraid the game doesnt give you enough ammo and might have to restart a episode & need the BP points in the game from jewels you find this way to upgrade your character throughout the game. Theres also some lockpicking bits to open up chests for items with Natalie/Moira
recommended: this seems plastered on and makes absolutely no sense in its inclusion besides again artificially extend a short game. While kind of fun the first 1-2 time the harder ones later on makes it impossible not to fail as there is no time to change your mind.\n\nThe core gameplay revolves around the switching between your 2 characters in each episode. It really screams co-op if you want to go through the game by yourself sadly due to many annoyances. First of all getting caught by enemies usually locks you up often with their moves which really infuriates you towards your AI partner and secondly the controls are just not very intuitive at all
hoursPlayed: and with 2 characters to manage it really feels like a artificial way of Capcom to implement panic moments and tension by relying on slow & poorly implemented controls. You never really ever throughout the game feel in control of your actions due to this. Im all in for a 2nd partner in the newer RE games as the dialogue between them and their environments add to the atmosphere and story

reviewText:
I have just finished playing through the first episode. Honestly, it was incredible - much better than the first Revelations, packed in just a couple of hours gameplay.
I regret not pre-ordering this game, as the last few games in the series made me anxious about buying this one. After reading reviews saying that it brought back the classic, unique element of survival horror that the older games offered, I decided to give it a shot, and now I can say with a chill down my spine that this is the scariest game of the series, at least from what there's been in a while. Play with the lights out at your own risk, I started off on the Survival difficulty, which was a great experience.

I would strongly recommend to any fan of the Resident Evil franchise, and to anyone who enjoys the horror/survival horror genre in general.

+ The game controls pretty well and plays intuitively

- Tons of unlocks that cost points only gained from grinding the campaign
- No ammo/money drops from enemies
- Two linear

reviewText:
I was really excited to play this game when I started out, but as time goes on I feel torn.  I have beaten the game and here's my opinion/review:

Sure it def. brings back the creepy feeling of the first resident evil games and maybe even pushes past them almost more  towards silent hill in that regard, but b/c of people's griping about re6 I feel like this game has made steps backwards from re6 and suffers from that.

Did re6 have it's problems yes.  I felt like it could of done the boss battles a touch better, it did feel a touch not interacive enough for those.  Also some of the characters kinda felt like their side of the story could of been better, Helena's side of some of the boss fights for example, she felt just stuck up on a ledge while Leon got to fight.   But!  Re6 had GREAT controls, and the game looked good and played good.   This game looks about the same or not even as good as re6 and it plays like trash.  It stutters and the character movement feels more like movement from resident evil 1 vs resident evil 6 (clunky which was ok for resident evil 1 when it came out but re6 made vast improvements on this).

No online co op mode for the campaign was a crappy idea, but the secondary characters feel more like an extra tool than useful compainions so I guess it's understandable-  It's a pain have to recheck areas twice just b/c one character can't see or pick up an item just b/c they don't have a flashlight/sixth sense.

Don't get me wrong I loved some of the zombies in this game (even if they are too reused/as in the same exact models for alot of them) and it was def. nice not seeing a bunch of zombies toting guns, but movement of your characters?  Why?  Why back track on great controls?  I mean sure I get a little girl shouldn't be able to drop kick a zombie, but Barry and Claire?  They should be able to jump, slide, duck, roll, slide over a table just as good as Leon or Helena from re6.

It was neat using the little girl to see monsters, and their weaknesses to help Barry fight I will say that.  And the stealth kills are cool, even if they weren't implemented in the right ways (i.e. you need the little girl to see the orange globes in the creatures body parts to know the best place to take them out with the least amount of ammo, but all the sudden if you kill one from behind a knife hit to the back/stomach area always kills them? makes no sense.).

I also liked that certain objects in the stages could be used to help you fight, i.e. shooting a fire extinguisher to help you see the glasps.


So in closing I guess my 2 biggest gripes are that the controls just don't feel tight anymore like re6 and the game plays like crap for what it looks like in comparision to re6 in certain areas.  Also the no online co op for campaign.

Game does bring back the horror roots, some puzzles, but controls returned to clunkyness and the bosses felt lacking [not enough boss fights, some bosses felt uninspired and too reused (gray skined guy that has huge claw arm coming from his midsection/torso), never really felt like they had specific weaknesses, nothing cool required to beat them i.e. having to hold down jill in re5 and shoot the bug attachment on her chest and pull at it, no major death scenes i.e. snake eating you whole, chainsaw guy cutting your head off].

I'm torn on whether or not to recommend this game.  On it's own I think the game stands ok at it's price tag so I guess yes, but as the next installment of resident evil I can't stand that they back tracked on somethings, and as much as it sucks to think for me personally if the future re games continue on this path I think I might just be done with the resident evil series.

reviewText:
The game had a very bumpy start.  For the first month there were a lot of issues with performance and other bugs.  Since then the game was patched and works great now.  So that is why the game has low-ish recomendations.

It's a Resident Evil game, so the story is B-movie material but still enjoyable.  The campaign is fun once you get the hang of switching constantly between your characters, and picks up after the first episode which is really short compared to the others.  There are a lot of unlockables hidden behind high-rank playthroughs as always.

Raid mode does some things amazingly well, but in other areas is a step back from Revelations 1.  The parts and guns system is amazingly additctive and more deep than it was in Rev 1.  There are a ton of characters, and the skill system allows you to play whoever you want and still have the bonuses you want.  The bad news is it lacks much of the fun levels and character that Raid mode had in Rev 1.  Most of the time it is just a small arena.  Also most of the maps are from RE6.  There are no hidden enemies, no hidden BP medals, no voice clips.  But there are emotes, lots of emotes.  And if you really get into it, I suggest picking up the extra storage DLC for parts and weapons.  It's $2 for each so it isn't that bad.  It's still additctive, but it is different from Rev 1 Raid.  There are enough unique skills for the characters to keep things somewhat fresh.  Some get pretty silly.

I'd buy it if you like Resident Evil games for sure.  It plays more like RE4/5 and Revelations 1 than RE6.

reviewText: I had trouble figuring out rather to vote this game up or down, Now that I played all the main episodes I feel as if I can post my review, Well... Where do i start? first off they did a much better job with horror in my opinion than they did in RE5 and 6, but not as good of a job as Rev1, The ending left me kind of unsatisfied, and the story in my opinion has very little chance to be played more than once, they took a cheap way out for the end of the game thet made me upset just to leave room for another REV, The gameplay seemed unfinished, But even though the enemies get stale and the gameplay is not great the story is not awful, they also may have won me over with some quotes and who does not like barry and claire?  They could have added some more story for Barry and Claire, And I think the game lost A LOT of its fun due to the fact it was eposodic, The walking dead, Game of thrones, Life is Strange, ect can get away with being eposodic, but RE is not an eposodic series, even more so considering what they could have done with the story but did not do, And it is one of those games you may just want to come home one day and play and beat in 2 days, so the episodes leave you feeling restricted if you did not wait for the full game, I would give it a 6 or 7 out of 10, Oh I also can run far cry 4 on high and I have a gaming computer, but this lagged in some areas on some low settings in some parts of the game, Is it worth $25? yeah sure. Is it worth $40? maybe not. But for 25 if your a fan of the series go ahead and pick it up.

reviewText:
The game is pretty much what a good resident evil game should be. A nice story(not the best around but still good), good caracter and lot of different zombie to kill. Once you complete the campaign you can do it agait to try get S rank in each mission, find all the hidden item (Tower symbol, Kafka and bug), do countdown mode, invisible mode or complete raid mode.

The only down side for resident evil Revalation 2 are so far technical and faulty advertising. Many of the technical as been resolve with the release of episode 4 so that part is clear. As the false advertising, be careful The game advertise an offline co-op that was not suppose to be there and back pedal to add it in. But so far can only be play with 2 gamepad.  Online coop for raid mode that was supose to be here with episode 4 is still missing and lastly the over 200 raid mode map are in reallity 145 map (48 map with 3 different difficulty and 1 unique map) and 157 map if you own the dlc.

Bottom line a game that is for you if your a fan of resident evil

reviewText: I absolutely love the game. Been an RE fan since Zero, and Nemesis. Resident Evil: Revelations is by far, the best survival horror sub-franchise since RE: HD Remake - RE4.  Revelations 2 have got dynamic story, interesting LOCAL co-op splitscreen play, and no short of cheesy one liner dialogues from our favourite Barry. Set in the timeline between RE5 and RE6. There's even a raid mode for those of you who get thrilled with playing alongside another anonymous online, with hours of different maps from different RE games in the past. What's more to know is that capcom has been keeping the game constantly upto date EVEN AFTER the final release of Chapter 4 with FPS tweaks, co-op fixes and RE.Net, as another interesting concept for attaining special loot for your raid mode experience. If you love RE4 + Revelations, this is definitely the game for you! Support the devs! See you on Raid mode!

reviewText:
+If you set your brightness as the game tells you some places have a brilliant atmosphere. Trying to find my way out from a dark forest with a messy map while killing those nasty Revenants is just perfect for me.
+A real survival horror experience. You can run out of ammo if you don't search for them carefully or if you waste and you can do that pretty easly.
+Dialogues. Yes there are some cliché lines, but there are many I was quoting for weeks after I completed the game.
+The story is surprising and interesting that made me think about it for a long time.
+Gameplay has been refined with additions like sprint or dodge, and trust me you'll need them.
+I was happy that Uroboros is back with some tough monsters like Revenants, Slingers, Durgas and Splashers, and of course Uroboros bosses.
+2 endings based on who killed the boss in the end of The Judgement. This choice is genius in my opinion, but others don't really agree with me.
+A new virus, the T-Phobos, which brings some new enemies like the Afflicted which is a really fast zombie, the Glasp which is a big invisible fly-like monster which only move is an instant kill move (yes, you should be afraid of them), Orthus the annoying zombie dog with a pig head (don't ask me...Sushestovanie is a strange place) or the Vulcan Blobber who can shoot fire balls (yes he's a ton of fun).
+Raid Mode. It's a ton of fun with lots of unlockable original characters, costumes, weapons, gestures etc.
+/-Until the end of Contemplation it's like they were doing the grounding and the game only shows what it's really got from the end of Contemplation, but in The Judgment you get a lot of puzzles and most of them are deadly ones (like the Knight Room from RE1)
-Optimization. The game may run with huge FPS drops and stuttering on high end machines. The game itself will be completable, but as time goes on you'll become Moira in real life so you will learn to have Weaponized Swearing.
-Optimization 2.0. This game has the Capcom cliché named audio is out of sync during cutscenes" problem. Most of the time it doesn't have a fix
date: so you have to watch the cutscenes on YouTube.\n-The extra episodes suck. They are extremely hard
recommended: but not in the fun way
hoursPlayed: rather in the ♥♥♥♥ing annoying way.\n\nIn overall:I can say that Revelations 2 is worthy for the Resident Evil title. There are so much memorable moments and I can say that I love this game
voteText: but the optimization takes away from the good. My best advice is to buy only Penal Colony and if you feel like you could do it for three times more then buy either Complete Season or Box Set (if you really liked Raid Mode then buy the Box Set)\n\n"

reviewText: Resident Evil Revelations 2 offers an engaging story that doesn’t take itself too seriously, enjoyable co-op multiplayer, and a worthwhile reason to replay the game. It really isn't doing anything new, but that may be precisely why it's able to handle the core gameplay so well. If Capcom has decided that light-horror, high-tension action is the firm and final direction for Resident Evil moving forward, Revelations 2 at least embraces that and provides a road map for where to take it next.

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations 2 brings back some pretty big scares. It's like the classic Resident Evils combined with the newer third person shooter ones: Epic Action & Frightening Horror, as well as an awesome storyline. Shortly after the time I wrote this review (Please bear with me here), I had 3 hours sleep last night, and I was completely tired, with it also being 1 AM where I was. At around that time, my blood was pumping with adrenaline as I was going through a hard & epic part of the game, and after I made it through, I laughed gloriously.

I haven't known a game in years that has got me so hyped up at such early hours, with such little sleep. What a scary, intense and awesome game. Making a player scared but being awesome at the same time in an action survival horror is probably a very hard thing to do, and I give Capcom a round of applause.

In short: If you're into scary action survival games; Like you want to kick ♥♥♥ but have your ♥♥♥ kicked at the same time, this game is for you.

reviewText:
I only played this game to get it out of the way (you know, obligation to have a taste of every game in your library). Even so, Biohazard Revelations 2 failed to fulfil any of my expectations.

I thought it would be a long, jump scare filled horror with plenty of freedom to tackle horrifyingly difficult encounters in your own way.

As it turns out, BR2: Episode 1 is extremely short (see that play time? yeah, that short), only made me jump scare once (because I was about to sneeze), and is rather linear (though it was quite good at hiding the linearity), and the improvising was limited to -kill with bullets -kill with knife -kill with brick throw. Of course, the option to use bullets is there as long as you don't blanket fire, so the other options are pointless.

One thing that did surprise me, however, was the story. Much more interesting, character driven, creepy-thriller style story than I thought.

As a side note, I guess I am not in a position to complain about gore and language in a game like this.

In summary, extremely short, mediocre shooter, poor horror, good story. Perhaps worth the time for the trading cards.

reviewText: For a $25 game, Resident Evil: Revelations 2 is a pretty impressive game. The campaign lasted me a good 8+ hours and includes a lot of replay value in the form of different modes, difficulties and multiple endings. The gameplay is much tighter and focused than Resident Evil 6 and the game is paced better than the previous Revelations game. Even though the campaign is more than enough to warrant the $25 asking price, Capcom even threw in an extremely addictive and robust Raid mode that is jam packed full of missions, characters and RPG elements. Revelations 2 offers a ridiculous amount of gameplay for the budget price and feels more like a real Resident Evil title than RE6 does. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
After finishing Episode 1...
I'm already in love with this game!

(Updated after finishing Episode 2 and some Raid Mode maps)

I'm still in love with it.
I love the whole new sneaking/crouching idea, the crafting idea, switching characters gives the game a whole new feel.

Framedrops are kinda pain in the ♥♥♥, especially during the cutscenes.
Raid Mode is fun to play while waiting for the episodes to go live and it's fun to practise your shooting skills and it's quite fascinating to revisit the old maps from other Resident Evil games.

(Updated after finishing Episode 3 - May contain spoilers)

First things first, I love the whole puzzle collecting thingy again and to be honest, only now I've noticed that they brought the old thing from Resident Evil 4 where you have to shoot down a gem to pick it up, I know this thing was earlier in the episodes, but probably I was blind AF.

The boss battle... Oh man, the boss battle was the best one I ever had in years! This fight, oh I loved this fight. Hoping the last boss will be epic as this was.

Oh and never trust mining places. If you encounter one, you should know that you'll be stuck there for a while... flippin' hate mining places/quarries.

reviewText:
Just finished it and I had a great time. Tried one mission of the Raid mode too and really liked it. If you liked the first Revelation game you'll like this one.

Good points:
- Great characters from the Resident Evil franchise with some interesting new ones
- Fun gameplay similar to the first Revelation game with added partner switching which works.
- Nice environments (Screw the critics, I like them)
- Mysterious story that seems to be the norm for this franchise.
- Excellent controller support (I played with the windows controller which is like a 360 gamepad)

Bad points:
- Framerate hiccups and game slowdown
- No local coop (not a problem for me but...)
- No online coop FOR NOW (read below)

The online coop will be added after all episodes are out meaning around March 17th or later. It's been mentionned on a lot of gaming websites and on Capcom's site too so I don't get the complaints I read here. Didn't encounter any other problem or gamebreaking bugs during my time with the game but what's there can be fixed by a patch anyday so I wouldn't really worry about that. If you're not sure you can wait until everything has come out so the problems will surely be fixed then. Overall it's an 8 out of 10 for me and I know I'll play this for a while.

reviewText:
When the game first came out it had a few problems. Bugs and the whole co-op offline thing. Now after patching and all the episodes are out, the game is really one of the best in the Resident Evil Series. The controls are more like Resident Evil 6, but without the melee meter. The inventory system is MUCH better than RE6, and it's more like the earlier Resident Evil with limited bag space you can upgrade over time. The story while somewhat short (around 8 hours casual) has multiple ways to replay it in different modes and difficulties. The story itself is pretty good! Lots of twists and while it feels weird at first to have to switch between the two characters, you begin to realize their strengths and see the advantages of team work.

Raid mode is where this game really shines though. The Raid mode is a ramped up version of Mercenaries from the earlier games. There are a large variety of enemies, including some enemies from previous titles. (Excutioner, i'm looking at you.) If you thought these enemies were bad before, now they get buffs, everything from invisibility, on fire, super speed, toxic gas to one that makes you die if you get too close and don't kill it within 30 seconds. Oh, and the buffs stack on the enemies when you get higher level. When you are fighting a Scagdead that can kill you in one hit that is invisible, on fire, and has super speed suddenly things get very tense. It's definitely challenging. A great thing about Raid mode is every character possesses certain skills that the other don't, for example, Cipher gets a katana to replace the knife. If you level up the Sword skill to max, you can pay again to unlock it for all other raid character to buy. Then that character can buy and use that skill. This is great because if you have a favorite character but they don't have the skills you want them to, now you can give them those skills. With the Dailies it's fairly easy to level up the characters to max out the skills you want.

The only negatives about this game really are the in game purchases for hearts and toolbox space. Hearts you earn by doing the daily missions which are easy enough if you are accustomed to raid mode. The Hearts are what you use to revive during Raid mode matches. Your partner cannot get you back up in Co-op. You won't really use them until you get to around level 100, that's when they game gets really crazy and very hard. It might take you a while to build back up your hearts so you can do more high level stuff unless you want to pay for them. Toolbox space you don't really need unless you are a pack rat because you can combine the parts.

All in all, this story reminds me more of Resident Evil 2, with the parallel storylines in the same areas but offset by time, with all the options and gameplay of the newer Resident Evil titles. That's a combo I like very much.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Casually playing through first episode took right under 2 hours. Possibly means this game will have almost 8 hours of Campaign gameplay.
-Very extensive and enjoyable Raid Mode. Tons of levels and 3 difficulties for each level.
-Raid mode is not grind focused, so far, as of getting my first character to level 20. As you play through each stage at each difficulty, you should get enough XP to level up and keep going without replaying levels over and over.
-Improved dodge system.
-Improved skills system (and there are some really sweet skills. HUNK gets active camo).
-Great music in Raid Mode, really sets the mood well.
-Less frustrating Raid Mode overall. Completion Medal (Trinity Bonus in Rev 1) is much easier to get.
-Split screen coop has been fully integrated into the pc version!

Cons:
-Campaign AI partner is sadly stupid sometimes. I've watched Moira walk up to an enemy, take a hammer to the face, and walk right back to the same spot once she got up.
-Many players are experiencing a horrific frame stutter. This happens mostly at random, and can mess up your dodging, shooting, or just doing anything in general.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I've been playing this game for 82 hours as of this edit, and I do still recommend this game. Previously I recommended getting it on the console if possible (to avoid framerate issue and for the lack of split-screen coop before) but now I'd definitely recommend this on PC. The framrate issue has been improved, yet it's still a problem. Split-screen coop is now a full feature in the game. The MAIN reason I recommend this game on PC is that there are numerous characters in raid mode, but some of their character models use the latest versions that I don't care for (I won't name them to avoid spoilers). With mods I'm able to enjoy these characters in their best forms, as well as remove that awful film grain from the screen. So if you want a good Resident Evil experience at a reasonable cost, I really recommend this game. Enjoy!

reviewText:
OverviewWhatever your opinion of this whole PC same-screen co-op “scandal”, as some people say, the game itself is still fun to play. It’s Resident Evil, and comes with all the quirks and issues that have plagued the other titles, but is still a fun game to play.

Story/AtmosphereAs only one episode has been released, the story is still somewhat unknown. The events of episode one take place many years after those of the original game. You begin as Claire, waking up in a prison cell, with no clue as to where you are or how you got there. You soon meet up with Moira, Barry’s daughter, and adventure together. You do eventually leave the prison itself, only to discover where you are.

The second part of episode one has you playing as Barry, who received a distress call from Moira, and has come to the prison to investigate (how he tracked the location down we’ll either find out later, or may never know). He meets a young girl named Natalie, who winds up accompanying him in his search, because why not take a little girl into a monster infested location while you search for your daughter who sent out a distress call from a monster infested location.

The story isn’t too convoluted, yet, but that will surely change. Capcom is known for throwing twists and turns at every corner.
Once you find out where you are, you’ll come to appreciate the location. Capcom has done a great job rendering the prison and its surroundings, and you’ll get to see many parts of it, from both Claire and Barry’s perspective.

GameplayGameplay is almost similar to the Outbreak games, where you control multiple people. As Claire, you’ll be accompanied by Moria, who holds a flashlight while you hold the gun. Why Claire is incapable of holding both a gun and a flashlight I don’t know, but that would throw off the whole mechanics of the game, I guess. After a certain point, you can freely switch between both characters, and you will need to do that for certain parts of the story. Moira can also find collectibles, or ammo, or other items by seeing a glint, then shining the light at the glint to make it interactive, allowing her (or Claire) to pick it up. If the AI is controlling Moira, you can’t do this.

The same goes for Barry and Natalie. Natalie can crawl through small spaces to open the way for Barry, while also being able to point at glinting objects (literally, you point), which allows her or Barry to then pick up that object.

Like the first Revelations, you can dodge enemy attacks, but the dodge seems far superior and actually works, compared to the first game. You have the quick turn (180), and can walk while firing.

GraphicsThe game looks good. Characters are well detailed, except for their faces. Claire quite often looks like she’s constipated. Environments are dark, disturbing, moody, dank, etc. I find the enemy models to be terrific.

The environment is done well, too. Trees cast an eerie glow from the sky, bushes and leaves rustle. Is it your AI partner running through that bush, or something else?

There isn’t a lot of graphical options to set in-game, and are pretty much standard fare.

And while the game does look good, it doesn’t look fantastic. But, such is life when it comes to what is essentially a straight port. Resident Evil games have always been developed with a console first attitude, and that’s fine. But Capcom is especially lazy and/or incompetent when it comes to porting games. Resident Evil HD Remaster is the exception to this rule, and is actually a very well done port.

Sound/MusicThe music, as usual for Resident Evil games, is great. If you pre-ordered it, you get some soundtrack selections. My game only has four music files, but I don’t know if more will be released with each episode, or if that is the extent of it.

Sound effects are great, and really lead to some tense moments. The acting, while passable, is like all Resident Evil games, and occasionally sounds forced while always sounding cheesy. The characters even poke fun at certain things, such as Claire exclaiming how she didn’t become a Claire sandwich, and Barry making fun of his master of unlocking comment from 1996.

PerformanceAnd this is where Resident Evil Revelations 2 falters. The performance is spotty. Often times, when readying your gun to aim, there’s some slight lag as the game zooms in to your character’s head. There are lots of moments where the framerate stutters for no apparent reason. It’s a completely unoptimized product. Which is also evident when the game tells you not to turn off your console while its saving. Yes, the PC version tells you not to shut off your CONSOLE. If that isn’t incompetent “optimizing”, I don’t know what is.

I didn’t experience any crashes or startup issues.

Multiplayer InfoSo this is what’s causing an uproar by a lot of fans. The PC version of Revelations 2 is the only version not to have local, offline co-op. Not that it’ll be patched in later, but it just doesn’t have it to begin with. I don’t get the big deal myself, but I can understand how people feel deceived by Capcom, as this information was not originally in the game description, so people who pre-ordered or bought it thinking they’d be able to play locally with a friend are annoyed, and for good reason.

Online co-op for Raid mode (not the campaign) is to come in a later patch. If I remember, I’ll update my review accordingly whenever that happens.

Everything ElseThe game is short. I completed both acts of the first episode in about three hours. Let’s assume each episode is about that time, you’re looking at twelve hours of a story once all episodes are out (four episodes at three hours each). It’s not horrible that it’s short, and it’s not a full priced game either, so value for money is pretty on par.

Raid mode, while fun, is somewhat boring at the moment, as you’re limited to playing yourself. Once co-op is patched in, I’m sure it’ll get better.

SummaryDon't judge the game based on Capcom's multiplayer issue. Judge the game on what it is; a game. Don't give it a bad review because you're ticked off with them, give it a bad review if it's actually a bad game.

It’s Resident Evil, and you either love or hate them. I, personally, have hated the fact that the games have taken an action-heavy stance, and I loved the slow and methodical pace of the first three games. However, it’s still a fun title, with what little time you’ll need to invest into it. And the story is always worth seeing.

Also, Barry. Barry is back.
