reviewText:
FIrst - the misleading bit about local coop is unfortunate and is certainly a strike against Capcom.  I'm hoping they rectify this issue for those who bought the game solely for this. But....

I wasn't planning on trying any sort of coop with this game so luckily I wasn't affected.  Res Evil has always been a single player experience for me, and to that end I found the first chapter of this iteration to be a lot of fun.  It keeps the structure of the first Revelations intact, but adds something new into the mix with a light crafting feature and an AI partner that is actually somewhat helpful.  If you've played any RE since the fourth one, you're fairly familiar with the gameplay from the start; and I'm glad to say it's just as tight a third person shooter you could ask for.  There are bits of exploration and action which are fed to the player at a good pace.  It's not quite the backtrack-fest of the earlier RE's, but it's also not the Michael Bay-fest of the 6th game.  It's a good balance and I appreciate the thought put into both the creepy atmosphere and the enemy encounters.  That said, the setting is a little ho hum so far (act 1), and I'm hoping to see some diverse environments as it continues.  Also of note is the performance - I had some stuttering issues, but when setting the framerate limit to 60fps this dropped dramatically, though not completely.  So I am hoping for a patch to address this.  Lastly I'd like to bring up Barry's daughter.  We're supposed to like her, and hope for her well being through Barry's sections; but she's far from agreeable.  With all her f-bombs and angsty complaining, I kind of wish Claire would accidentally shoot her - I've tried believe me!

All in all, a good start to what I'm hoping is a great game.  I give it a hesitant recommendation only because of it's performance issues.

reviewText: Personally, with technical issues aside (some low framerates and shaking model in some occasions, that will be patched), this is the best Resident Evil campaign since a decade. Very immersive (use quality headphones !) and good story. The Raid mode is a really nice addition to the game, where you grind XP for levels, guns, abilities, etc it was pretty cool in Revelations 1 but I think it's 10 times better in Revelations 2, really well done.
voteText: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
The gameplay and UI are way better than RE6, however, developers need to fix frame stutterings issues for PC that occurs regardless of settings. Puzzle wise, RE relevations 2 is alot more simple than previous installations, more puzzle solving and claustrophobic enviroment is the way to go . There is a good mix of action and horror segements, not overwhelming like RE6. Swtiching between characters in game is pretty smooth. Good job on the music. As this the initial release, bugs are expected, I'll forgive you. Lastly, maybe the episodic release is too harsh ....... or the wait for 1 week per episode is too long.

Episode 1, What I liked:

1) Enviroment
2) Neat UI
3) Smooth character switch
4) RAID mode
5) Good mix of action and horror

What's bad:

1) Frame issues
2) Episode ........
3) Insufficient puzzle solving
4) No local Co-op

Score 7.5/10


Edit

Episode 2

Fixed frame issues !! yeah~  The environment/atmosphere is creepy as ever, game play is intensive. I got freaked out once while sneaking around a low wall and a Revenant just suddenly stick its head in your face and growl.... The story narration through Barry's and Clarie's campaign is nice and well paced. We finally got to meet the story's main antagonist (maybe) and of course, the encounter ended with another cliffhanger for Episode 3.  Episode 2 contains some nice intense boss fights that are not draggy like RE6. Really nice and I am looking forward to episode 3.

Some bugs though (Contains spoliers)

1) Natalia sometimes would not warn or point at the invisible fly
2) Zombies sometimes will stuck around corners

reviewText:
You see all these people complaining about choppy FPS and freezing, I've played the first episode for about 2 - 3 hours and messed around on top of that, I got ZERO lag. ZERO FPS drops. ZERO freezing. People complaining about it either; a) have an old PC. b) have a good PC but a lot of ♥♥♥♥ on it that makes it slower i.e programs open/processes. or c) just complain because they can. Either way I had a very enjoyable time with it.

- I had just tried it on my Laptop today which has a gtx 780m, 8gb of corsair ram and an i7 4790Q, worked great and locked at 70fps sometimes dipped to 60 - 65 but literally no freezing or lock ups what so ever.

Anyways, do I recommend it? Yes, but only for people who like/love Resident Evil. I've been playing the series and loving it since number 4, went back and finished all the other ones and loved those and even went on to 5 and 6 which weren't THAT bad (although Chris punching a boulder is a bit over the top), however the fact that this is an Episodic Series" is a poor choice for Capcom. I have no idea why they decided to do this

reviewText: When the game first came out many of us who grew up with the early RE games thought this was not worthy of the tittle Resident Evil, however i have come to appreciate and respect the work and time spent making this game. That does not mean that my initial evaluation has changed, it simply means the game has earned it's place in my RE games collection. And also means that this game was for me personally the best 40$ spent in a long time, simply because it offers a lot of replay value per $.\n\nI have spent countless hours playing the game, and raid mode, also having completed the game itself added another layer of replayability, with the addition of weapon/and costumes unlocks. Both of which make you want to replay the game gather more BP= unlock said weapon and costume.  And yes i am fully aware of the fact that replayability is not a word in the dictionary, but that does not mean we will stop using lol and rofl, or trololol anytime soon does it?

reviewText:
I've barely started playing this game yet (at time of review only a bit over 1 hour in) and already I think this is shaping up to be the BEST Resident Evil game yet (more than even original RE1 [my previous fav).

-Pros
--------
The game is atmospheric as f-uck.
Cool enemies.
Very cool location setting (Prison setting).
Claire is nice.
Moira is hot.
Music is very well done, moody, atmospheric, just plain good.
Neat mini-game mechanics such as Moira's flashlight searching and Moira's lockbox.
Controls seems pretty good and fluid for the most part.

-Cons
--------
The loading screen (opening some doors) is pretty immersive breaking with a flashing of black for a half second.
No Jill.
There is some frame stuttering / optimization issues.

So in short, if you are a fan of the Resident Evil series, you should definitely get and love this game!

reviewText:
This game is great.

To all people who experience lags and stuttering" ---> get a better machine or turn down some effects. Up until now i`ve only exerienced them on Raid mode and only for 10 or so seconds on the start. Or in really effect loaded stages like with snowstorm effects and co.
Just pause the game at level start and wait some seconds( 10 sec. should do ). Then continue playing. This should solve the lagging ( it works for me). I am sure CAPCOM will solve this soon enough
date:
be patient.

!!And hell yes this IS a great game!!

For me as an old RE fan with playing every part avaliable i would say this can turn out to be one of the best RE stories we have had so far. Very tense moments at some points.

The game itself presents again as more of a shooter then the old scool survival we know and love.
Not much of puzzles or Item searching. You progress most of the game straightly linear. Engage in fights and action like the known RE4-6 parts.
New is that you always have to keep an eye on your AI controlled partner and sometimes you even need him for some of the puzzles. (Reminds me of RE Zero)

Item and resource management is vital so far
recommended:
even more on the harder dificulties.

Alot of Content has been added. Lots of Weapons and Skills for Raid Mode ( Plays like a shooter with RPG elements)

Ingame there is even more challenges and achievements and this contet is getting bigger with every episode.

So if you can overlook tis "buh bad" lagging problem that some people experience and makes them stop playing because the game is not perfect from the start... ((( what a shame - seriously people. The game was just launched and you expected no bugs???))) ...i am sure you can enjoy a very good game that will get even better from episode to episode.

reviewText:
It's alright, it's a budget Resident Evil that is more enjoyable than it's big budget brothers and priced like a budget game.

You will see people complaining about 40 pounds worth of DLC when the full game isn't even out yet, there's a very good solution to this problem, that is don't buy the DLC as it's mostly fluff and content for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ raid mode.

You can buy the full game now for 20 pounds and get each episode as it comes out, or buy the first episode that is out now and play that for a mere 5 pounds. If you want to know whether the game is worth it, the entry price to find out is miniscule. I'd recommend doing that if you are on the fence and decide for yourself rather than take the word of me or other people.

One thing of note is that I have heard people with mid-decent spec computers have had some performance issues, I'm running a 970 and mostly stay at 120 frames per second, there are about three bits in the game though where it appears like performance tanks, but the framerate still is reported at about 60, I think it's a bug more than it is poor optimisation, but if this bothers you I would wait for it to be fixed.

And for those wondering, I was worried that the mouse controls would be bad, that there would be mouse acceleration or negative mouse acceleration, but if there was I didn't really notice it, and I'm pretty autistic about stuff like that, so if that was a worry for you then you shouldn't be worried.

reviewText: Resident Evil Revelations 2's first episode is almost what Resident Evil used to be. Survival Horror (of course). Bringing back 2 characters from the dusty closet was a great idea.  The gameplay is solid, it also gives off a Last Of Us vibe as you have to craft torniquets, use bricks, bottles, and alchohol. Otherwise, the game is great so far and the Raid mode is keeping me waiting for the next episodes. Praiseworthy.""

reviewText:
If you were a Resident Evil/Biohazard fan, I highly recommend this game. Gone is the oversaturation of QuickTimeEvents from RE6. This game brings back the spooky and horror atmosphere of the previous games  (RE 1- 4), and mixes the control system from RE Revelations 1 to great effect.

During the campaign mode, you have 2 characters to control but at the same time, it provides a completely different gameplay perspective from the Co-op/partner system in RE5 (which kind of removed the sense of the danger from the game). In RE Rev 2, the partner system actually adds a sense of tension and stress to the game.The game cleverly (sometimes not) builds its puzzles around the duo system (think of Sherry and Claire from RE2). Some of the puzzles actually bring back memories of the puzzles from the classic RE (especially RE1).

Moreover, if you like shooting zombies and like grinding for gears, there is Raid Mode. It is like a mini-RPG Shoot-Em-Up game. If you played RE-Revelations 1, you know what to expect here.

My only complaint, if there were any, would be a very minor one. I, at first, kind of did not like what they did with the character 3d faces, but then, you do get used to it after a while.

In conclusion, this game is highly recommeded for any Resident Evil fans.

reviewText:
To be honest I didn't expect much from this title. I thought it will be like 5 or 6, but for my surprise it is very good. So you might give it a chance.

PROS:
+ Great atmosphere.
+ Good Story so far.
+ Episodic realase*.
+ It's actually an horror game no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t action like past games.
+ Japanese voiceovers
+ Raid mode it's great, long and complex.

CONS:

- Frame drops in RAID mode. Just once in one mission not a big deal though.
- IA is kinda dumb. The AI-controlled character will frequently stand there and do nothing.
- No online coop.
- Framerate stutter at the beginning of episode one for like 5 minutes no more.

* I thought that episodic release will be tedious and annoying. But I find myself enjoying this experience so far.

Buy this game if you have a decent rig to play it. For me it's a 9/10.

reviewText:
I have rarely written a review for a game on steam, but having read what people are writing about this game i feel i need to. If you listen to the excrement that the negs are spouting you will miss out on a gem of a gamne.

Please ignore any of the reviews you read where the main subject matter is the lack of Co-Op. This alone does not warrant a negative review.

This game is brilliant fun. It has the right mix of survival horror and action. The episodes so far (just finished episode 2) are really well structured and have me excited for the next instalment.

Raid mode is good fun with plenty to unlock and enough to keep you interested for a fair few hours.

Every so often I encounter a drop in frame rate but nothing game breaking.

Reading the majority of the negative reviews on here leaves a sour taste from over entitled spoilt brats. Give the game a go and you will not be dissapointed.

reviewText:
This is an updated review as of the time of Episode 3. This review primarily focuses on comparing RER1 and RER2.

RER2 got off to a somewhat rocky and meh" start with the first episode but EP2 and EP3 are significantly better.

Pros:
+The game mechanics are improved from RER1 and they've maintained the fun stuff from RER1 while adding cool and interesting new stuff like the skill trees. The partner mechanics are fun and allow for plenty of on-the-fly switching during combat for strategy.

+Claire and Barry are back! This might seem like not a big deal but if you are a longtime RE fan it's nice to see them back
date:
and they are handled perfectly.

+Good soundtrack. Not amazing but it is atmospheric and gets the job done.

+Good replay value for collectibles and medals-- chapters are short
recommended: and they're easy to quickly replay to go back and get extras.\n\n+Raid Mode is more fleshed out and is a full-fledged gameplay mode this time
hoursPlayed:
as opposed to it being an afterthought in RER1.


Cons:
-The story has gotten better with EP2-3 but it's really hard to believe they're going to tie all of this up nicely in EP4.

-Difficulty is a bit average. Especially if you run chapters again to get extras
voteText: you will end up with massive stocks of ammo and tons of BP to spend on skill trees
helpfulPercent: which kind of trivializes the need to bother managing ammo. If you're looking for a challenge
votesHelpful: I recommend you play the game straight through once
votesTotal:
and don't replay episodes until you've finished the game.

-No online campaign co-op. This was "acceptable" in RER1 since it was a port of a 3DS game but it just feels like a silly omission here.

-As of this writing there are still some stuttering/freezing issues. I've only ever had the game totally freeze on me once
votesFunny: but the stuttering issues are frequent and irritating. They seem to be working on this so hopefully it will be fully fixed."

reviewText:
As per usual, Capcom have completely disappointed their fanbase. What kind of company sells a game based on its co-op features, promises offline co-op in the store description, and then doesn't deliver ANY kind of co-op on launch?

This is a complete waste of money. Feature-wise, the game seems like it might be good in co-op. There are a few nice little touches that encourage co-operative play. Moira doesn't use guns, but can aim the flashlight and finish off enemies for Claire, effectively turning the RE4 staple of the good old 1-2 Shoot'n'melee combo into a co-op action, which is a great idea. The sound design and atmosphere are top-notch, and the enemies genuinely feel slightly threatening. In co-op, this game might be quite a lot of fun, what completely kill it is the partner AI.

The AI is a complete handicap; moira would frequently be unable to follow me, she would fail to finish off enemies I had shot, she refused to use her crowbar at all even when I was on the brink of death, and she would only occasionally use the flashlight, usually in well-lit areas, the dark areas being left unlit by her shy torch.

In its current state, the game feels like playing a splitscreen game in co-op by yourself and occasionally dropping one controller to play with the other. It's a shame because the dialogue is a decent peg above standard Resident Evil fare, and the plot is genuinely interesting for once with a wonderfully fresh SAW-esque vibe to it. You know a series is stagnating when borrowing from SAW makes it feel fresh.

Do NOT waste your money in this game until co-op is patched in. Although knowing Capcom, they're probably lying about that too.

reviewText:
I was skeptical about this game until I read about the raid mode. Story is typical Resident Evil fare, but the gameplay is solid. They rolled back some of the movement features from RE 6 thankfully (like the roll dodging and accessing your inventory via a clumsy interface through a phone or something) and have kept the meat of the 3rd person shooter mechanics. This with the RPG elements similar to Mass Effect 3 or other short wave based rounds with leveling up equate to solid and quick fun of gunning zombies down with either defense mode or point A to B (sometimes with and without a timer). Still waiting on that online co-op, but it'll be released when all four episodes are out.

Graphics are good overall, but the pre-rendered cutscenes are cringeworthy with how the faces look.

reviewText:
This game has so much potential, it’s a shame to see that Capcom has ruined the PC port.  First the objective stuff, then the personal complains:

[OBJECTIVE] = First off, the main story mode is basically unplayable.  The game lags constantly, often just straight-up freezing when there are more than two people on screen (which, since you are always with an AI companion, is anytime there is a single enemy on screen).  I have fiddled with the settings more than I care to discuss, and nothing works.  Looking online, some people suggest locking the fps, others suggest unlocking it, some suggest turning v-sync off, some suggest turning it on; basically, no one has any idea how to fix this mess.  I’m not going to go into a long, detailed description of my specs, but suffice it to say that I can run games with much larger environments, more effects, better graphics, and better, well, EVERYTHING without any issues.  I was able to get raid mode to work, but even then it jittered here and there.

Also, the camera is “sticky”; when you move the camera while aiming it lags for a second (just the reticule, not the whole game) and then zips up to its proper speed.  As I’m sure you can imagine, this makes getting head shots, or, rather, ANY type of shot very difficult and frustrating.

Based on all the other reviews, I know I am not the only one having these issues.  I would not recommend getting this game until people start to say that they are fixed.

[PERSONAL] = There are just so many design choices that make no sense.  First of all, why are custom parts locked to guns in raid mode?  Half the fun in RE Revelations was experimenting to see what was optimal.  Who cares if there are tons more custom parts now; no one is going to risk wasting time and money on a new, totally-strange gun load out if you have to destroy the gun to get the parts back or destroy the parts to get the gun back.  It’s supposed to make you really consider whether you want to put parts onto a gun, but everyone is just going to go with the tried-and-true parts like increased damage or increased magazine size and then destroy the gun to roll those parts over to a new gun of the same type when they get one.

And then there is Moira Burton, the workshopped-to-death punk girl wannabe who is constantly freaking out about all the blood and gore and violence around her.  Now, yes, it is reasonable that a girl of her age and background would act this way but that does not make it any less annoying.  This is RESIDENT EVIL; blood and gore are as common as bad dialog here.

She also has this weird thing with guns in that she won’t use them or even acknowledge them, really.  When you get your first gun, right after the two of you were nearly killed by an enemy (who then went on to brutally murder another girl in front of you two, more on her in a second) she asks, “are you going to use that?”  No, Moira, I’m going to stick it in my butt so I can play Russian roulette every time I sit down.

Yes, yes, her aversion to guns is supposed to allude to some tragic event in her past but WE ARE IN A SURVIVAL SITUATION, MOIRA.  It's bad enough that I have to switch to you to find hidden items and kill stunned enemies, but can you at least harden up and stop talking to me?

Last, and certainly not least in my list of petty complaints: do you remembers Rachel Foley, the super-hot blonde combat specialist from RE Revelations?  Did you like having her in raid mode?  You did?  Well, good news!  RE Revelations 2 has her ugly, brown-haired, glasses-wearing, office-nerd sister!  Isn’t that just GREAT?!

Now, I would like to note that I am posting this on Feb. 25th, the day of release of the first episode on steam.  Once all of the episodic content is out the lag issues, stickiness issues, and the lack of Rachel Foley might be fixed (since they are releasing more raid mode characters with each episode); if they are then please disregard those complaints.

That being said, Capcom still chose to release this game with all of the lag and stickiness.  It just goes to show why you should never, ever pre-order a game even if it is from a company you respect and trust.  I don’t think this will be my last Capcom game, but it will certainly be the last game that I ever pre-order.

TL;DR = Lots of potential, but bogged down by horrible lag.  Wait until all of the episodes are out and then see what people are saying about how it runs.

reviewText: I got episode 1 in a bundle for pennies. I'm not sure I'd suggest buying the whole package. You can just buy an episode and play raid mode. reviewText:
Is better than I expected! :)

Pros:- The gameplay feels smooth
- Another step forward to the campaign co-op. It's fun to play.
- There are not many types of enemies but they're OK.
- Even tho the environments are kind of linear or predictable, the level design is fun.
- The story is well presented + The different endings ;)
- Nice length and difficulty.
- Claire Redfield <3 (Yes, I'm a fan since RE 2 and RE CV)...and Barry F*cking Burton's come back! ;)

Cons:- Lack of online co-op
- The lack of backtracking until the last chapters (and it's minimal).
- The craft system (stoled from The Last of Us) is not bad. But is not that interesting to use.
- Stealth is very clunky / simple. The comparison with TLOU is unavoidable.
- MT Framework Engine...The assets looks like cardboard since RE5. But I think the art and execution of RE Rev 2 and RE 6 are the best of this games. I

Note:
Performance issues are solved with the lastest updates.

I think it is a good game for its price. I liked the endings as I said. I recommend this one over the first Revelations (Or Revelaitions" haha if you know what I mean!)."

reviewText:
This game is a step in the right direction for the Resident Evil Series just as its predecessor Resident Evil Revelations was.

Pros:

-Better atmosphere and pacing: Atmosphere is back and done more subtly with more depth and horror.  It won't match other horror games today, however it takes good ideas from other places.  Much better than Revelations 1 and that was already an improvement for pacing.
-Better FOV than Resident Evil 6: The last triple A title was chock full of ways to try to get us to feel claustrophobic and even had an option to change which shoulder the player was looking at.  With a much more comfortable FOV in this game, you're stuck with 'over the right should' view and that's not only classic RE 4, but also good enough when paired with proper FOV.
-Good length: about 10 hours taking my time.  None of this 4 different campaigns with a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t in between.
-Laser pointer vs. crosshairs: the option exists!  However it is located in a bad spot on the menu (more on that later.)
-Good forced single-player co-op: For once the series has struck a good balance between the constant escort mission and co-op AI.  With the ability to switch between the two pairs of characters (Claire and Moira—Barry and Natalia) the switch is not only available, but necessary.  One player is always the power character that can get the damage dealt and the other forms the new role of pointman/strategic distraction.  The secondary characters actually have important roles to the story and gameplay and are actually fun to use if used correctly.  They have to be used to get all the items in the game.
-Great child character that doesn't need you to hold her hand on everything, gun use excluded: Natalia is a fearless little girl that manages to not be whiny, annoying, or hopelessly mired in little girl inane chatter.  She is dead useful in gameplay, and when used right will be your designated pointman instead of the power character Barry.   A character that straddles the line between escort mission/and useful skills.
-Story: The story was a good one and very Resident Evil with viruses, villains, and even some zombies! All I cared was that it wasn't Chris and Piers storyline from Resident Evil 6.  I could care less for an action love fest, the WHOLE campaign.
-Good variety of enemy types: This iteration of the Revelations series has a lot more different versions of enemies and even some old favorites in RAID MODE.  Lots of good character designs and types that let the gameplay feel how it should feel on a per-chapter basis.  A nice take on a regenerating enemies.
-RAID MODE: A fine addition for anyone that just wants a slight challenge and lots of combat.  Unlocking old costumes for Barry and Claire was fun to play for.
-Weapon Mods:  Weapon modifications are done easily enough in the campaign and balanced enough in RAID MODE.  Figuring out the best combinations on different weapons can really make all the difference during a boss fight.  RAID MODE does not allow you to take off mods like in campaign mode.  Either you have to destroy the weapon to get the mods back or you have to destroy all equipped mods on the weapon to get the weapon back.

Cons:
-Laser aiming buried in menu: You have to go to settings, then 'Display', then 'Details'.  Instead of something expected like under 'Gameplay'.  STUPID.
-Graphics and animations: Graphics are not going to match RE 6 levels and should not be expected to be.  This game does well in its art and atmosphere, but will not impress with sheer graphical fidelity.
-Moira's English Script: Whether she's making another pun of the moment or using curse words in odd ways, Moira is good at talking like a fantasy 10-year-old.  Whoever wrote her script thought that she had to play the typical teenager who seems to have no practice at cursing.  Sometimes the good ol' lines are best to stick with instead of coming up with new ways to make teens look like try-hards.
-The inclusion of a bad ending: Normally this would be good as it gives the player some leeway and includes more content.  However I looked up the triggers for the good/bad endings and found that one decision in the middle of the game is the deciding factor.   The trigger could be missed simply if one had been listening to Moira talk the whole time.  I won't spoil the game, but this seems like a dumb way to get a bad ending, as the decision made will get past the encounter either way without any sign that something wrong was done nor that it would affect another certain pair of survivors.

Final Thoughts: Overall I liked this version of the new Resident Evil gameplay systems the most and it shows the most polish in my opinion.  While it can't beat out the originals in my book as they would have to be classed within they're dated context, this was by far the best implementation of Over The Shoulder gameplay since RE 4.  I would highly recommend this game to anybody that had doubts as to the direction of Resident Evil going forward.  If Revelations 1 showed us the possibilities of Resident Evil, then Revelations 2 will further show that if Capcom treats her right, the series can live on.

reviewText: I got episode 1 in a bundle for pennies. I'm not sure I'd suggest buying the whole package. You can just buy an episode and play raid mode. The problem is I am struggling to find anyone in matchmaking except for the randomly generated mission search, but who wants to spend time in that? So I cant suggest anyone buy this now UNLESS you have friends to play with. In that case, I'd say at least buy episode 1. Be warned that this is a very grindy and repeatitive mode but if you like a little Borderlands mixed in with your Resident Evil, its quite nice.\n\nBut the campaign itself, while only 3 hours for one episode, was surprisingly good. I really like the control refinements here. Its taken some inspiration from Alan Wake, I would say. The gunplay is reliable and the partner system is pretty much hassle free and a nice addition. Good experience overall.

reviewText:
I have toyed with playing Resident Evil games on a number of occasions before but this is the first one I have bought. The first episode was on sale for 79p whilst all the other episodes were not discounted at all. The publisher must be extremely confident that you will get hooked after the first episode to do that. However this did not work on me, after the first episode I was left with the overwhelming impression that it was okay but had no desire to buy the rest of the game.

The campaign's plot so far is intriguing, the way the story is told by splitting it into two parts is excellent. The combat is mostly uninspiring shooting dribbly monsters in the face. The character switching felt a bit forced in the first half where one character had guns and the other had a torch with no good reason why they both couldn't have guns and a torch. However the switching worked much better in the second half where you had a tough guy with all the weapons and a creepy child who can see monsters through walls. So overall it is reasonably enjoyable.

There was also a boring raid mode where you need to just repeatedly kill a bunch of monsters to level up your character and unlock things to kill more monsters. This didn't hold my attention for long.

So overall I feel I got my 79 pence's worth out of this first episode but I am in no hurry to spend twenty odd quid to get the rest of the game.
voteText: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
REVIEW BASED ON THE FIRST EPISODE  since I am too poor to buy the other ones
Resident Evil Revelations 2 is an episodic survival horror game like Siren: Blood Curse and Telltale's The Walking Dead.

Pros
Balanced Gameplay, not so stiff as Revelations and RE5 though not so loose as RE6
Great story that may hook till the end
Scary/Terrifying/Dreadful atmosphere & soundtrack
Co-op single-player experience kind of similar to RE 0, partners are useful Moira can blind enemies and Natalia can point their weak spots, but it's still a bit forced
Improved Raid Mode which features scenarios from previous installments
OLD RESIDENT EVIL MEMES BROUGHT BACK TO LIFE Cons
Overused enemies
Players may experience stuttering despite their hardware
Moira's excessive swearing
Same old Jill memes >tfw no Jill   In summary , RE Revelations 2 is a great horror/tps game as its predecessor, featuring the comeback of two of the most beloved Resident Evil characters and also offering an amazing shooter experience for the price of a shiettty pixel-art indie game.

reviewText:
I've not played much in the genre and this is the first in the series I have played. I bought as part of a humble bundle and was fully aware that it was a single episode and short.

So after all the disclaimers, I can say I actually quite enjoyed this game. The game scared me several times, so the atmosphere is what I believe it should be. The characters were interesting enough and varied enough that I enjoyed playing them. I enjoyed the two person teams for the missions.

On the downside, it was a little easy to get lost in the dark on the second part of episode. perhaps that's part of the fun, but I wasn't sure if I was going in the right direction. Also, not knowing just how dead you are getting was annoying.

8/10

reviewText:
Surprisingly, this game is really great and the best of the RE series that I played so far. Why? Because this is a true horror survival - not a action oriented shooter horror like RE 5 - but more true to the originals and as one of few horror games out there that works perfectly in co-op mode (Once you are ingame after the intro, press start on your two gamepads and you are set) ! The split-screen co-op with gamepads is fantastically implemented, the roles for the two players are very different making it more interesting. The pace of the game is perfect. Most importantly though, this game has NONE of those ♥♥♥♥ing ridiculous quick-time events that I hated so much in RE 5 and 6. Good riddance to those.

This is just a really good survival horror game with a good story that goes on with a good pace. It has none of the weaknesses RE 5 and RE 6 had, such as silly dialogs, action sequences and story. Instead it just comes off as well polished.

The only thing I miss a bit from RE 5 is the ability sell items and upgrade your weapons and this feeling of general ammo scarcity. This is perfectly made up by the fact that this game is overall much better than RE 5 and probably more true to the first RE parts. The upgrading in RE:Revelations 2 happens via items you find, and the upgrades can be attached / detached when you find a bench. There are also skills you can unlock globally for certain/all characters, using XP you collect by completing missions.

Imo, this game should have been named RE 6, and RE 6 should be named as some action spin-off of the series. This game is the real dea l and catches the real spirit of the series, forget RE 6.

reviewText: Overall, from what I can tell from the first episode, the campaign is great. Claire's portion feels a lot like The Evil Within, but a lot more restrained resource-wise. The Survival difficulty is balanced to bring back that old RE feeling of every bullet counting, without being almost unplayable like Revelations 1's Infernal difficulty was.  Barry's campaign is similar to the side campaigns in Revelations where you begin with more weaponry and the gameplay is more action-oriented, similar to RE5. His campaign also introduces rudimentary stealth elements, but they seem largely unnecessary even on Survival unless you're like me and just went with it anyways for the sport of it.\n\nThe only thing that bothers me is that there isn't any sort of campaign co-op. In RE5 and 6, I felt like the co-op was an unnecessary addition, and I felt that survival horror was best when you're isolated. But in this game, where the side characters are more support characters than actual full roles (Moira and Natalia are only able to attack using melee, with Natalia only being able to use bricks found in the environment and largely relying on Barry), I feel like co-op could add a really interesting dynamic to the game. The game does support couch co-op on the console versions, but this was removed from the PC version. I can understand why Capcom might think that people might not be interested in playing this game in co-op due to the fact that the support characters don't necessarily see much action"
date: but I personally would love playing a support roll for someone else. The lack of co-op doesn't ultimately affect whether or not I would recommend the game to someone
hoursPlayed: you'll probably like this too."

reviewText: I enjoyed Rev 1, it was a good game and felt like a return to form for the series to me. 2 didn’t look very promising when I first saw it so I passed on it. Recently I got Episode 1 as a gift from the Humble Bundle. I actually enjoyed it for a while and I felt that the $20 for the rest of the season was worth the time I had already spent with it. Ultimately I got my money’s worth out of Raid Mode, but the campaign is ♥♥♥♥ and why I can’t recommend it. My suspicions of the game being a mess due to ripping off disparate elements from other popular action horror games at the time (i.e. Last of Us, Evil Within) proved true as the campaign is just a mess and it’s unable to decide what it wants to be. Enemies are numerous and tend to keep respawning and ammo is scare but they are very few options to avoid enemies. There are tricks like how Moira can regen and Claire can melee enemies while she’s AI controlled so you can kill enemies without wasting ammo but they still love throwing damage-sponge enemies at you where that trick won’t be very effective. I just stopped at Episode 2 because it just became a slog. It’s good to see Claire and Barry back, but they can’t make up for the rest of the campaign.\n\nRaid Mode is fun, especially with a buddy, but it can be pretty grindy. As I said though, I enjoyed what I played of it.  It’s a shame that Capcom screwed this game up, because if they just improved on Rev 1’s formula without slapping together elements from other games it could have been real good.

reviewText:
Avoid like the plague.

I'm running this game with an i5 4690k and a Sapphire R9 290 Tri-X which is totally overkill for this game and the amount of dropped frames and jittery movements of the player models and panning of the camera angle makes this game look even more disgusting than the dated graphics would have you believe.

I spent £5 because I thought hmmm a cheap RE title
date:
I might as well give it a try" - my word of advice - DON'T!

I got 36 minutes of gameplay from the mission which was even drawn out by the fact I had died 4 times (most times due to backing up into spinning blades due to the totally glitched audio which I shall get on to in a second). I've attempted to play the "RAID mode" and I once beat it within 6 minutes...and then the game crashed trying to save that data. My other 7 or 8 attempts to start this mode has resulted in a crash of the game.

As other people have stated the description of this game is a straight-up lie. There is no offline or online co-op to speak of.

Something which I noticed which nobody else has really seemed to mention in these reviews is how the audio in this game is just downright broken. For anyone that doesn't already know
recommended: this game incorporates the usage of 2 characters at all times where they attempt to help eachother out and overcome challenges and "puzzles". Every now and then these characters exchange utterances
hoursPlayed:
and if you are unfortunate enough to pan your camera angle a few degrees half-way through their mindless chatter then it will sound as though one character is letting out a slight murmur from several miles  away.

Another thing which people fail to point out is how downright atrocious the control settings are. I'm a PC gamer through-and-through and the mouse control is completely unusable because the default sensitivity has you doing 360 degree spins at the slightest movement - and to make matters worse is the total lack of "mouse sensitivity" setting available. Plugging in a 360 controller remedies this issue somewhat - but even then there is no option available to alter controller sensitivity.

£5 for a quarter of a "game". 36 minutes of gameplay

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations 2 is the slowest, laggiest, worst-optimized game I have had the misfortune to play on PC.  If it's any relief, other people report it sucks on the consoles as well.

It could be my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ computer. The aging, vernable Athlon II x2 215 in my computer could run loops around the competitors... back in 2007. Acting as the heavy lifter is an AMD 6670 HD card - once considered midrange, but now is so cheap and weak it's almost built into motherboards.

I can't comment on the story. The 20 minutes or so I played of Raid were decent... or would have been if the game weren't stuttering. It's essentially a corridor shooter. For $1, I can't be bothered to ask for a refund.

Don't support crap ports. Say no to this ho.

reviewText:
The story in this game is sort of a 2 parter as in you play as Claire Redfield / Moira Burton and then later on you play as Barry Burton and Natalia Korda.  Claire and Moira get kidnapped and find themselves in an abandon prison. You're trying to survive and make it out alive.   Barry is trying to find his daughter Moira as he gotten a distress call from her. Barry finds a girl on the island named Natalia and he keeps her company while trying to find his daughter.

Gameplay is much improved from the first Revelations and looks even better. You can change your character on the fly with a push of a button. Each person has their own abilites. For example, Moira has a flashlight and a crowbar. She can use the flash light to find and highlight items, Blind enemies, or use a crowbar to beat up on someone, open up heavier boxes/doors.  While Claire uses weapons that you find.  Revelations 2 is its own story and you don't have to play the first one to understand whats going on.  The game plays fine with a controller/ keyboard and has a bunch of graphical settings you can set compared to the last game. So you can beef up the game to your liking.  If you enjoyed playing Resident Evil Revelations or any Resident Evil game then this game is right up your alley.

This game sort has a throwback feel of past Resident Evil games and also an Resident Evil 5 feel when your swaping around your characters.  So far I played the first chapter of the game and im having fun shooting up zombies / mutated monsters.  I played on hard took me around 4 hrs to beat the first chapter. You also get acess to raid mode, which has another level of weapons and abilities. Where you can earn points to upgrade your weapons and perks.   I purchased the complete season. However, say if you wanted to try out a chapter the pricing of $5.99 is surprising well priced for the amount of content you get in the chapter.  There is up to 4 chapters / 2 bonus chapters. A new one is getting released each week, this game is going with an episodic feel with a cliff hanger at the end so far. Can't wait to play the next installment.   I would recommend this 3rd person horror Shooter, would give this game a shot when you see this on steam sale.

So far Raid mode is a mixed bag, it's definitely a budget title with not much in the way of transistion animations for player characters and hit reactions for combat feedback. Combat is decent enough, if nothing special, but hideous frame drops render it unplayable. We're talking single digits here, and I'm running a Quad-core 4GHZ i7 and GTX970. Absolutely unacceptable.

reviewText:
The game has some major issues that make it unplayable for me.
- Audio desynchronized during the first cinematic.
- Framerate drops are common, even after lowering settings and setting a fixed rate.
- Camera movement and aiming are very finicky, even at lowest sensitivity settings.
- I was knocked off a ladder while well out of reach of any enemies.
- The Co-op issue I wasn't even aware of until reading other reviews, but its lack of presence on the PC version is worth mentioning.

All in all, I don't not recommend you purchase this game. At least until its updated to correct these issues.

reviewText:
С полной уверенностью могу сказать что все отрицательные обзоры писали кучка тупых недовольных школьников.
Если вам понравился первый REvelations - покупайте, потому как эта часть почти не отличается от первой в плане геймплея, но есть небольшие изменения (вместо генезиса из первой части у нас есть второй персонаж с фонариком, что гораздо быстрее и лучше работает + можно ослеплять врагов). Есть классические и новые персонажи (отдельный большой + за БЭРРИ), графика лучше чем в первой, отличный сеттинг, звук ♥♥♥♥♥♥, есть пугающие моменты (гораздо лучше чем в первой части). В плане ДЛС все шикарно и не могу понять почему люди негодуют. По моему все максимально справедливо : не хочешь покупать все эпизоды вместе с костюмами и доп. персонажами для рейд мода - ПОЖАЛУЙСТА, покупай только эпизоды по мере их выхода, если умер пока проходил миссию в рейд моде - ПОЖАЛУЙСТА, купи кристалл и возродись (в первых резидентах такой опции не было, ты умер значит начинай заново, а здесь у вас просто есть выбор и все).
Игра однозначно стоит своих денег. Если говорить про минусы, то все что я видел это поправимо, например : при первом запуске все было на мин. настройках и возможность поменять настройки мне дали только уже после начала игры (в глав меню есть только начать игру и выход), еще нету коопа, НО он будет, ну и ....в общем то это все, никаких фризов и зависаний я не обнаружил, и у меня комп средний, все настройки на максимуме.
В итоге, по первому эпизоду и оффлайновой части рейд мода видно что игра достойная, и из современных интерпретации резидента это самое близкое по настроению к первым частям франшизы, однозначно рекомендую настоящим фанатам серии. 8/10

reviewText:
Campaign feels a little short so far, but I suppose thats the point of an episodic release. Game does a good job with the atmosphere.
Lots of people complaining about frame rate and performance, but I personally had no trouble until the Raid Mode where it would stutter a bit when loading the maps. Speaking of Raid mode, it's once again a fun diversion that will have you playing long after you complete the campaign.
It's a great sequel to Revelations.

If you're sitting on the fence about the game, you can just buy one episode for the price of a baguette. Baguettes don't entertain you for 3 hours or let you shoot zombies though.

reviewText:
Very atmospheric installment of the RE series.

Gameplay is satisfying as you constantly swap between Claire Redfield and Moira Burton: Claire gets the heavy weaponry, while Moira holds the torch. The torch is essential for locating pickups much like Jill's scanner in RE: R 1. But it's when Moira also gets the crowbar that the fun starts:

Tip: When there are single enemies, choose Moira and use her torch to blind the creature. Claire eventually wades in automatically with her melee knocking him to the ground. Then smash him with Moira's crowbar - this saves on a lot of ammo.

RE: R 2 isn't without its problems. Framerates can get horrendous during combat, especially with multiple enemies. But this should be sorted eventually with the inevitable patches. The graphics are ok and don't warrant the framerate drops, whilst the cut-scenes are quaintly old-school.

Despite this, as an old-school Resi fan, I'm really enjoying the game so far, and can wholeheartedly recommend it to any fan of the genre. 8.5/10


Edit:

Ok, so we're the third episode in and, despite a couple of patches, the framerate for the single-player campaign is anywhere from fair to atrocious. I am able to run more demanding games than this, yet the stuttering, even in cut scenes, renders this game almost unplayable.

It's a great shame as RE: R2 could be a fantastic return to form for the franchise, yet technical issues make this game not an enjoyable experience at all.

Revised score: 5/10

reviewText:
Well what can i say. Resident evil revelations 2 part 1 was a little gem. The extremely well though out environment and new enemies really felt like a lot of work has been put into this game. The two person game mechanics worked really well as you didnt need to constantly switch between characters but instead providing you with incentive by giving perks for doing so.
The serious lack of ammo really made me feel frightened at times and i had to on many occations resort to using the old knife and dodge techinque which actually worked well.
The space is smaller and instead of large maps with bland halls, we instead got tight spaces with well though out environments.
I cant wait to start the next chapter and i would say that so far, revelations 2 holds a slight lead on revelations 1.
Overall i would rate the game a solid 8/10
My machine did struggle at times and there were a few instances where it wasn't clear what i was supposed to do next.

reviewText:
The people who reviewed this game negatively did it off of a standpoint of which I do not follow. This game is about on par with resident evil 5 for combat. the voice acting, although not great, does have some strong points. it is very interesting how they intertwined 2 stories together, one boasting a great stealth like RE3 approach, while the other is reminiscent of RE6 in terms of how much ammo and weapons you start with.

Pros:
-Very good story thus far.
-Graphics are about what you'd expect.
-Gameplay is interestingly intertwined, for all types of survival horror players.
-Weapons are balanced equally with monsters.

Cons:
-No merchant!
-Set up more like RER which while that is good, it has it's drawbacks.
-Atmosphere is a little iffy, reminds me of The Evil Within.
-Voice acting is a little cheesy, although it has it's strong points.

I will not rate this game with a number due to people who want to skim through the reviews to look for numbers, so let this short guide help you.

reviewText:
To start with I'm relatively new to the resident evil series, having only played 4-6 and, now, both Revelations.  I found both 4 and Revelations to be the most fun by far.

Currently revelations 2 feels like a mix of RE4 and Revelations with a small bit of 5/6.  The basic controls are the same as revelations, but there is a true inventory system like the one in RE5.

A feature that I am currently ambivalent towards is the partner swapping feature.  While the support character has useful abilities, they cannot use guns and as such their ability to fight is severely limited.  Additionally the hidden items in the area can only be seen at all with the support character.

I did have framerate dips here and there, but nothing to bad.

As for the co-op features, I didn't get the game for co-op, but fully understand the issues with no offline co-op on the PC version when it was advertised as having it.

Currently I would recommend it if you are OK with the lack of co-op and enjoyed RE Revelations and RE4.

Edit: As for the day one DLC, it's raid mod characters, costumes, and inventory slots.  If you REALLY need those extra inventory slots, then it's a microtransaction.  Personally I never even came close to running out of inventory slots in revelations 1, so there might be no issue here.

Edit 2:  A couple of new things now that episode 2 is out.  It's telling me to purchase the next episode, despite my having bought the complete season.  So, that needs to be fixed ASAP or I'll be droping this to not recommended.

Second, having played more raid mode I've noticed a lot more issues with frame rate drops in certain maps.  Particuarly defense and timed maps.  As for the new features and changes to raid mode, there don't seem to be any real hidden things in the maps (or at least I havn't found them) like the BSAA medallions in revelations 1 raid mode.  Additionally there are basically 3-4 ammo boxes in each map, and at most 3 weapon or part boxes.

The combining weapon mods to level them up is a feature I like, since it does make it far easier to get  better mods that you want, and I feel that the mods being locked to the weapon they're installed on until you either destroy a part to free a slot or destroy the weapon to free the parts makes it a bit more challenging to decide on a loadout.

The character options also allow for much more customization, similar to the RE6 skill loadouts.  Each character has a different set of skills, which are unlocked as that character levels up.   You use skill points to upgrade the skills that you want, to match your playstyle.  This includes the secondary grenades, which are limited use per mission skills.

I know a lot of peeps are sick of zombie games, but Resi was where it came from (gaming wise) and without these stumbling ghouls..it just wasn't the same. I still follwed the stories etc to all the games, but this one really has made it all up. I am not gonna spoil it, but you get to be one of the old epic characters from Resi 1. and from what I got from ep 1, its kind of bring everything together.  Roll on next week!!!

reviewText:
PC Ver has No offline/online Co-op as of yet but I like what I've seen so far. A Darker and more moody atmosphere is present remiscient of the series horror-roots. I also like the new characters and the teamwork dynamics of the combat. Ammo/supplies are limited like they where back at the roots and so searching for hidden items is encouraged to help stay prepaired. Glad the arcady actio-feeling gameplay is seperate from the Story Mode and can be found  in Raid Mode to create a diverse mix of Survival Horror - Action. Its a fine addition to the game and will keep people clocking in those hours thanks to its RPG-Esque additive gameplay although the missions/gauntlets dont feel as varied as I would like but its enough would still like to have some of the challenge that was present in the orignal Raid Mode in Rev1. With its modest price-tag and mixture of content I deffinately reccomend.

Edit: Still no online co-op for Story Mode, remains offline-local co-op only thanks to patch updates. However co-op offline & online are avliable in Raid Mode.

I have put in nearly 300+ hours in-total and am chuffed with Rev2 an excellent step in the right direction for the series!

reviewText:
It seems I may have overestimated this game... But I cannot down rate it either.

The story is alright: survival horror is done right, I was really scared of glasps. Ammo is scarce, especially on higher difficulties, you'll get more points instead of the ammo. The plot is great too: lots of references to past RE games, we finally got Claire back, but I really hate that stupid Barry's appearance change, (Scratched that because I solved this prob with a mod replacing his face with the one from Remaster). I also like that some of the mechanics from RE6 are back, like finishers. It kept me playing until I got all achievements and S ranks on all episodes and difficulties.

And now to the most disappointing part - the Raid Mode. At first it was really exciting, I've been replaying the first episode for 50 hours. All these new additions - passive and active skills they are really great addition to Raid. You can build up your own set of skills and create various play styles. There were only 2 gauntlets +1 I got from Throwback Map pack. I was looking forward to release of online feature and a new difficulty. Eventually after release of the last episode, the online feature was delayed, and we got a new difficulty which doesn't change enemy spawns, has 4 chests instead of 3, and all enemies were 6 levels above you. This couldn't bring any challenge. I've finished new difficulty a week before online was released. Then they promised to raise difficulty, and I had high hopes for this... and what did they do eventually? They've risen the enemy's level by 15 above yours.. Considering the power of my current guns, I can beat literally any stage on any difficulty with lvl 1. There was nothing new after online was released, you can't even perform grapple breakers in co-op game which is ridiculous, though you can perform them in campaign, how screwed up is that?

Conclusion: 7/10. This was the most awaited game for me this year, which I stopped playing much faster than expected.

reviewText:
I'm asounted at the level of whininess and belligerence directed at this game. Performance issues aside, Resident Evil Revelations 2 is quite good. Many of the people attacking it aren't judging it as a game, and half the criticism comes across as petty and irrational. I never would have expected anyone to get so bent out of shape over no local coop. That's LOCAL coop. As in not online coop. I don't even care if it was mistakenly advertized, the backlash came across as more of a childish manufactured mass temper tantrum than a legit complaint.

anyway

tl;dr version: campaign is quite good. raid mode (while it hooked me) is ok but lazy and very simple to break and make TOO easy.

This game is running off the same engine used for RE6. At first I was worried since RE6 was a terrible game with a terrible engine, but its been tweaked. The controls are tight and fluid and have been reconfigured to be more intuitive and arcadey. It works. Graphically, the game looks great but isn't perfect at the moment. There are frame rate issues, some stuttery camera issues, and some animation issues. Mostly because the game is still new and hasn't been optimized yet.

Anyway, Revelations comes in 2 flavors: campaign and raid mode.

Campaign:

This mode has been polished the most performance wise. Revelations 2 has some stuttering, frame drop issues and goofy graphics issues, but once everything is loaded and working proper, it looks and animates really well. I'm making a point of this since its not the same for raid mode.

If you buy the game for the campaign, you're in for a treat. It is quite good. The story thus far is compelling and mysterious. Capcom has made an attempt to get back to the game's roots by making items and ammunition scarce in turn making the enemies more scary and dangerous as a threat.

However, there are permanent character buffs and weapon modding systems in place that do make the game easier potentially turning it into cakewalk like most recent REs allow.

Also, and I don't know why Capcom keeps doing this with RE games, they've designed the game around a partner system again. So you've got a real dumb AI sidekick that tends to help you in battle by starting at you and getting hit by enemies. Thankfully you can switch between the two characters so if you get downed, you can switch and pick your partner up. Very unlike RE5 when your AI controlled partner would stand next to you and watch you die.

Raid Mode:

Just like Revelations 1, this is the arcadey action mode of Revelations 2. Kind of like mercernaries mode in the older RE's, but expanded upon.

performance wise, raid mode is terrible. Certain maps will frame stutter and lag badly. I have an R9 270x video card, and the first 30 seconds map 6 in gauntlet I is like a slide show no matter what the game's settings are.

Raid mode in Revelations 2 is a departure from Revelations 1's. In Revelations 1, each map was a sequence taken from the campaign and modified into a 3rd person shooter stage. It threw in level progression that would unlock various weapons, characters, and power ups. You could also farm stages for better items. Playing the same level on a harder difficulty yielded different enemy spawns and spawn locations, so each difficulty made the same stage completely different.

However, in Revelations 2, each map is tiny and short and is ripped from RE6 and rarely from Revelations 1 (wtf?). Enemy spawns and spawn locations NEVER change between difficulties. Harder difficulties merely speed enemies up and add more obnoxious status/elemental buffs. Oddly, when enemies spawn they stand up at the same sluggish easy to shoot in the head rate regardless of difficulty. Its actually quite boring. I don't know if this will change once all the chapters are released, but this is what raid mode is currently.

In contrast to the boring levels, Revelations 2 fleshed out the character system tremendously. Instead of having a player level shared between all characters like in Revelations 1, each character has their own individual experience and level gains. As characters level, they unlock new slots for skills and weapons. They also come with their own personal skill sets and earn skill points to purchase and upgrade said skills. Its neat, but seems a bit wasted next to how basic the stages are.

The only thing that remains mostly the same in raid mode is the weapon system. Weapons still come with their own level, but the level no longer exists as a restriction (a lvl 1 guy can use a lvl 75 gun which is nerfed to lvl 1 strength). There are also uncommon guns, gun titles, as well as rare named weapon variations same as Revealtions 1. Rev 2 retains the gun parts system where you earn and pick up and attach gun powerups. Power ups seem to be a little more generic this time however. Currently, its very possible to upgrade a weapon that makes raid mode boring and easy. Very unlike Revelations 1 where the hardest difficulties were still hard as f*ck even if you had a fantastic weapon.

my biggest complaint with Resident Evil Revelations 2: I can't play as the guy who looks like Conan O'brien from Resident Evil Revelations 1.

Anyway, if you made it this far, good job. I wasted too much time typing up a review that will likely not be read.

reviewText:
March 19, 2015
So far I've clocked 80+ hours on this in campaign & raid mode. So it's definitely worth it and I highly recommend it to any resident evil fan. It's got all the nostalgia, some corny lines, a virus, gross stuff, jump scare, tight corridors, and no bad camera angles thank god. Invisible mode is pretty horrible to play through but highly challenging. Also depicts references to other Resident Evils including the very first one..... and most of all Barry makes a return since.. RE, the very first one. Oh and different endings!

Also performance and technical issues described below are now much much improved and is more stable.

March 12
I like the dodge system in that you actually shouldn't dodge/evade your body into a weapon because you think it'll provide i-frames. So yea... do watch where the weapon is coming from which direction and where you want to move away from.

The past&future system is very nice I like how choices you make during the past significantly affect the future character's campaign and that the future character isn't exactly following a same recycled map either with large deviations after running through partially the same map the past character went through.

Problems are there aren't any online co-op until the game is fully released sadly... so for those of us who purchased it early we gotta wait 4 weeks, anyone buying it after the Mar.17th /2015 you should have co-op available or the game really done-fkedup. Other problems that people with weaker computer specs might experience a lot of technical difficulties or technical griefing(e.g. fps dropping to atrocious levels where the game is unplayable, during certain game modes like invisible mode monsters appearing/reappearing cause horrible frame lag for unknown reasons, a lot of end-user made fixes not developer made fixes to work around THEIR problems...)

Aside from that I think it's a good resident evil game, although the partner thing that has occurred in the previous sequels and this most recent title really doesn't help instil horror. Though tight corridors and strange looking freaks will sort of tense you up for the first bit. But once you're used to it the fear dissipates quick.

Playing single player in this game controlling two characters I find is also very smooth, was skeptical at first and thought it would be extremely clunky but the switching between characters is so quick you can practically use both of them in combat to ground stab a guy on the floor at the same time

For the price it's not bad, I definitely wouldnt've paid 59.99(like RE6) for it but for 24.90 on the full story campaign it's not bad. It's more action packed than walking dead where your choices do reflect the future in some ways(weapons, secrets etc.). There's a lot of challenges in the game and a lot of bonus objective things to do if you're into that kind of thing; they call it achievement whoring.

If you have Raid Mode you'll be spending a lot more time in there than in the campaign after you're done the story.

reviewText:
I'm writing this a few days after the initial release in February 2015, I've completed the first installment and enjoyed what I've played of the game, I've noticed a lot of negativity being directed at this but it seems to me a lot of that is mis-directed and more to do with secondary issues such as this being Capcom's baby.

Performance wise I've got no complaints, I experienced a bit of character judder on day 1 which was very off putting but it hasn't happened since so I can't find anything that put's me off the game. I'm running an AMD gpu (I thought I'd mention that as there can be a performance difference based on brand with some games).

This is not an overpriced title and I think it is well worth getting. For what I've played (remember it had an episodic release originally) I'm giving it an eight out of ten.

8/10

reviewText:
Be aware that because Capcom is the most inconsistent company there is with their PC ports, that this game has unfixable input lag with M&K and even with a gamepad. It makes aiming with a gamepad an enormous hit and miss chore, and M&K is actually the way you want to go. I still take unnecessary hits when playing with M&K because I am inaccurate once in a while because of the input lag when facing enemies moving quickly towards me. However I was able to mess around in the game options with some things and turn down my mouse sensitivity in razer synapse both to a point where I can play through the game relatively well enough to get through without too much trouble. But the input lag is still there, and it wasn't in ANY other RE game, not even in RE 4 or Revelations 1, so why here? It makes no sense. I stopped preordering Capcom games a long time ago because they are so spotty with there PC ports and this game is a perfect example of that.

The game is good. It improves on RE:R1 quite a bit. It is a RE game for sure, with the RE atmosphere, weapons, enemies, items, characters, and so-bad-it's-good voice acting. I still reccommend 6 over any of the other games because it just has such perfect controls and gunplay and the best herb combination system in the whole series. I really don't have any complaints for this game besides the shtty input lag.

Though it is a solid game and is very fun, and I can play through and get things done fairly okay even with the input lag after messing around with it quite a bit and fixing it to a playable point, which you should never have to fight with in any game, I am not recommending it because I am not supporting any more of Capcom's brainless, sloppily, carelessly programmed PC ports. If they can do something so idiotic to this game even though Revelations 1 controlled just fine, then never fix this game because they could care less, then just imagine what's in store for future Capcom PC ports. It's hit or miss. reviewText:
Be aware that because Capcom is the most inconsistent company there is with their PC ports, that this game has unfixable input lag with M&K and even with a gamepad. It makes aiming with a gamepad an enormous hit and miss chore, and M&K is actually the way you want to go. I still take unnecessary hits when playing with M&K because I am inaccurate once in a while because of the input lag when facing enemies moving quickly towards me. However I was able to mess around in the game options with some things and turn down my mouse sensitivity in razer synapse both to a point where I can play through the game relatively well enough to get through without too much trouble. But the input lag is still there, and it wasn't in ANY other RE game, not even in RE 4 or Revelations 1, so why here? It makes no sense. I stopped preordering Capcom games a long time ago because they are so spotty with there PC ports and this game is a perfect example of that.

The game is good. It improves on RE:R1 quite a bit. It is a RE game for sure, with the RE atmosphere, weapons, enemies, items, characters, and so-bad-it's-good voice acting. I still reccommend 6 over any of the other games because it just has such perfect controls and gunplay and the best herb combination system in the whole series. I really don't have any complaints for this game besides the shtty input lag.

Though it is a solid game and is very fun, and I can play through and get things done fairly okay even with the input lag after messing around with it quite a bit and fixing it to a playable point, which you should never have to fight with in any game, I am not recommending it because I am not supporting any more of Capcom's brainless, sloppily, carelessly programmed PC ports. If they can do something so idiotic to this game even though Revelations 1 controlled just fine, then never fix this game because they could care less, then just imagine what's in store for future Capcom PC ports. It's hit or miss. There is a 50/50 chance that with each new game they are putting out in the future that there will be some major flaw with it that they will never fix, because that is just how they work and that is the reputation that they have built for themselves as a company on the PC side of things.

Capcom: Great games, horrible ethics towards making PC games.

reviewText:
I didn't expect much from this one, and yet I got much more out of it than from lots of other, far better reviewed games of recent memory.

First of all, the (first episode) of the story campaign is a well done mix of the old and new Resident Evil styles with room for bizarre body horror mutants and slow walking zombies as well. The pacing is really good and fun, violent action as well as slower moments of exploring the creepy hallways both coexist. The game is often surprisingly scary, especially in the second act where you control Barry.

And that's just the first two hours of the game: After that, there's the Raid Mode which turns out to be a completely different game in and of itself. It contains of a bunch of unique levels (not just recycled ones from the single player campaign). You have to shoot your way through them, earn points, purchase new skills and weapons, earn trophies, unlock new levels and then do it all again with another character. It unfolds an incredibly depths and enables a variety of completely different play styles and I'll probably sink many hours into it.

That's what I got for just 6€. It's an incredibly good value for a well produced and polished game (especially the game play). After all the discussions of The Order: 1886 I hope this game might serve as an example of how smaller AAA games can succeed with a more humble pricing and a high focus on gameplay. Resident Evil Revelations 2 has one priority: offering an enjoyable and fun time.

reviewText:
I've played the first episode and have done just about all the gauntlets/maps in raid mode so I feel confident enough to write a review for this.

Story- It's pretty meh, but it's just the beginning so I'd imagine it picks up and gets better with further episodes.

Raid Mode- Fantastic as ever. I like most of the changes they made, though some are rather annoying and degrade the experience. There's plenty of levels to play through currently and you got enough characters to progress with. Overall good times.

Pros- Good bit of content for $6 if you buy the episode individually or $25 if you get the complete season. I managed to get 2 copies at a discount and it is plenty worf so far. Raid mode is the main course while the Story mode is like an appetizer at the current moment.

Cons- FPS drops harder that the bass in all dem fancy kazoo songs. Lack of offline co-op for story mode might bother some people, not me really. 2nd player would really only be either holding a flashlight or pointing and throwing bricks. Not too much fun. The real main problem is lack of offline and online co-op for Raid mode. What's the point of fighting off hordes of cancerous infected with the downs if you can't do so with a buddy? Fix the FPS drop and add Raid mode Co-op and I'm a happy camper. Also, the limit of weapons, parts, and discs you can store is terrible. In that regards, it's blantant cash grab with their expansion packs for storage. Bad Capcom, bad.

Bottomline- If you enjoyed the first Revelation's Raid mode, then get this game. Best would be getting the complete season as it's cheaper alternative than each individual episode or the retail copy that comes out in March. Unless your internet is bad, then well get the retail. If you're just looking for a quick bit of fun, just buy the episode and play Raid Mode. If you are all enamored with the offline Story Mode Co-op, get the console versions. If you don't like Raid mode then you're just outta luck.

reviewText:
Update 3/19/15
1. Capcom fully patched the frame rate issue this time. Shout outs to them. Game runs smooth for me.
2.Moira actually grew on me, she went from fairly annoying to having some of my favorite lines in the game.
3. The story was fantastic. Loved it. Raid mode still fun solo, Game is still a 7/10.
Update 3/2/15:
1. Capcom came through with a patch to remedy the frame rate drops making them incredibly rare, though they still happen when I pan or rotate the camera too fast. My laptop isn't that powerful so that could be why I still see them.
2.Finished Episode 1! Barry and Natalia are an amazing pair. The father-daughter thing works well for them. Of course Natalia still freaks me out when I spin the camera around and she's just standing there staring at Barry.
3. If you're like me. impatient, the episodic structure may not be for you. There are a lot of things to do even with 1 episode out (at the time of writing) Waiting for the full game release 3/17 might be your best choice if episodic isn't your style!
4. With the patch and having experienced more of the story I can definitely recommend this game as stated I now score it at a 7/10 even without the full game being out yet.

Will continue to update throughout the release schedule!

Original 2/25/15:
Writting this from MY experience so far! Score: 6.5/10 will probably go up to about a 7  when fully released and patched.

I'm only giving this a thumbs up because there isn't an in-between rating. I recommend waiting until Capcom releases a fix before buying! Once they fix these things I would definitely recommend it.

RE Revelations 2 as the potenial to be an amazing title, however there are glaring problems:
1. Frame Rate drops, like most reviews before mine I have experienced drops and freezes. I managed to make them less frequent by lowering my settings a bit, but they are still incredibly noticable. ***Patched***
2. Co-op functionality, while I personally don't play Resident Evil as a co-op game anyway, we were promised co-op for this version of the game and I expected the option to be available as most others did.***There's a local co-op mod being released/worked on if it's that serious??***
3. Window settings, there doesn't seem to be a Fullscreen (windowed) option and the Windowed view made the game sluggish. ***No lionger an issue.***
While these things take a fair amount out of the submersion of the game, they don't make it unplayable.
Some positive notes:
1. Atmosphere, I'm not too far into Episode 1 but I personally think the Horror aspect is definitely there within the prison setting so far. Had a few jump scares even when I knew that something was going to jump out.

2. Raid Mode, From what I've seen some people experienced crashes here, I however didn't. Incredibly fun mode even solo. I actually think it's more fun/challenging this way.

3. Characters, So far, I think the characters are enjoyable. Claire and Moira have a unique chemistry. Although I don't care for Moira's speech patterns, but she's a teenage girl I didn't expect much. See Ohmigod"

4. Story
date: Not much to say here. It's dark

reviewText: This is a very good game that begins decent and then improves with each episode to become a creepy, fun, action-horror experience. Although the graphics are not astounding, the atmosphere is suitably creepy with varied environments (including a nice homage to the past...). There are creepy enemy encounters, some great tension filled battles in which character switching is very useful, a few shock scares, and one shock scare in particular that *almost* made me scream, haha. There is varied gameplay between the Claire/Moira episodes and the Barry/Natalia episodes. While I generally enjoy stealthy games, I did find myself feeling that Natalia's ability was a bit to powerful and made the stealth component a bit easy. Overall, on Normal the game isn't too difficult, and I was a little surprised that most of the boss battles weren't very tough...I am eager to try the game on hard to see if this changes! Raid mode, although I have only played it for a couple hours, is very fun in an arcade-y, addictive, pick up and play sort of way. Combining this with the multiple difficulty levels, all of the things to search for and find, and all of the medals to attempt to acquire means that you are getting a substantive game for $25. Highly recommended!

reviewText: A definite improvement over the first Revelations game, which was itself a definite improvement over the likes of Resident Evil 6...so at least the series is heading in a positive direction.  We're still not back to the glory days of Resident Evils 1-4 and Code Veronica, though - try The Evil Within instead if you want something THAT good! - but this is probably the best Resident Evil game since number 4 (yes, THAT long ago).\n\nIt's certainly nice to see the horror taking precedence over the action again, and the character-swapping mechanics are possibly the most successfully realised in a Res Evil game, period (i.e. MORE than just a cheap gimmick).  And, wait for it...STEALTH in a Res Evil game, for the first time ever if I'm not mistaken!  Nice.  Add in some frankly amazing graphics, probably the best characterisation and dialogue in the history of the franchise, and some nice little in-jokes for the long-term fans (NOW who's the master of unlocking?")
recommended: it's pretty hard to complain about this one.  Keep it up
hoursPlayed: Capcom...\n\nVerdict: 9.5/10."

reviewText:
Another great Resident Evil game. If you enjoyed RE4, RE5, RE6 and Revelations 1 you will love this game. They even brought back raid mode, a much better raid mode I must say.

The campaign is well thought out and it will suck you in big time and it also offers a lot of replay value. The medals can prove very challenging and are fun to achieve. Barry's humor will make you laugh lol. This game even has more the one ending based on in game decisions.

Warning! Raid mode is very addicting. It is all about fighting enemies and gaining abilities and weapons that you can trick out and customize. The stages start off easy but they get harder I'm telling you haha but it is so fun to grind in this mode.

This game is so complete and it connects a lot of things that happened previously in RE lore. A must buy if you are committed to the series.
