reviewText: Waited until episode 4 was released before I would pass judgement on this game. The verdict, I greatly enjoyed this game and played through each episode multiple times just because I thought it was that fun. The co-op mechanic, while not ideal for survival horror, is mechanically the best in the series.  Having played every RE except the Code Veronica Gun Survivor and the mobile phone games, I gotta say this is one of my new favorites and if they are going to continue this co-op style, then they should build off of what they did here.

reviewText:
Despite the tedious technical problems for PC players; Revelations 2 is a much needed improvement on the less desirable qualities of Capcom's latest attempts of the last 10+ years.

Unlike titles 4-6, while the action is more than survival horror should be, it finds a great balance of enthralling, but not over-the-top, Rambo styled, roundhouse kicking/face splitting atrocities of its formers.

Unlike RE 4, specifically, your AI partners are rather useful and don't get on your last nerve.

Unlike it's predecessor, Revelations 2 has a very satisfying amount of monsters and atmosphere (though for a 3DS game, it's hard to complain).

Revelations 2 is a good 8ish hours to spend your time if you play all six chapters. Not overly informative to the universal storyline of Resident Evil, but definitely a welcomed addition  - - 8.5/10.

Atmosphere:Hm...it honestly doesn't feel like resident evil 4-6 it feels more like siren. In my opinion some areas in the game get to that level of scary, if for short periods of time.
Story:It's alright, but it seriously feels like a siren game.

Can't decide on whether this or 4-6 mercs is better but this mode is pretty damn good.

reviewText:
First off, lemme say that I think the game is an overall enjoyable experience considering the budget. I don't regret my purchase and will definitely play all the future episodes. But the game certainly has many problems, and I honestly don't really expect them to fix any of these as more episodes are released.

Gameplay
The biggest thing about Revelations 2 is the overhaul to the partners system. Rather than simply having an incompetent AI who won't kill anything and might as well not be there at all, each partner now actually feels valuable. I had my concerns when I saw the trailer and discovered I had to switch control to a second character just so I can shine a flashlight at stuff, but after playing, I realized playing as the utility character" can actually be pretty fun.

However...

While the partner actions are well designed
date: they're very poorly implemented. The AI is still as dumb as ever
recommended: and the fact that more is now expected from your partner only makes it worse. During a fight
hoursPlayed: you can't even predict if your partner will follow you as you run down a corridor... some times they just stand still and get hit!\n\nThere are some fun partner-melee combos in Revelations 2
voteText: but you simply cannot expect the AI to properly do their part
helpfulPercent: so if you want to perform them
votesHelpful: it's usually best that you switch back-and-forth and perform both roles by yourself.\n\nIn Revelations 2 you have one "weapons" character who carries all the firearms
votesTotal: and an "utility" character who doesn't really have any weapons at all. Now get this: if you're in control of the utility character
votesFunny: the AI in control of the weapons character WON'T FIRE THE GUNS AT ALL until you've beaten the story and unlocked a perk on the post-game screen
commentsCount: said perk will actually allow them to fire guns and not consume any bullets at all
column16: but at a drastically reduced damage (hint: just have the AI use a weapon with high knock-back power).\n\nAnd while the utility character can indeed do many cool tricks
column17: the game likes to keep those a secret from you until it's too late. There are many moments where you will have barely survived an onslaught
column18: and the game will tell you
column19: "BY THE WAY
column20: YOU COULD'VE DONE THIS AND AVOIDED ALL THAT TROUBLE ALTOGETHER." Come on
column21:
seriously?

Story
Gameplay complaints aside
column22: I did enjoy the story. The decision to do episodic releases is kind of weird - I guess they wanted a share of The Walking Dead's success. But the first episode did end on an interesting cliffhanger
column23:
and I'm curious to find out what happens next.

Raid Mode
Raid Mode is mostly the same as it was Revelations 1. It's very grindy and not quite as fun as Mercenaries. It's enjoyable though. If you have the patience to get through the boring early levels
column24: you'll find yourself pleasantly surprised at the variety of enemies this mode offers.\n\nI'm not sure if this is exclusive to the Throwback Map pack
column25: but I've played through quite a few stages taken from RE6. It's fun to start a mission and be thrown into a familiar setting. The downside is that revisiting these levels will really make you realize how inferior the graphics are in this game."

reviewText:
RE-RE2, while suffering from some over-mentioned issues, is a solid experience that can only get better from here.

Episodic" format and temporarily missing co-op aside - there is plenty on offer to keep players entertained while waiting for the next installment (if they find themselves enjoying the basics and not bogged down by the [hopefully future patched] FPS spikes).

While there are noticable graphical dips (port)
date: the game still looks and plays decently. It may not be a return to "Survival Horror" in its most true format - but it does have elements of it
recommended: blended with the more recent 'action' style of previous titles. It won't scare you - but a surprisingly fresh and haunting soundtrack (with gentle nods to movies such as The Thing - and even a subtle hint of Star Wars) compliments light touches of gameplay creepiness or tension.\n\nUnlike previous titles (RE5/RE6)
hoursPlayed: duo-character play see's each character having their own unique abilities
voteText: whereas RE5 AI was practically identical - and RE6 was different only in melee moves and equipped weapons. Here

reviewText: Over looking the fact that there is no co-op function as promised (Sort it out ASAP), the game, so far for me, has put my faith back into the resident evil series. As we can all agree that 5 and 6 was more action than actual horror. Resident Evil Revelations 2 has once again got my heart pounding and my brain scared, the switch between players is a good concept as each character has different abilities and its not just there for the sake of being there, the amount of ammo is enough so then I'm not knifing everything but low enough for me to be worried, traps, infected and jump scares are all brilliant. However puzzles can either be predictable or are unclear to what they want the player to do. Overall though, definitely a step up from the last realises and has brought it back to the genre that bad it a good series in the first place, although they do need to sort out the co-op feature.\n\nOverall I would rate it (excluding there being no Co-op and focusing on the single player) 7/10

reviewText: This game is not as bad as people let on.  I've played through and beaten it and am running a moderate system (AMD FX-4130 3.8 GHz processor, 8 Gigs of Ram, Nvidia GTX 650), and there is some framerate slowage in certain areas (namely at the very beginning of the game, which seems to be all some of these people have actually played through).  However, I really never had framerate droppage around enemies so it never effected my gameplay.  My best guess is that there are certain moments in this game where it's initializing a lot of data and those are the spots where there's framerate droppage.  It is annoying when those moments occur, but this game is completely playable.\n\nThis is a fun resident evil so I would recommend it, especially at it's low price, but it's not a great, cannonical-style resident evil.  It doesn't feel completely 100% console, it feels a bit like a handheld game.  It's fairly low-poly, the environments aren't as cool as many resident evils, and it's got forced NPC characters that accompany you completely along the way (something people complained about in RE5).  These forced NPCs don't really add much to the game, they have the ability to see things in the environments that the main" character can't

recommended: I felt obliged to do so just to find items in my environment

reviewText: I personally havent had any issues with crashing that others have listed, however I do reccomend the console version if you have the option because the Frame Rate can slow down once in a while but this hasnt been a consistant problem for me. That being said, this is a decent game so far. The first half of episode 1 is a bit of a slow burn, and Moira will annoy the hell out of you, but it picks up after the first half and raid mode is alot of fun and adds some replayability  (although personally I prefer Mercenaries mode from the other games.) The microtransactions in raid mode are dumb but they dont affect the gameplay. Its a bit early to judge the entire game seeing as how we still have to wait for the last three episodes. I wouldn't say this game is off to a great start but its difinitely not awful. Here's to hoping the game improves with each episode.

reviewText:
Despite the tedious technical problems for PC players; Revelations 2 is a much needed improvement on the less desirable qualities of Capcom's latest attempts of the last 10+ years.

Unlike titles 4-6, while the action is more than survival horror should be, it finds a great balance of enthralling, but not over-the-top, Rambo styled, roundhouse kicking/face splitting atrocities of its formers.

Unlike RE 4, specifically, your AI partners are rather useful and don't get on your last nerve.

Unlike it's predecessor, Revelations 2 has a very satisfying amount of monsters and atmosphere (though for a 3DS game, it's hard to complain).

Revelations 2 is a good 8ish hours to spend your time if you play all six chapters. Not overly informative to the universal storyline of Resident Evil, but definitely a welcomed addition  - - 8.5/10.

I was wary about this game after my massive distaste with Resident Evil 6. However, I decided to trust the developers based on some footage and gave the game a chance. I don't regret it whatsoever.

The environments are amazingly detailed, gritty, and it harkens back to what I missed most about the Resident Evil series. That feeling of dread. I'm loving this game.

If you loved Resident Evil 4, and back when the game still had horror elements to it then I definetly recommend you snag this bad boy.

reviewText:
What can I say about Resident Evil: Revelations 2 that has not been said already... It's okay, but heavly flawed both gameplay and story wise.

First off, the graphics are subpar at best, nothing fancy, but graphics don't mean everything in gaming, well to me anyways, so I will let that slide.

Now for the story, it is a very interesting and creepy story, but it doesn't allow much room to exand upon unfortunately, as for the characters, you have Claire Redfeild, Moria Burton for one half and Barry Burton and Natalia for the other and they both play pretty similar, but with some minor differences, which I will get to in a minute. First, Claire and Moria's half of the story is much better in my opinion simply because of the atmosphere, it's creepy, dark and you feel danger all around you, you don't get that or much of that from Barry and Natalia's half sadly, which contains mostly Barry and his overpowered weapons like his Magnum and Assualt Rifle you get at the very start and when you start, it's pretty much the ame enviroments as it's set in the after the events Clarie and Moria went through (Sorry for the spoiler if you haven't played it already). But overall the gameplay is where it's at right? Wrong. It is almost identical in the style of RE: Revelations and RE6, sloppy and most of the time really boring. The scenery can be nice for brief moments, but the audio is once again amazing for Resident Evil standards anyways, the voice acting? Meh.

Now the story was okay at the start, but then it kind of throws a curve ball at some points where your scratching your head as to why am I here? Who is this person behid all of this? What happens with your braclet? Ahh yes, before I forget about it, the braclets... They seem to only have a subtle part in the overall story, meaning it has nothing to do with the story, it's mentioned about 4 - 5 times and that's pretty much it, no build-up with it and no answers, just never mentioned again. Isn't that nice?

Anyways, the game is okay, but for Resident Evil standards, especially as of late, it's okay, but I would rather play Resident Evil 6 to be honest. That's right... I said it... This game is for real fans of Resident Evil or Third-Person Shooter fanatics, but not for the folks who liked anything between RE1 to RE4.

reviewText:
*UPDATED*

Well the game itself is solid. I love the mechanics, the inventory, the crafting, the theme, the characters etc.

The game runs great and its a good return to a horror theme with frightening elements.

But CAPCOM, I cannot recommend this game. Why would you put TWO different endings, and make it not explicit that there was a choice to be made. The bad ending was fine but finding out that there were TWO, and then watching how much more satisfying it was for the good. I felt like I wasted my time because all my actions led up to telling me that I failed...?

At least the choices were explicit in 1-3

reviewText:
Edit: Capcom seems to have made the performance improvements. Game still stutters a little but is vastly more playable now - updating review.

Keep the improvements coming!

---------------------------

The game is a lot of fun... when it perfroms adequately. And half of the time it doesn't. There are some signs that the game at its current state is not acceptably optimized for the PC, even on high-end machines. Parts of the game would run smoothly on the highest settings, then all of the sudden goes into a frame-drop frenzy, rendering the game unplayable.

I cannot recommend this game until there is a fix for the performance issues. Unpredictable frame rate drops, stuttering and the lags really takes away from the game experience. The game does show a lot of promise with the improvements on Revelations 1 and the raid mode put on steriods - if only we can play it properly.

Unless you enjoy fighting a group of zombies at a stunning, seizure-inducing 10FPS, stay away - come back when there is a fix.

reviewText: I bought this game so me and my friend could play through the story of the game together... we both launch the game and to our dismay it says that you can only play CO-OP on raid... the game clearly states that it's CO-OP therefore it should be a CO-OP game. Why should I pay money on a game that falsely advertises itself as a CO-OP game. I have completely lost all respect I had for steam. The game states that it is a multiplayer game" that is obviously for raid mode and "local CO-OP" and "online CO-OP".  in this they are implying that the "multiplayer" is for the raid mode and the "CO-OP'S" are for the story
date: furthermore why create a game that has an AI companion that cannot be controlled by a friend/companion? Especially because almost all the previous games had CO-OP story. I am sincerely disappointed in STEAM and CAPCOM.\nYours sincerely a previously loyal consumer...\nLastly I am considering boycotting steam in general and telling all my followers to do the same."

reviewText:
PRO TIP: Never pre-order games from capcopm WAIT until you see how well it performs.

PROS:
-Interesting mechanics (Switching between the two playable character at any time, most of them have especial atributes. ex; Natalia can sense invisible enemies that Barry can't see but he needs to kill)
-Interesting story, not so good but really entertaining.
-Raid mode is back again
-Really neat soundtrack (Specially on raid mode)
-Decent graphics
-Claire is a hotie
-And Moira is... Moira.

CONS:
-Unstable mess; fps drops, jerky visuals
-flat character development
-Game it's pretty easy even on hard
-Sometimes the game switches to a character for no good reason, like it or not
-Childish convoluted story,
-Short [Less than 5 hours unless you stop by and walk around the scenarios]

I Pre-ordered the game thinking that it could be very good optimized for PC as the other RE games before this, boy i was wrong. Months later after the big ammount of patches and updates the game is still unstable.

reviewText:
I really don't like this game. Not because it's bad but because it's so god damn boring with some really annoying controls and really annoying AI with cheap deaths and cheap encounters designed to kill you the first time you experience it. That and the fact each chapter is literally an hour to two hours long with half of each chapter being simple copy & paste levels.

-==Minor spoilers==-

One of the first big This is BS!" moments for me was in Episode 1 playing through it as Clare. Right near the end
date: at the end of the main zone in the chapter
recommended: there's a part where you literally have to know what you're doing to not die and you won't catch onto it in the five seconds the game allows you to pull it off to complete the part without dying. This is the part where you have to open a gate which triggers a hoard
hoursPlayed: pass through the gate
voteText: turn a lever and run back to turn a flamethrower turret around to face the entrance
helpfulPercent: cutting off the zombies. The design is so cheeky they clearly place a healing item in the far corner of the room in direct vision of where the objective is: The lever. The lever itself just looks like a dull
votesHelpful: bland fixture. 90% of people will run straight to pick up the healing item and run past the lever to trigger the flame turret. If you're fast enough you'll catch the "E" flash as you near the lever but you literally have to hit the lever without error to get past the area without letting hulks in who will
votesTotal: in close quaters
votesFunny: ♥♥♥♥ you up.\n\nThe second "This is BS!" moment for me was in Episode 2 near the beginning where
commentsCount: yet again
column16: a horde is triggered and you have zero idea what to do. This is when a boss appears in the little bar they set up. It turns out he's unkillable so you have to run around until a cinematic cuts in... A cinematic that stops you from controlling the character
column17: can't be skipped and has about a 2second delay after it ends before it allows you to fully control your character again. Then you have to run and climb a ladder which is pretty straight forward except for the fact your companion AI is utterly stupid so if you do manage to get up the ladder the AI
column18: Moira in most cases
column19: will bit lagging way behind trying to get up the ladder and most likely getting herself killed which prompts you to go and rescue her or you fail and have to retry anyway. Then
column20: while waiting for her to get up on the roof enemies climb up the ladder and spam jump attacks at you as Clare. You will die here on your first playthrough unless you've already died to it and know what to expect.\n\nThe third "This is BS!" moment for me was in Episode 2 near the end of the chapter when you finally catch up to Natalia. Shortly after you meet up with her a boss drops on your head. Literally. Not only that but the game continually spawns in mobs in sets of two as you fight this massive
column21: fat blob that shoots out fireballs from it's magic urn. You also have very little ammo and very few items to use. This also happens in an area where there are hulks and other normal mobs roaming around so if you go past a certain point to trigger the boss without killing the other enemies(In a large open room) you are absolutely ♥♥♥♥ed
column22: sir.\n\nAfter the third BS moment I wasn't mad
column23: I wasn't angry. I was just bored
column24: disappointed and put down the game happily. Up until this point everything was the same. Enemies only really jumped out at you in a lame attempt at jump scares
column25:
some enemies just stood there with their backs to you for obvious stealth kill scenarios(Which isn't actually explained to you until Episode 1 part 2 as Barry I might add!) and some played dead but mostly it was just predictible jump scares where enemies were hidden in corners or behind doors waiting to jump out or lying down on the ground in an obscure place... That or they just spawned in in areas you didn't have visbility on. Boring. The fact that most of the level design consists of linear corridors it just wasn't very engaging or at alll entertaining to play through.

Then you have the repeated levels for each character playthroug(There's only two sides of the story: Clare and Barry's scenarios). Played through an episode as Clare? Enjoy it? Well you better have loved it because we're going to make you play through it again except as Barry but set six months later and slight alterations to the level with one or two minor areas unlocked to force you through. It's just boring. It wasn't cool to copy and paste entire levels in Dragon Age 2 and it certainly hasn't been cool since!

Companions also suck. There's very little reason to use them other than to be forced to use them to hunt for hidden items. And by hidden I mean items you can't see unless you hold your flashlight over them(Clare and Moira) or point your finger at them(Barry and Natalia). This is the soul purpose of companions: To find hidden items planted across the level -- items that could be placed ANYWHERE but are invisible until your companion flashes their light on it or points in it's direction. They do nothing when they aren't controller. They have lame abilities they never use unless you control them such as Moira's ability to "stun" and enemy by flashing a light in their eyes or Natalia's ability to detect enemies(Which is only used when you control her). Playing as Barry is boring because all you do is crouch and play as Natalia then wait to see an enemy appear with her monster vision
column26: switch to Barry and either stealth kill it(Crouch behind it and knife it for an instakill) or shoot it from a distance.\n\nIt's just not very fun. It's just a very boring game to play complemented with cheap scenarios that are designed to flat out kill you without a chance to beat it the first time you encounter them."

reviewText:
Don't buy this game if not every episode is on sale. You won't even enjoy every bit unless you unlock the game. I played the episode one, and just like every RE fan I enjoyed it. The things is, the mechanics are good and the game itself is a very nice port but the way they presented the game towards the PC is absolute cash grab.

Objectives are obvious to do, with no little challenge as compared to old RE titles (PS1 Director's Cut was harder, and even then bullets were as scarce as ♥♥♥♥) and you can pick up obviously convenient items along the way. You can't even die from getting mauled by an axe-wielding infected (and I'm already playing on the hardest difficulty of the game)

The storyline is rich and I can see that CAPCOM gave it a very, very surprisingly (and pretty obvious) twist. But I find the lack of environmental interaction and how your choices matter in the game is somewhat plunged into a canal of disappoint since you only get to do objectives towards the pace the game has to offer.

Unless you want to spend a few bucks to find some obvious jumpscares and get to see a Jill Sandwhich go ahead. But I recommend getting other full Resident Evil Games instead of being lured to a episode-based cash grab sequel.

reviewText: As much as I love RE, I have found yet another game in the franchise that tried too hard, and got less than nowhere.  First problem, the frame rate is screwy, no matter what you set your own to, the game will not work properly.  I could HEAR the entire opening scene, but I couldn't see it.  Character development might have been nice, but I couldn't see it to judge fairly.  Enemies (because of the fps problem) literally materialized either from nowhere, or a minute after their sound were heard.  Really screwed with whatever enjoyment of the game I might have had.  The interface with the mouse and keyboard didn't quite sync up, making pulling or using a weapon detrimental to my health, lol.  I ended up returning it after an hour of gameplay".  Thats in quotes because most of the time I was on pause
date: trying to figure out or reconfigure the controls so I could play."

reviewText:
This game is inconcievably broken in every way I can imagine: the controller support sucks, especially when you try to aim after running; the keyboard support, surprisingly, also sucks; the default sensitivity is WAY too high, and the button mapping on both keyboard and controller is atrocious.

Really not sure which group of gamers this game was designed for. It's a shame I can't dismiss it as just being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ console port.

An equal shame that THIS is the follow-up to Revelations... I'm especially disappointed in you lately, Capcom.

reviewText:
i love resident evil.

this game is amazing so far and im barely about to start episode 3....so im half way there?

PROS:
i love the story (so far)

gameplay is fantastic

graphics are great

the atmosphere is pretty creepy and feels like old skool resident evil

the monsters are awesome and feel like zombies again

the boss fights (so far) are pretty sick

the weapons are good and plentyful

the weapon upgrade system and upgrades are cool

CONS:
still a little frame loss during certain areas but not a lot and im sure it'll get fixed at some point

The invisible bugs are gey, dumbest idea ever to put in a game, soooo gey. should be removed from the game and something more interesting should be put in its place....soo gey.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
if you like resident evil, either the old or the new, you'll love this. it's like a perfect combo of both :)

Resident Evil Revelations 2 isn't ur old school classical horror game, it is more like dead aim, more shooting with a few good jump scares, when i got ep.1 i thought let me try and if it is good ill go for the rest, well i did go for the rest the game's story isn't that good but it is a better story then most recent titles, the game's quite fun if you forget resident evil classical style of play and are more for the gun RE gun games it is a fantastic game.
______________________________________________________________ Now to what this game is great at, the raid mode is an epic mode like mercenaries used to be just made better, play through the game if you want to  know the story and get a hang of the game, but raid mode trust me,  this is the heart of this game, you have 2 kill many infected in a certain time period depending on the level, customisation is perfect in raid mod you can have a character with a lot of combonations, and there is a nice perk system, lot's of ways 2 play.
______________________________________________________________ pros:
- make you character how you want in raid mode
- many updates to raid mode
- good gameplay
- smooth fps
- many kinds of levels

cons:
- bad story
- high price
- bad options menu
- pay gates


Final Verdict 8.5/10

reviewText: (This review only covers the four main episodes of the game, and not the two bonus episodes that slot in between those chronologically.)\nI was too young to get involved with the Resident Evil franchise at its inception on the original PlayStation, and have only ever engaged in the franchise via Resident Evil 5.  My girlfriend is a huge fan of the movies and games however, and picked this up for us to play on the Steam Link in the living room together, so I figured I'd give it a whirl.  The original game was released episodically, so a base purchase will get you just Episode 1, and you can purchase each additional episode (a total of 4, plus 2 extras" that are more side stories than the rest) or pick everything up in a bundle like she did.  Its interesting as a gamer to see the episodic model slowly coming back into style after the model kind of petered out in the 00's with Half-Life and SiN.  Early Access games can take the model to the extreme end of things

column36: and for that the story comes out much more tolerable than other sketchy dubs of Japanese titles.\nI did experience some technical difficulties with massive frame drops and skipping in early gameplay

reviewText: So far so good. The first episode definitely brings me back to the first Resident Evil Revelations. I recommend this game for it's ongoing story and to see what will come next. A lot of people complain about episodic games, but there is an appeal to waiting for the next installment. It's like Christmas. But the game handles solid, the controls are tight and Raid Mode is a blast. Most nagative reviews have to do with game performance so make sure your computer is up to snuff.\n\nMy only gripe to speak of is that there is, as of yet, no online multiplayer for Coop Campaign or Raid mode. Yet. It is said that online capabilities will be coming later on down the line. Of course I wouldn't buy anything on maybe" but I have no consumer's remorse on this purchase and if you enjoyed Revelations 1
date: then you should get this game."

reviewText:
After playing through episode 1:

It's a good Resident Evil game and a worthy sequel to Revelations 1, which was one of my favourite RE games. It's not a cover shooter. At times there can be a shortage of ammunition if you are not careful, and the enemies feel dangerous. This makes it feel more like a survival horror game. There is about 2 hours of story gameplay in this first episode. You also get to play as Barry, which is great! There are some funny references to RE1.

The graphics feel rather dated. This is not a problem to me personally as long as the gameplay is good, but to some it might be an issue. I haven't noticed any dramatic framerate drops.

I have tried a few missions in the Raid mode and it's pretty fun. Gives something to do while waiting for the next episode.

+ Gameplay is enjoyable
+ Barry effing Burton!
+ Raid mode

- Graphics feel about 5 years old
- Sometimes enemies get stuck on doorframes etc.
- Something tells me people are not pleased with the missing local co-op, so let's mention it here...

+/- Episode structure. I hope I'm still interested when the next one comes out

Imperfect but fun game so I'm going to give it two out of two thumbs up.

reviewText:
I would strongly reccomend not buying this game at the current time due to the possibilty of having FPS issues. I have only got 10 minutes in and I am stuttering so bad that I cannot even look at the screen without feeling sick. The gameplay itself on other platforms is fantastic, and it is a really great game worth a buy. The PC version however, has way too many problems with it and it should really be look at.

Update: As of now, I somehow got the game to run at a decently playable level. The story, mechanics, and combat are fun. If there was a patch for the game that would come out to address some of the bugs, I would really reccomend the title.

The Character mechanics alone make for some interesting single player game play.

Also, inventory managment makes a triumphant return. You have to balance health items, weapon parts, secondary weapons, and ammo as you go along to make sure that you are going to be able to pick up helpful items.

reviewText:
As of 2/27/2015, the game is mostly playable save some raid maps which slow down to a slideshow. I'm running an X4 860k paired up with a 750ti. It's really not that bad, I can usually keep 60fps running at max. I don't think the issue deserves a negative rating as I'm sure it will get patched sooner or later (optimistic). Edit: It's fixed.

The game itself is solid. However, coming from the prespective of someone who played RE6 a lot, the mechanics are a step down. I'm not sure if it's the game or just the port, but the controls seem a little rigid, especially the running and aiming. It has nuances that you have to keep in mind. Specifically, while your character is in a sprint, you have to only press forward and change direction with the mouse. If you try to move left or right with the keyboard, it will shift the camera in that direction. This wouldn't be a problem normally, but the speed it changes the view is too fast. It's minor, but having the reverse controls would have made more sense (ala RE6).

The story is typical. It has a much more horror" feel (still not very scary
date: but it does get tense). The first episode is laughably short. Anybody can go through it in 3 hours at most. It almost felt like a tutorial. I'm really hoping the next episodes will be much longer.\n\nPartner switching is back! This is the best addition
recommended: in my opinion I feel like this is neglected a lot. Claire gets Moira while Barry gets Natalia. Moira initially gets to use the flashlight which can stun enemies which allows you to either melee them
hoursPlayed: or switch to Claire to follow up with a ranged attack
voteText: you can then switch again to keep stunning the enemy. Switching back and forth is very fun
helpfulPercent: and finding ways to circumvent enemies with both characters is satisfying. Barry's Natalia takes more planning as she can throw a brick once before having to retreive another. This makes sense as the enemies you encounter in Barry's story are slower while they are faster in Claire's. This great design in play
votesHelpful: and Capcom is not getting any recognition for it.\n\nRaid mode
votesTotal: what can I say. It's fun. It's no mercenaries
votesFunny: though. Progress by beating missions and upgrade your skills and weapons. I'm not a fan of the weapon upgrade system
commentsCount: a lot of the time it feels like RNG
column16: but at least you're never totally underpowered and having to keep up with new weapons does mix things up a bit.\n\nI recommend the game to the Resident Evil fans. For everyone else
column17: please know what you are getting. A solid game with a few hiccups. It's not broken like some others are making it out to be."

reviewText: This game wasn't at all what i expected but I was still blown away. I am a massive fan of Resident Evil and never miss a game. I was expectng this game to carry on in the vein of Revelations 1 but it seems to be more like RE6. The gameplay, graphics and especially the sound are all top notvh and can't be faulted. I did have a few problems running the game to start with, there was a lot of random frame dropping, but once that was sorted I was fully immersed. The first episode was amazing and felt like a throwback to the old days with it's zombies and overall atmosphere. The introduction of new enemies and characters is really keeping this series fresh and this is no exception.\nHighly recommend.\n9/10
voteText: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I recommend this game firstly to a fan of Resident Evil who can enjoy it's nurmerous changes in game design (I'm mainly stating this because of the recent remaster of the re-released remake of Resident Evil 1). The weekly episodes is something I'm new to, never got to play Telltale's Walking Dead series. So, I think it's pretty cool, because not only do I have an extended value of the game, it's Raid mode has more replay value than expected. Having the game released in episodes, at the price of $6, seems justifiable. The online store is only there if I want to actually spend more money on the game, entirely up to my decision. I'm never reminded of the online store anywhere in the game, aside from opening the in-game store and the red crystal icon, which is so small its not even annoying.

The game does have its far share of problems though, one being the dropping of frame rate in certain areas of the campaign and on certain maps of raid mode that I guess require a lot of rendering. It confuses and irrates me particularly because, for me personally, similar maps on different difficulties will drop frame rate dramatically. My laptop can handle other games at max settings with ease, so this is a problem the developers will need to fix for the community, and I'm sure they will because they are releasing weekly and bugs/problems show up regardless of any game.

If you can get past the rough edges of this game, then I hope you'll enjoy it, because I enjoy it immensly for what it is and I'm excited to see what happens in the following weeks of the game.

reviewText:
Quite Good Game
I been playing Resident evil since the first one was released in the 90's and its always nice to see new releases of the series. Now i first notice peoples been talking about FPS drops a lot, but i myself have not had any problems with the game at all.

Good Graphics: They seem to have done a mixture of old style resident evil and new style wich i really enjoy seeing, plus this game is not like the first revelations wich was made for Nintendo 3Ds, so the graphical detail is quite good.
Game Runs Smoothly: Im using MSI GTX 970 Gaming 4g, i5-4440 Processor, 12gig Ram, Windows 8.1 (No FPS drops at all, smooth all the way)
Multiplayer/Co-Op: This is one of the reasons peoples are buying this game, if you have a friend or mate you often play with this should be a game to look for.
For 25€ this game is nicely priced: Im not sure why they decided to ask so less from a brand new game, but the game really seems to be worth for the money.
Only negative i could find about the game so far is that its being released in Episodes? this isint exactly any new concept due many games have done this but for a resident evil game i find it quite odd, but... if you can look past it, the game is surely a good one to consider buying.

reviewText:
Resident Evil is always a tough sell. It's reached the point where not many would find enjoyment in these games save for those invested in the series.
Here we stand on a unique beast. A PC port of a sequel to a spin off series that started on a handheld, and yet oft touted as the 'return to roots' we've always desired.

Do I enjoy Resident Evil Revelations 2? Yes, quite throughly in fact. But Capcom has seemingly gone out of their way this time to ensure that I wouldn't.

For starters: The game is nearly unplayable with a mouse and keyboard. Even at the lowest camera and aiming sensativity settings, the mouse driven camera is an unwieldly beast. Dashing with keyboard controls is fine, until making any form of turn, at which point the camera spins wildly. Some animations do not play nice with keyboard bindings, and its quite curious as to why. Especially considering: None of these issues are present when using a controller. Unfortunately, this is the only method of play I can tolerate given the mouse and keyboard issues, and having purchased the game on PC with hopes of using my prefered method of input, I am certainly disapointed.

I suppose I could throw in my two cents about the offline co-op debacle as well: I don't care in the slightest. Modders have patched it in, and there are clearly some issues, so one can understand why the feature was axed. Moreover, I have no idea under what circumstances I would be playing a game split screen on my PC. I've yet to play the game cooperatively online either, but given the mechanics, I don't see the game being very enjoyable if one player is nigh defenceless. The character swapping works quite well solo, and I think I'll leave it that way.

Some other notes: The game is pretty great looking. Environment textures are a bit on the lacking side, but character models look great when the game is cranked. Shooting (with a controller) is pretty responsive, and feels like a step up from Revelations 1.

So, can I recommend Resident Evil Revelations 2? I suppose I could, with a few added stipulations: If you're a fan of the series (or at the very least, the previous game), and you don't mind using a controller, then sure, there's some fun to be had here, especially considering the low price.
